TALK.START.PARA: —The Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) seeks to modify the procedures for allocating satellite pay television broadcasting licences. This matter arises directly as a result of the current, long running fiasco in relation to the tender process for pay television licences.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that those who have a knowledge of the history of broadcasting in this country would be able to cast their minds back to the late 1980s, when we had an auction system for AM-FM conversion for radio licences. The experience on that occasion was that, at the height of the boom of the market, there were those who were prepared to pay extraordinary sums of money. Indeed, the successful bid for the first licence in Melbourne was by 3KZ, which paid $31 million. The second highest bid was one lodged by Bond Media, which at that time was required to lodge a deposit of $10,000. Subsequently, Bond Media was not in a position to come up with that amount of money and after a significant period of time the bid fell over. It then went to the next in line, which happened to be the then 3DB. It paid about $10 million.

The lesson from all that was that a great deal of delay and inconvenience was caused, and a great deal of uncertainty by the market, because of what was regarded as a highly desirable tender process. As a result of that lesson learned by the department, it was decided in relation to the MDS licences that there would be a requirement for a five per cent deposit to be paid up front. That was in order to ensure that those who bid for the licence were genuine, that they were serious long-term players and that they had the financial capacity to at least come up with a small proportion of the amount that they were claiming to be able and prepared to pay in due course, if they were ultimately granted the licence.

That is an approach that made a great deal of sense and commended itself to the department and, indeed, to this very Minister, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), who signed the determination authorising that approach to be adopted in relation to MDS licences.

As to what then happened, there is no doubt that in reaching that position the Minister took advice, as any reasonable Minister would—advice such as any sensible department would offer. That advice accompanied the determination. One presumes that he read both the advice and the determination before signing it and he was, therefore, fully seized of the intention of the department, the preferred approach, one that the Government itself chose. No doubt he was mindful that the department ought to have learnt from history and would not make the same mistakes again. So there we had a Minister, not inexperienced—one who has been a Minister of the Crown for three years or more—who had been in this portfolio for some months already and was then consciously turning his mind to the requirement for a five per cent deposit to be paid.

What happened, nonetheless, was that on 19 January the Minister was provided with the determination, accompanied, one can only presume, by advice from the department, which he read. If that is not the case we will presumably hear about it in due course but it is unthinkable that any Minister could simply sign a document without taking other advice. Indeed, there are a number of sources of advice. If one is in any doubt the advice ranges from the experts that Ministers are able to employ on their personal staff to the department, where one has as many experts as can be afforded within budget constraints to advise on all manner of technical and policy decisions. In addition, there is nothing to stop a Minister from going to the outside industry and seeking further advice if so minded.

In a situation where a determination is presented, one is expected to read that before signing it, otherwise we do not need Ministers. We simply authorise bureaucrats to sign documents and, presumably, if they get it wrong they get the chop. So there is a very clear line of responsibility. That is why we have secretaries to the departments. There are circumstances in which, even through no fault of their own, departments are seen to be under-performing and secretaries get moved around. There is no shortage of sheeting home responsibility to those who are nominally in charge. In this situation, this Minister was presented with a determination which he signed on 19 January. He has given various explanations, one of which has been that he checked it for completeness. He has shied away from conceding outright that he did not read a word of it, but he has effectively said that he did not read the document—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read it.
—Oh, the Minister did read it, all right.
—I said so, Senator.
—He now says he read it. We clearly argue—
—I said then that I read it.

—How long did it take to read it? The point is that one can read, one can glance, one can look at a document. I presume the Minister is saying he did not comprehend the significance of it. If that is the case, one has to ask why, because this is not just another piece of paper. This is arguably the most significant document in the history of satellite pay television in this country, because this is what gets the game formally under way. This is what brings applicants into the game and this is what requires people to apply their minds to very large sums of money, not just in the short term, but over a much longer period of time. So the Minister was not being presented with just another piece of paper, just another one of the many documents that are presented to Ministers. He was being asked to address his mind to the formal start of the process, the determination that would get the whole game up and running. What did he do? He apparently read, without comprehending, a very significant clause that simply required the payment of a nominal handling charge of $500. Any reasonable person would expect that a Minister of experience, a Minister who had been through this very same process in relation to MDS licences, would be acutely aware, not just of the history of the matter, but of the necessity to have in place a sensible requirement such as a five per cent deposit. Yet for reasons that are not yet clear, he simply chose to sign that document and to return it.

PARA.TAB: We do not know whether he had advice. He says staff members were not present. Presumably the whole department was not away on vacation. Even if those people were, they are expected to be on call. Similarly, staff members are expected to be on call; they get overtime built into their salaries. Of course, one would expect them to be ready at all times to cast their eyes over important documents. It is no excuse in the slightest to suggest that somehow, because one staff member is away, a Minister is absolved from applying his independent mind, discretion and judgment to a very significant cause.

The important aspect of this Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 is that it is clearly sheeting home direct responsibility to this Minister. He has spent the last 10 days or so trying to blame everyone but himself, trying to shuffle responsibility off to his department, setting up an inquiry to identify all the shortcomings of the bureaucrats. At all times he has been absolutely determined, not only not to acknowledge any breach of ministerial responsibility, but not even to answer questions on the subject, under the dubious and quite wrong basis that somehow that committee overrides the processes of the Senate and the Senate estimates committees.

In other words, there is absolutely no reason at all why the Minister should not be accountable to the Senate, why he should not provide explanations on these matters. But he has chosen, for damage control purposes, to hide behind the establishment of a committee. One can understand the political imperatives in all that, but suffice it to say it is simply nowhere near good enough. If the doctrine of ministerial responsibility means anything in this day and age, it means that Ministers ought to be responsible for their own decisions. If they sign important documents, they ought to take advice beforehand, and they accept the consequences of their actions. In the situation where the Minister chose not to insert a five per cent deposit requirement, a number of very important consequences flowed. They were that all of the potential applicants then structured their bids around the rules of the game.

No-one can be critical of that because that is normal commercial sensible practice. Naturally enough, what we had was a whole series of people putting in up to 50 bids when all the experts were guessing that there might be only one applicant for licence B and there was a bit of speculation about two or three international heavyweights who might put in for licence A. Everyone was astounded to discover that there were 50-plus bids. Indeed, the informed speculation is that, of those, 19 are multiple collapsible bids. In other words, it was a complete farce—perfectly proper within the rules, but nonetheless one that presumably this Minister, in his wildest dreams, would not have contemplated if he had bothered to comprehend what he read. Indeed, in my judgment, if one does not comprehend, one has not read—one has looked at the document; and that is nowhere near good enough.

The fact remains that, the rules having been set and the processes put in train, the rules of the game simply cannot be changed midstream. This is not expressed to apply to the current prospective winners, UCOM and Hi Vision, but of course what this Bill does say is that they are expected to fall over.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not.

—The guilty conscience is very evident up front. Almost in the first couple of lines of the press release that announced this immediate and knee-jerk response to Terry McCrann's article we find the Minister saying that this is not in any way intended to reflect on the commercial capacity of these two bidders. That is put in purely and simply because the Minister was acutely conscious of the fact that that was precisely what it did.

PARA.TAB: What we say is that it is not proper to pass judgment in that way. It is certainly not proper to introduce amendments before the event has even occurred. Whether or not we might all think it will happen or is likely to happen, whether or not we think these bids are utterly unrealistic, whether or not they are much, much higher than anyone had reasonably anticipated, and whether they are multiples of the bids that were put in by those that might be regarded as serious players, the fact remains that the tender process allowed for bids of $177 million and $212 million respectively to be put on the table. What the Minister then says, in effect, is: `We will assume that that will fall over because then we will put in place arrangements that will ensure that those who come afterwards will have to put up five per cent within three days'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said—

—If what I have said is checked, it will be found that I said that there was a widespread expectation in the community, and certainly amongst the players in the game, that that was what would happen. If the Minister wants to say that they will fall over I would be very interested to hear it, because that would seem to be the only possible basis for introducing this amendment at this time. Otherwise he would wait and see, and when the 30 days had expired and these bids had not been successful, he would be proceeding with amendments. He is introducing them at this stage only because he takes the view that A and B will not survive. Not only is that prejudging the matter but, as I have said, it certainly does not make their capacity to raise funds in the marketplace any easier. I would have thought that it simply demonstrates the panic-mode, knee-jerk response to an article written by Terry McCrann, less than 24 hours after which we had the Minister's press release being put out. If ever there was policy making on the run, then this is it. It is certainly not the first time and I am sure it will not be the last. The important thing to remember is that, once a process has been set in train and once the rules of the game have been established, they simply cannot be changed without it being a retrospective process.
—What if you find out it is wrong? Do you just let it go?

—Has the Minister decided it is wrong? Has he decided that A and B should not be allowed to proceed, should not be allowed to come up with the money, because, if so, this is all irrelevant, utterly academic, and of no importance at all? This Bill can only ever be relevant if those applicants fall over. From that point on a whole series of things might happen, but the fact remains that, if there are 50, the next 48 went into the process on certain defined terms prescribed by the Minister. They have their acquired rights, they are entitled to assume that those rights will not be affected midstream; and yet that is what this amendment proposes to do.

PARA.TAB: It makes it clear that the Government wants to change the rules simply because of what it now acknowledges to have been a monumental error. But one does not change the rules part way through the process. One does not assume, for example, that if these two do not get to the barrier it might be another two or three years because everyone will take 30 days plus 45 days and maybe even longer, and that process will simply multiply right down to the bottom. None of those assumptions can be made because, again, that would be second-guessing what will happen as a result of the process the Government has established. Therefore, not only is it premature to be introducing them before the 30 days expires but it is quite unfair to those with acquired rights. The Minister is attempting to make judgments about what will happen down the track when he has absolutely no idea. He does not know whether any bids will be withdrawn. He does not know whether there will be rearrangements. All of these consortiums are very fluid and are perfectly capable of being restructured on short notice—

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know?
—I am saying that they are capable of it. It has certainly been put to me by a number of people that they are, and I would not have thought the Minister would agree that they are locked in cement.
—That is the silliest argument you have ever put.

—I am sorry that the Minister does not understand it or follow it. I am not being critical of him for that. The fact remains that the Act itself allows for licences to be transferred, for bids to be withdrawn and for restructuring of arrangements to take place at any time. In those circumstances, the last thing the Minister ought to be doing is making yet another assumption about what will flow after the 30-day period and then introducing amendments that somehow are designed significantly to restrict the activities of subsequent applicants. Therefore, we will be voting against this Bill. Not only is it retrospective but, clearly, it is interfering with rights of all those who are currently bidders. It is, therefore, manifestly unfair. The Minister must stop making policy changes on the run and acknowledge that responsibility stops with him and that he cannot simply blame his department and everyone else. Within the space of about 24 hours of this fiasco—
—You just want the mess to go on until August.

—It does not necessarily have to go on to any particular point in time. It can be adequately resolved, in a very short space of time, within the rules that have been established. The Minister knows the commercial realities. Those who are in the game are not juveniles. They know what they can do. They know whom they can talk to. They know how to negotiate. The last thing we ought to be doing is somehow prescribing, or proscribing, the way in which those processes should proceed. Yet that is what this Bill does, simply because once again the Minister has got it wrong and wants to patch it up on the run. That is why it makes a great deal of sense to sit back and have a good think about these things, to let the process take its course, as the Minister intended when he signed that fatal determination. If he does that, I am sure that matters will work themselves out, that we will get licences issued in the not too distant future and that we will have a process that is in accordance with the rules established by the Government. But to change the arrangements at this stage not only is unfair but is further confirmation of the panic mode that is gripping the Government at the present time.

—The tendering document for pay TV satellite licences was obviously flawed, by anyone's standards, in that it did not require a percentage non-refundable deposit at the time of allocation of the licence to demonstrate the financial bona fides of the successful tenderer. I do not think anybody would disagree with that. The Australian Democrats still advocate, and we have done this all along, that for all licence tenders there should be some merit based requirements. Financial and business plans should be lodged in all cases. The national interest must always be taken into account. We still want to see those requirements put on all future tenders.

PARA.TAB: There is no reason, however, in this debate to go over the reasons why this tender document was flawed. That debate will occur when the findings of Professor Pearce's inquiry are tabled. We have told the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) that we want a reasonable time to consider the findings of the inquiry, and he has agreed to that. We expect to see that report by Professor Pearce on the table in the Senate so that we have at least the last week of sitting for this session to consider it. The Minister is nodding, so he is agreeing to that too.

We believe that the tender document was basically flawed when the financial deposit was omitted. If we are going to see pay TV in this country—and I still say, as I did in the last debate, that we do not see that it is a major priority—we might as well have a tender that proceeds smoothly from today where everybody knows where they stand. It is all up in the air at the moment. We want something firm and we want it today. We will, therefore, be supporting this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This second broadcasting Bill which we have before us this afternoon, the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993, simply reflects the fiasco that the Government's policy and administration of the introduction of pay TV has become over the last couple of weeks. Since Parliament resumed last week, we have seen a most unedifying spectacle. Not only the Minister at the table today, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), but also in the other place the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall) have been ducking and weaving and stonewalling to cover up their incompetent administration of this pay television area, refusing to answer quite legitimate and serious questions on the issue.

PARA.TAB: As the shadow Minister, Senator Alston, outlined in some detail a little while ago, the issues and this legislation itself have arisen basically because two unknowns, UCOM and Hi Vision, were the successful bidders for the two satellite pay television licences which were to be issued purely on the basis of price based bids. However, because of the way in which this tendering process was conducted, we have absolutely no guarantee that these two players can actually deliver their bids. We do not have even the somewhat limited guarantee of a five per cent deposit of the bid amount being required of the bidders. Hence the fiasco that we have seen over the past 10 days, with the Minister refusing point blank to answer quite relevant and legitimate questions about this issue, both day after day in this chamber and on Tuesday night in the Senate estimates committee hearings.

The fact that the Minister has set up his own pet inquiry is no justification for failing to answer questions put to him, either here or in the estimates committee, especially when they are simple questions of fact such as I asked at the Senate estimates committee on Tuesday night. Perhaps it is worth relaying several of those questions to the Senate just so that we can understand how simple and direct they were and how easily answerable they should have been. Among those were questions such as: on what date was a decision reached within the department not to require a five per cent deposit for any successful television licence applicants under the satellite proposals? On what research was the decision not to require a deposit based? What were the department's grounds for making such a decision? And finally: what was the department's specific purpose in not requesting a deposit?

They are very simple questions. They are basically questions of fact which the Minister and his department ought to have been able to answer, but they refused point blank to answer them. We were able to establish on Tuesday night that this is the first time a price based tender system has not required a deposit to establish the bona fides of the bidders, at least in the past few years. Also, according to Senator Collins on Tuesday, his transport and communications department is a highly competent, highly efficient department which is at the cutting edge, as he claimed, of fostering micro-economic reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is.

—The Minister interjects that it is. He reinforces that claim. If that is the case, the only logical conclusion we can reach is that the failure to require a five per cent deposit was not an error, it was not an omission, it was not a blue by the department. On the contrary, we can conclude only that it was a conscious and deliberate decision. The relevant question to ask is: why was this decision made?
—There is to be an inquiry and we will find out.

—The Minister says that there is to be an inquiry and that we will find out. Why do we have to wait for that inquiry? If there were good and proper reasons for that decision being taken, they are obviously known now, this Senate is the proper place to provide those reasons. Why not tell us, and tell us now? Obviously, those reasons would be known. The representatives of the people in this place have a right to know. They have a right to know now whether the department had good and proper reasons for not requiring that five per cent deposit. We also have a right to know what those reasons were.

PARA.TAB: We should not have to await the outcome of the Minister's own pet inquiry to get answers to questions like these. If the reasons are good, why is the Government changing now, by bringing in legislation belatedly requiring a five per cent deposit from the next highest bidders, if the UCOM and Hi Vision bids do in fact fall over? As Senator Alston said a few minutes ago, that is the only basis on which this legislation becomes applicable. Why is the Government now changing its position, if it did have good and legitimate reasons for not requiring that deposit at the outset? In the absence of the immediate answers to those very relevant and very legitimate questions, I believe we cannot support this legislation and it ought to be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that not only the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) but the whole of the Parliament has problems at this point of time. I think we should try to overcome the problems as best as we can with the least fall out. Clearly, the issue of ministerial responsibility is not ignored. That will no doubt be a very relevant part of the report of the inquiry, which the Minister has generated, and which he indicated will be presented to the Parliament in a week or two.

PARA.TAB: The measure that we have before us at the moment is an attempt to redress some of the failings that have been revealed in the current legislation and, as such, I am inclined to support them. However, one thing that was said by Senator Alston has concerned me—perhaps the Minister could address this in his reply—and that is the issue of retrospectivity. Senator Alston indicated that the measure that is currently before us has an element of retrospectivity. I am not able in my study of the Bill to detect that element of retrospectivity. I will be interested in what the Minister has to say in his reply. I will also be interested to hear whether Senator Alston has anything to add to his comments in the Committee of the Whole—that there is an element of retrospectivity in this legislation.

I believe that Australia cannot afford pay TV. However, it is on the road now and it is up to us to do the best we can to ensure that the legislation is sufficient to protect the consumer. I am not sure that the provisions in section 98 that deal with the second phase, which the current applications for the A and B licences are undergoing, are capable of ensuring that. I believe that there should be tighter provisions as to merit in section 98 of the legislation. But, I have no amendments to that effect. I just raise that issue with the Government at this stage.

I would like to address also the matter of the licensees themselves. It came as some surprise to everybody around the place, I suppose, including the Minister, that one of the five directors of Hi Vision, a company that has been a successful bidder, was a porn merchant of some long standing. That did not come as a surprise to me because I mentioned it in the Senate in 1984, and it should have been known by people who would have been interested in that aspect. I am not suggesting that the Minister should have known it. Perhaps I should have drawn it to his attention, but he has been saying that he is at arm's length from the subject and it was not my province, I believe, to do that.

My concern is the protection of the consumer. The possibility of such companies, with such influence, gaining control of pay TV in a particular area heightens the need for us to have a good look at the legislation and to see whether, in the end, Parliament is able to provide that protection. I am suggesting not that we should go on in a proactive manner but that we should at least have a fall-back position where the Parliament can have a say, particularly over the standards that apply to pay TV.

I have distributed throughout the chamber an amendment which goes to schedule 2, part 6, of the broadcasting services legislation. In clause 10(g) there is a provision that R-rated material will not be able to be broadcast over pay TV until Australia-wide quantitative and qualitative research on community standards of taste and decency has been conducted by the ABA and the ABA has approved the broadcast of such programs. That is a very important issue. It was, I believe, the intention of the Parliament, on the last occasion when we were discussing this, to have a situation whereby the Parliament has some final say over the matter.

I moved an amendment which was gutted by the Government. Nevertheless, the gutted version now appears as section 128 of the legislation, which enables the standards and codes to be amendable by the Parliament—standards and codes which apply to all types of broadcasting and television, including commercial, narrowcasting, and so forth. Because that provision is in (g), where the ABA has the final decision, it may be regarded as a standard or code by some, but my advice now is that it is not regarded as a standard or a code. Therefore, it does not come within the scope of section 128. Consequently the Parliament will not even have the minimum fall-back position that is currently available under section 128.

The effect of section 128 is that, even if a resolution is passed in this place, it is not really going to be dealt with unless the Government ensures that it gets on into the House of Representatives. So there are fairly severe checks on the operation of section 128 as it applies. What I am trying to do is to amend the legislation to close that loophole.

I will be quite frank with the chamber. The amendment that has been distributed to honourable senators does state that these programs—the R-rated programs—will not be able to be broadcast unless the ABA has recommended and the Parliament has, by resolution of each House, approved the broadcast of such programs. I must admit that that is stronger than if the ABA or the industry had made these a standard or a code of practice which are amendable by the Parliament pursuant to section 128.

I am happy to have a fall-back position which would simply eliminate the anomaly and place that decision of the ABA in the same situation as any other decision by the ABA in respect of code of practice and standard. I do not think it can be argued that this would not be a standard—it is a standard. Clearly, it is a standard. It is just a matter of some clever draftsperson getting hold of section 128(a)—unless, of course, the chamber wants to agree to this amendment, which I would be happy with. As I say, I have to be honest. It is stronger than what is currently provided for under section 128. I suppose, in fairness, that I would be happy if section 128 applied to that particular decision of the ABA as though it were a standard or code of practice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the explanation Senator Harradine has just given. We will not be dealing with the committee stage until later this evening. I will access the Hansard, which will, of course, allow us to consider Senator Harradine's proposed amendment in relation to the explanation he has now given for it. We will do that and I will advise Senator Harradine after we have done that whether the Government is in a position to agree with at least his fall-back position, if not the first position.

PARA.TAB: The argument that was run here in the Senate today by the Opposition is the thinnest and the most transparent argument I have heard run by the Opposition in any debate in the six years that I have been in the Senate. The Opposition's credibility is absolutely on the line today. The Government's credibility and my personal credibility have been under constant attack now for some time. Decisions will be made—and, indeed, may well be made by myself in hindsight—about the Government's credibility and my credibility in terms of decisions taken—and this, I might add, is a common occurrence—which looked sensible, rational, reasonable, proper and responsible at the time when events and circumstances were as they were but which, when one looks back on it, have changed.

But today the credibility of the Opposition is on the line. I was actually half expecting that Senator Alston would walk in here today and say that, although those opposite were going to kick up a stink about it and say that the Government had made errors, they were going to support the Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993. I actually did think he might have done that, because the line that the Opposition is running on this today and the position it is taking is the most irrational, illogical and, in the truest sense of the word, irresponsible position that I have ever seen the Opposition take.

I spent a lot of time in opposition, unlike 90 per cent of my colleagues. I had 10 long years of it—five as leader. I handed out enough stick in my time, so I am not complaining about that. But at the end of the day—and the Hansard record of the Northern Territory Parliament will show it—I supported sensible things that the Government did. I often praised it for doing sensible things.

I actually cooperated with the Northern Territory Government on this. I supported it in the Parliament. We were the first place in Australia to do something about pornography being sold over the counter. In fact, Senator Harradine will recall the debate when I said that I had raised it in the Northern Territory Parliament after a visit to my local video store in Malak, where I lived. There was a cardboard box of remaindered X-rated videos at the cash register which were being sold for $20 a copy. I raised the matter in the Parliament.

As a result of cooperation between the then Opposition leader, me, and the then Government—I gave it public credit for this—legislation was introduced to restrict the sale of not just X-rated videos but also R-rated videos. I might add that this was against the screams of the video shop operators. I believe it was the first time in Australia that it happened. I think my memory is correct on that. We restricted not just X-rated—it still happens, Senator Harradine—but R-rated material so that it had to be put into separate areas, closed off, and not admissible to anyone under the age of 18. My record is very clear on this. Castigate the Government, by all means, for its mistakes—I have done plenty of that—but, having kicked it to death, if it proposes something sensible, support it.

I will just show the Senate how thin Senator Alston's arguments are and, boy, are they thin! Senator Alston said that one of the reasons he is not going to support this legislation is that it contains an imputation against the financial success, viability and stature of these companies. He knows it does not. The imputation is there, he says, and that is terrible. I thought Senator Alston's public statements, and also Dr Hewson's, about these companies were terrible. I said to my staff, when I had read and heard what Senator Alston had said, `This is outrageous, even for a shadow Minister. He might have his own views about the non-viability of these proposals but it is totally improper for him, even as the shadow Minister, to express them so early after the bids were announced'. This was before there was any question of porn merchants as directors or anything else. This was 24 hours after the bids were announced. It was an outrageous thing for him to say. What did Senator Alston say? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If a rank outsider wins the Melbourne Cup you send in the stewards.
That does not impute anything for the companies, does it? Honestly, Senator Alston should have a look at the public record before he comes in here with these silly assertions.

PARA.TAB: I told my staff that it was an outrageous thing for Senator Alston to have said publicly about these companies and that that would not help the companies much to get their money. Senator Alston went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The absence of any requirement for commercial viability or formal qualifications and the apparent lack of any meaningful qualitative assessment of the bids would appear to have resulted in prices being offered which are way beyond the values as anticipated by the market.

I thought that was an outrageous thing for him to say. I said to my staff, `We now have the shadow Minister publicly saying that, in his exalted opinion, the bids are too high'. That is not going to help the companies raise their money.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston has the absolute gall to come into the Parliament today and say that legislation, which he accepts, specifically exempts these two companies from their rights, and they have still got them, to go ahead and get the licences. If they pass the very intensive scrutiny that is required by the ABA in terms of their being fit and proper people to broadcast, if they pass the TPC, if they do their 30 days and if they come up with the money, they will get their licences.

Senator Alston is not specious enough to say, because he cannot, that the legislation prevents them. He says he is opposing this legislation on the grounds that there is an imputation in the legislation that will help them to not get these bids. The shadow Minister has publicly derided the companies and publicly stated that, in his view, the prices they offered were too high. Let us look at the real reason for his doing this: he just wants the confusion and the uncertainty to be continued. This is the most transparent and dishonest argument that has ever been put in here.

What happens after 30 days? I will tell the Senate. This Parliament gets up—that is what happens after 30 days—and it does not come back until August. That is the real reason, and he was not honest enough just to come out and say it. What he asserted was that he was concerned about an imputation contained in passing this legislation that these companies cannot get there. But he himself, in what I say was an outrageous statement, literally 24 hours after anyone even knew who they were, said publicly that in his professional opinion they had made too high a bid. In other words, it was not marketable and therefore, in his view, they could not have got the money. It is tissue thin. That is the real reason he does not want it passed.

We get to the point where I come in. Non-stop, crazy assertions have been made, by a shadow Minister who has never been a Minister, about what I have to do at my end. The definition of ministerial responsibility is raised once again. There is probably not a more debated subject in the parliaments of the world than everybody's definition of ministerial responsibility. Let us have a look at that. This week I have signed papers, pages of them, relating to over $50 million worth of roadworks. I will tell the Senate what the reality is. Any Minister deals with an enormous amount of paper. Not only does he deal with an enormous amount of paper but he has got one or two other things that he does at the same time. I will mention one of the other things that he does.

Under our system of responsible government, Ministers of the Crown—and this is a much debated subject—also have to be elected members of parliament. It is not like the American system, where they just bring them in off the street. They do not have to worry about the voters; they do not have to worry about getting elected so they can put their policies into practice; they just have to do their job, read the paper and do nothing else. Under a responsible system of government, we have also got a few things like constituents. When we are in the middle of an election campaign, we have got a few things to think about, like getting into parliament to ensure that the government's program can be continued. So, on top of everything else, what was I doing all this time? I was flat out—Senator Alston has already alluded to this as if it were something to be criticised—getting ready for a federal election campaign. That is what I was doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You got a bit stressed in it too.
—I loved Senator Macdonald's comment yesterday about how his party had succeeded in picking up two extra seats. That was a bit of a pyrrhic victory.

PARA.TAB: Ministers of the Crown have lots of things to do. Senator Alston's assertion that I was running around mobile polling booths is not correct. I do not think we had any mobile polling booths. But I went back to the Northern Territory in January and I confess that I had a deep suspicion that Parliament would not be sitting again in February. Our resources in the Northern Territory are pretty thin. Well, one of them is thin. I am a bit thicker. Basically they consist of my colleague—

TALK.START.PARA: —Between the ears, you mean.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I wonder whether these non-stop interjections, from someone who this morning could not be bothered actually debating the issue we are discussing, could cease.

PARA.TAB: I was doing these other things. I assert that what I said, or meant to say, when I talked about even my unconscious position on what my attitude to this bid was going to be was the correct and responsible decision. I took a decision that I was not going to, ab initio, sit down with my department and construct the tender process. That is what I meant. Others can have their own views about the wisdom of that. But I say, even in hindsight, that I am glad I did not, when I look at the backflips that have gone on, on the other side of the Parliament, when I get bucketed for intervening and when I get bucketed for not intervening. I made a decision that, ab initio, I was not going to sit down and say, `This is how we are going to construct the tender process'.

Did I look at the paper? Yes, I did. I read it. Here this morning, Senator Alston used the words `normal, sensible commercial practice'. That is correct. I assumed, and I have to accept responsibility for it—if people are going to say afterwards that that was a stupid assumption, they can—on the consistent, unbroken track record of my department in issuing broadcasting and telecommunications licences that, to quote Senator Alston, normal, sensible commercial practice would apply. Did I see the $500? Yes, I did. I made an assumption—it was not a conscious assumption—which I have now found was correct, about the amount of $500 being very low. I might add that these assets were potentially going to be worth $200 million. The department had applied a $50,000 requirement on an asset that might have been worth half a million, a $100,000 deposit requirement on an asset worth around a million—an MDS licence.

It never occurred to me, and I confess it—here is my responsibility, come and get me—that after it put a $100,000 deposit requirement on a million dollar asset, that on a $200 million potentially valuable asset there would be no deposit requirement. I saw the $500 and I assumed that it was such a low amount it was just a bookkeeping fee—that is, a cost recovery method of paying for the shuffling of the paperwork, or helping to, and that it would discourage specious or frivolous bids where anybody could sit down and just shove in $100,000 bids in a frivolous manner. So it would discourage that. But it never occurred to me—and I confess it never occurred to me—that anything other than, to quote Senator Alston, `normal, sensible, commercial practices' would not then be applied.

What is Senator Alston's party going to do about this? He said, `We should sit back and have a long think about policy'. I should have known that because I read this the other day, and I have just recalled it. How could I resist reading it? When one picks up a magazine called Quadrant and on the front, it says, `The future of the Liberal Party—Malcolm Fraser, C.D. Kemp—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Am I correct in presuming the Minister is closing the second reading debate?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not suggesting at all that that is not appropriate. I am querying the amount of time the Minister is speaking. He voted yesterday on a 20-minute time limit for speeches. He has now taken 25 minutes, and I was just wondering if you could give me a ruling on that.
—There is no point of order. The Minister's time was for 20 minutes and he has not spoken for that length of time. He has five minutes to go.

—I could not resist reading an article of the magazine that has on the front page a whole stack of articles about `the future of the Liberal Party—C.D. Kemp, John Stone' and so on. Listen to what John Stone said. I will say this: John Stone does not take any prisoners. Listen to what John Stone said about why the Liberal Party failed. Senator Alston—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I thought we were here debating broadcasting policy. I presume this Minister is serious about wanting to get to a sensible resolution of the matter and I therefore invite you to direct him to be relevant to the debate. It cannot conceivably be relevant to discuss the views of others about the future of the Liberal Party. We are more than happy to have that discussion with him after the event, if he would like to, but I do not see why the time of the chamber should be taken up with such irrelevancies.
—On the point of order, just briefly, I am responding in debate to the specific statement that Senator Alston made in this debate, that he is going to have a long think about this policy.
—The point of order is simply that nothing of the sort was said. I suggested the Minister ought to have a long hard think. He probably should have a Bex and a lie down as well.
—Would you just like to get some relevance to the issue?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, today we have put a position that a decision needs to be taken quickly. That is the relevance of this matter. Senator Alston is asserting and has asserted, as the Hansard will show, that he thinks people should take a long think about it. This is what some of his colleagues thought about why this particular philosophy in the Liberal Party should, on the one hand be done, and on the other hand not be done. I will read from two contributors, one of whom agrees with Senator Alston and one of whom does not. John Stone does not. John Stone said, `Some notably silly remarks by Dame Beryl Beaurepaire added to this general confusion, apart from the fact that it is a mistake to confuse women's issues' et cetera, and he goes on to talk about why some definition needs to be given to the Liberal Party and then says this—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins may wish to hang around and hear some facts about the results of the election on 13 March. That is what I intend to talk about in this matter of public interest. The result in the election revealed that the Labor Party had again scraped into office across Australia with a very narrow margin in a few seats. One wonders, on the law of averages, why the margins are always so small. I think it is a matter that needs to be looked into further. It is a matter that I certainly will be addressing in further contributions in the chamber in the months ahead.

PARA.TAB: I will confine my remarks to the election result in Queensland, where the Liberal Party performed very, very well in the 1993 election. The Labor Party came almost to complete catastrophe in Queensland on 13 March. I will indicate some of the facts. In Queensland the Liberal Party was the only major party to increase its primary vote at the election. The House of Representatives vote increased by 2.7 per cent, to 31.2 per cent, and the Liberal Party increased its number of lower house members by one, including the election of Mr Peter Slipper as the new Liberal member for Fisher. I congratulate Mr Slipper on a very fine win.

The Liberal Party increased its Senate vote in Queensland by 2.2 per cent, to 31.5 per cent, the largest increase recorded by any party in Queensland at this election. I might point out that the Labor Party in Queensland had its vote reduced by 1.1 per cent. It is interesting to note that in, I think, every other State the Labor Party vote went up—ever so slightly in most of them, I might say, but an increase. As a result of the election, the Liberal Party in Queensland easily maintained its quota of four senators.

I congratulate at this stage the Liberal Senate team led by my colleagues Senator David MacGibbon and Senator Warwick Parer. I also pay tribute to the other members of the Senate team, Mr Ross Cunningham, Mrs Ann Buchanan, Mr Henry Bird and the Reverend Owen Davies, for a fine contribution to the campaign in Queensland.

In contrast to the result for the Liberal Party, the Labor Party decreased its House of Representatives vote by 1.1 per cent, to 40.5 per cent, and decreased its number in the House of Representatives by two. The Democrat vote was down quite substantially in Queensland. The Democrats lost, in the House of Representatives election, some 7.5 per cent

SPEECH.PARA: of their support. Support for the Greens went up by only 2.6 per cent, so it did not all flow over there. I think one would find as well that in the Senate the Democrat vote fell quite substantially. Although the Democrats gained a seat there, they gained it on a very low quota margin. I think they started off at well less than one quota but by a drift of preferences throughout they were able to get another senator in.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to understand that the improvement by the Liberal Party in Queensland principally came about in rural and provincial areas. In the seat of Capricornia there was a 17 per cent swing to the Liberal Party. It is 17 per cent, I might add, because we did not run a candidate in the previous election. The Liberal candidate who ran for only a few weeks in that Central Queensland electorate achieved a very credible 17 per cent of the vote.

In the North Queensland electorate of Herbert, based on Townsville, the Liberal candidate, Peter Hazard, achieved a 6.3 per cent swing to the Liberal Party on top of the 8.7 per cent swing that he obtained in the previous election. In the Cairns based electorate, or Far North Queensland electorate of Leichhardt, the Liberal Party candidate, Bill Cummings, received a very substantial 9.5 per cent swing to the Liberal Party on top of a 13.1 per cent swing in 1990.

The overall swing to the Liberal Party in these three major North and Central Queensland provincial seats was 10.6 per cent. Madam Acting Deputy President, I have some graphs which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard. I have distributed them to the Minister at the table without telling him what they are, but that is what they are. I seek leave to have those incorporated.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The graphs actually show the results of the votes for the major parties in Leichhardt, Herbert and Capricornia since 1983 and make interesting reading. In the sugar seats of Queensland there was some confusion originally over our sugar policy, but that was overcome when the coalition put a lot of work into the sugar policy and came up with a policy that was substantially beneficial to the sugar industry and was one which the sugar industry accepted very readily. It was a policy that a lot of work was done on and a lot of contributions were made to it behind the scenes by Queensland coalition members. I specifically congratulate Mr Ian McLachlan on the work he did, and also Mr Bruce Lloyd on his contribution to the sugar policy.

PARA.TAB: There was a very strong vote for the coalition in the sugar seats. I make particular reference to the increase in the Liberal vote in the sugar seats of Hinkler and Leichhardt. In Hinkler, the swing to the Liberals was about four per cent and that swing ensured that the new member for Hinkler, Mr Paul Neville, was able to win that seat from Mr Courtice, the former chairman of the Prime Minister's country task force. But I might say, with respect, we are well rid of Mr Courtice, a man who did nothing but divide the bush with his divisive and anti-bush comments. I welcome Mr Paul Neville to this Parliament.

I will also make a passing reference to a rather unfortunate trend that appeared in the Herbert electorate in this election. There was a candidate who ran principally, I think one would say, on an anti-Aboriginal, anti-migrant and anti-welfare program. That independent candidate running for the very first time achieved 14 per cent of the primary vote in the electorate of Herbert. That is a trend which needs to be looked at. There are some very strong messages that the Government, and in fact, all people interested in politics should look at. There are many lessons to be learned from that and I will be addressing those lessons somewhere else. I might say that the swing to this independent, who ran on an anti-Aboriginal, anti-migrant, anti-welfare thing, was most strongly shown in the strong Labor booths of Townsville. That is a particularly interesting matter and a matter which, as I say, does require further investigation.

I make reference to the seat of Groom where I was very pleased to see Mr Bill Taylor again returned very substantially to that west of the divide seat on the Darling Downs. I was also very pleased to see my friend and colleague Mr Alex Somlyay returned in Fairfax with an increased primary vote. His vote is now well over 40 per cent. It is a remarkable effort by Mr Somlyay and my congratulations go to him.

I look forward to the next election when, on all the discernible trends, the Liberal Party will win the northern seats of Leichhardt and Herbert, in addition to many others which are really ours for the taking. The seats in Queensland held by the Labor Party are very marginal. Of the 19 seats around Australia with margins of 2.8 per cent or less, seven are in Queensland. Dickson, won by Mr Lavarch at the delayed election by just a handful of votes, is now on a 0.5 per cent margin. The electorate of Leichhardt needs a swing of only 1.4 per cent; Moreton, 1.8 per cent; Petrie, 2.2 per cent; Herbert, 2.4 per cent; Rankin, 2.7 per cent; and Capricornia, 2.8 per cent. I repeat that seven of the most marginal 19 Labor seats are in Queensland. It is fairly obvious that Queensland will play a major role in the defeat of the Labor Party at the next election.

Thanks to the people of Dickson, Labor does at least have one Queenslander in the Cabinet—only one—but he got there by a handful of votes when he won Dickson at the delayed election. I think it is a disgrace to Queensland that the Prime Minister is so bitter at the Queensland right-wing faction, which would not support him in the leadership battles, that he has punished Queensland by putting just one Queenslander in the Cabinet.I suppose that is better than what was done by Mr Hawke, who had none, but I think it is an absolute disgrace.

The only other Ministry representative from Queensland at the present time is the junior Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall), whose handling of the pay TV issue has been an absolute embarrassment. As a Queenslander, I almost wish that he were not even in the Ministry, because his handling of that is causing concern right around Australia to the industry and, more importantly, is an embarrassment to those of us who are from Queensland, who have to bear the brunt of jokes about this Minister and the way he has handled that matter.

By contrast, the coalition now has a number of Queensland people in senior positions. In the Liberal Party there are two Queenslanders in the shadow Cabinet, a further Liberal in the outer shadow Ministry and three shadow Parliamentary Secretaries. In addition to that, the National Party has two shadow Ministers, one in the shadow Cabinet. This is a recognition by the Liberal and National parties of Queensland's importance and an indication that Queensland will be crucial to winning the next election.

All the trends are that Queensland will be crucial in the next election. Mr Goss, the Queensland Premier, has had a rather remarkable run for the last few years as a new Premier, after many, many years of Liberal and National Party rule. His honeymoon is coming to a very quick end, as I believe Senator Burns would agree. The gloss, as they say, is wearing off. The opinion polls are starting to show that. As Mr Goss gets more and more public servants from Victoria, Labor Party people coming up to be given a sinecure, the Budget and the financial system in Queensland, which have been so good after decades of Liberal and National Party rule, will plummet in the same way as they have done in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia. Everywhere the Labor Party goes, it cannot be trusted with money, and Mr Goss is getting there. Mark my words, our fine financial position in Queensland is just about to tumble as the socialist upbringing of people like Mr Goss—I do not like referring to socialists these days, but it is true—

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't know a socialist if you saw one.

—I can see Senator Burns and I know that he is a socialist. He is very left in the socialist sphere. The socialists just spend money they do not have. The next federal election will be fought on the slimmest margin since 1975, when the coalition last won government. A mere 0.6 per cent swing is required to unseat the Keating Government. At the 1993 election it was a one per cent swing; it is now a 0.6 per cent swing. I wanted to raise those matters to make sure that there is no rewriting of history. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Burns is leaving the chamber, but I remember that his predecessor, former Senator Georges, was quite proud to be called a socialist, and he wore that badge with a great deal of pride.

PARA.TAB: I just want to make a couple of comments following the comments of the previous speaker, Senator Macdonald. It is true that the coalition did reasonably well in Queensland—though not quite well enough. The Liberal Party did lift its Senate vote, and it is to be congratulated on that. The National Party won the seat of Hinkler and it won the seat of Kennedy, and it turned the seat of Dawson—which was marginally held by 80 or 90 votes—into a fairly good score for the member, Mr Ray Braithwaite, who made a sacrifice on behalf of his electorate and resigned from shadow Cabinet on the sugar position, to which, of course, his electorate responded by giving him an overwhelming vote of confidence.

That is not the main issue that I rose to speak on. I would like to raise some concerns about the appointment of Professor Ross Garnaut to head the Government's Wool Industry Review Committee. The long-term future of the wool industry and tens of thousands of growers and their families and rural townspeople will depend very much on the committee's findings. It requires an intimate and practical knowledge of the industry from the ground up, and an appreciation of the importance of restoring confidence and some stability to the industry and its markets.
Professor Garnaut has held several advisory positions which have made his views on a range of subjects very publicly known. In supporting Australian police advisers in Papua New Guinea he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It will involve Australians getting involved in messy situations from time to time. If Australians are going to be advisors in the police force, some Australians will be present when innocent PNG civilians are shot. This is one of the costs.
In the Sydney Morning Herald on 9 April, he described the situation in South Africa in the following manner:
There is a lot of intellectual capital in this country and it's engaged in an interesting way.

In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald he talked about the `mediocre minds'—referring to the then Minister, Peter Baldwin—who wanted to change the ANU, where Mr Garnaut is a professor, and about the multifunction polis, the steering committee of which Mr Garnaut was a member.

PARA.TAB: Garnaut has also publicised his views on the needs for changes to federalism, fighting the Senate's `permanent Opposition majority' and the Commonwealth diffusion of power as economic constraints.

From an article in the Australian of 2 August 1990 it is clear that Professor Garnaut would very much like to rule Australia from his personal computer, where he could manipulate people and resources just so, without any interference from the parliamentary democracy or `those nasty little States'.

However, he is most famous for being the author of Australia and the North East Asian Ascendancy. Like Moses bringing down the 10 commandments carved in tablets of stone, Garnaut's report outlines the tenets of economic rationalism which were taken up zealously by economists, commentators and some politicians. These commandments were embraced widely as everyone sought to find a model for Australia's future direction on the international stage. The most fundamental commandment and, in Garnaut's own words, the single most important step was, `Thou shalt have no tariffs'. Micro-economic reform on the waterfront and other labour markets and in areas of transport and communications was also important. But Garnaut said that it was not necessary to bring down the tariffs in tandem with micro-economic reform; and that is where John Hewson differed. So long as the tariffs went, Australia would be forced to become internationally competitive; that is, whatever was left of Australia's industry. Other economic rationalist commandments included, `Thou shalt have no export incentive or subsidy schemes'.

Strangely, though, Garnaut softens this when a personal interest takes hold. He encouraged the Government to provide export insurance for those businesses exporting to Papua New Guinea, the site of his early career. He said, `Thou shalt deregulate everything. Thou shalt not allow any form of statutory marketing structures to enable farmers to control the marketing of their own produce in the face of oligopolistic collusion from large buyers'. On the imperfections of the deregulated financial system, Garnaut writes:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian banks were not strong enough professionally to make the transition smoothly to a deregulated system.
This was in an article in the Australian on 6 March. As chairman of the R&I Bank of Western Australia, which made huge losses as a result of unwise lendings and investments, he should know.

PARA.TAB: He said, `Thou shalt pause not for the fate of those driven to bankruptcy and unemployment'. In an interview on Prue Goward's morning radio show on 15 May 1990, Garnaut admitted that there might have been some casualties in the car industry had protection come down faster. When asked for an example, Garnaut replied, `I don't want to speculate about the details. It's impossible to know without the pressures having actually been applied'. Will Garnaut also not want to speculate about the details of woolgrowers forced to leave the land because of some economic rationalist approach? These details are vitally important because they apply to thousands of people with a life's investment and know-how. Will Garnaut be unable to speculate about the effects of his wool recommendations? As in the car industry, it is impossible to know before it happens. This is simply unacceptable.

During an address in Western Australia in 1990, Professor Garnaut made another breathtaking statement to the economic rationalist disciples: there shall be no anti-dumping arrangements. Honourable senators on both sides of this chamber have worked extremely hard to set up effective anti-dumping arrangements. The Senate formed a committee to examine this important area, and there were subsequent legislative improvements. Both sides of politics are committed to preventing the flood of subsidised imports from wiping out Australia's horticultural and other rural industries, which are also among the world's most efficient producers.

Time and again, the Senate has been told of the enormous subsidies being paid in foreign countries that enable their producers to sell at lower prices. Those products, even if not bought into Australia, affect the domestic price. I believe that the Minister for Trade (Senator Cook) will have something to say about that today. To remove anti-dumping arrangements and have zero tariffs and allow micro-economic reform to catch up at will is a recipe for untold disaster in all aspects of Australian industry. Economic theories may be brilliant, men's minds may be brilliant, but such brilliance shatters when faced with the practical.

Do Garnaut's commandments for economic rationalism make any room for humanity, for moderation or for non-economic issues? Australia is not an economic model. Australia is living tissue, blood and spirit. We must not open the Pandora's box of these economic extremists too far. The Government has baulked at some aspects of economic rationalism. For example, the car, clothing, textile and footwear industries will not face zero tariffs by the year 2000. Yesterday in the Senate, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) repeated his Government's commitment to an effective anti-dumping scheme.

The appointment of Ross Garnaut as the head of the Wool Industry Review Committee is sending out all sorts of worrying messages to the woolgrowers, buyers and processors. What sorts of solutions will such a public advocate of economic rationalism and its theoretical extremism promote for the beleaguered wool industry? Will he come up with a dangerous and industry-threatening idea like his proposal to remove anti-dumping arrangements? Will the wool stockpile be thrown into a fully deregulated and privatised market? Will there be no more promotion funds? Will there be no generic advertising for wool? Will 50 per cent of producers be sentenced to the city dole queues while the market reasserts itself? Will properties lie vacant and deteriorating under sentence of economic rationalism? Will rural towns shrivel and die, their businesses bankrupt, their people unemployed, simply because there was a drought, a short-term wool price problem and an economic rationalist?

Professor Garnaut will say that we need to develop new wool related, perhaps processed, export industries. But how will that happen within his economic rationalism war where there are no tariffs, no anti-dumping, no government assistance or export subsidies, in a climate where micro-economic reform is proceeding far too slowly to make us competitive with established processors? Professor Garnaut stated in an article in the Australian on 30 November 1990 that he is against any broad scheme of industry assistance. Will there be a wool industry in 10 years time?

Senator Evans said the other day that he was sure Professor Garnaut would take the parameters of government policy into account when making his recommendations. But the professor has the floor on this one. There is no government policy on the future of the industry. That is Professor Garnaut's brief. Can a leopard change its spots? Can a man who is famous from promoting a strict economic rationalist approach do less than that? There has been no sign of his deviating from his cherished commandments, no admission that he was in error over advocating the removal of anti-dumping arrangements. I fear greatly for the future of the wool industry while its review committee is headed by a person of Professor Garnaut's distinction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address a very unfortunate matter brought to my attention by a constituent family in Tasmania. This case has overtones of elitism and racism with which no true Australian would wish to be associated. It concerns the failure of the Australian Embassy in Suva, Fiji, to grant a visitor's visa to allow a friend from Fiji to come to this country for a holiday. This is the background to this matter.

PARA.TAB: A constituent, Mr Glenn MacLaren, a biochemist of some 20 years standing, was provided with accommodation while on a two-month holiday in Fiji by Mr and Mrs John Narsaiya and their family. As a reciprocal gesture and in response to this kindness and hospitality Mr MacLaren and his parents offered to have Prascilla Narsaiya, a daughter of the family, to stay if she wanted to visit Australia for some period of time. Not surprisingly, Ms Narsaiya took up the MacLaren's offer on this matter. An application for a visitors visa was lodged by Ms Narsaiya, who was looking forward to spending Christmas in Australia on 22 December 1992. She was interviewed on 24 December 1992 by an embassy official. The embassy was not, however, satisfied that Ms Narsaiya would abide by the conditions relating to the visitor's visa and so refused to grant a visitor's visa to her. Reasons for this refusal were given to Ms Narsaiya, as they should be, and it is with these reasons that I take particular issue.

The first reason given by the embassy was that Ms Narsaiya's financial and employment position was not sufficient for a person undertaking international travel, because her personal financial position and assets were limited. While I consider such discrimination on the basis of wealth distasteful, I acknowledge that there may be a need for such a standard in some circumstances. One might observe, however, the number of backpackers and younger tourists that Australia rightly welcomes for extended stays in this country. It would be a rare young person amongst this group of tourists, most of whom are either at university or have just finished their studies, who would command assets or income of any substance. Yet we do not deny visitors' visas to them on this basis. It clearly would be wrong if we did.

Immediately, the question arises: why is this criterion sufficient to bar Ms Narsaiya from visiting Australia, but not to bar others in analogous situations? However, even if it is accepted that this criterion is generally applicable in a case such as Ms Narsaiya's, it would fail on the particular facts of this matter. The MacLaren family, the sponsors of Ms Narsaiya's visit, were prepared to provide the full cost of the trip and guarantee Ms Narsaiya's flight home. In other words, the MacLaren family expressly stated that they were prepared to take responsibility for her expenses. The MacLarens even went to the extent of offering to give these undertakings in writing, if necessary, and did so.

A lack of financial resources should only be a relevant matter for consideration in the granting of a visitor's visa if it is reasonably conceivable that this relative impecuniosity could create a problem. So far as Ms Narsaiya was concerned, there could be no fear of such a problem arising, because of the guarantee offered by the MacLarens. The inescapable conclusion is that the criterion of financial and employment status of the applicant was incorrectly applied here.

I come to the second reason. Despite the prima facie appearance of an incorrect application of a general guideline in the first reason for refusal, my most serious misgivings about this decision arise from the second reason given. One could say that this second reason was an omnibus reason, in that several grounds for refusal appeared to be consolidated within the one reason.

In the second reason, the embassy stated that the applicant had little incentive to return to Fiji, that it was highly unusual for a woman in Ms Narsaiya's position to stay at the home of a bachelor like Mr MacLaren and that the nature of the relationship between Ms Narsaiya and Mr MacLaren had not been fully articulated, to use the words of the embassy official. The speculation and supposition in these statements, which virtually amount to allegations, is manifest. But each one of these statements is so injurious and hurtful to all the parties involved that each statement deserves a response and an answer.

To say that Ms Narsaiya had no reason to return to Fiji is to imagine her life there as irredeemably hopeless and Australia as a promised land. Now, I do not doubt that Australia would appear that way with some justification to many people around the world. The point is that neither of these suppositions is true in the case of Ms Narsaiya.

Firstly, Ms Narsaiya has a close and loving family in Fiji, with whom she lives and which she would no doubt find it very difficult to leave. Secondly, she has a stable job in Fiji as a supervisor in a clothing factory. Indeed, Ms Narsaiya is valued highly enough by her employer for him to promise to grant her leave of absence from her job should she go to Australia. I am informed that assurances to this end were put in writing by her employer and given to the embassy.

One cannot find stronger attachments to a place than those of family and work. Both of these attachments are very strong for Ms Narsaiya. If it is true that there would be no reason for her to return to Fiji if she visited Australia, then there is no reason for any of us to stay where we choose to be. The demonstrable falsity of this demonstrates the unsustainability of this finding by the embassy. Secondly, the pejorative insinuations in the remarks about the normality of the planned visit and the relationship between Ms Narsaiya and Mr MacLaren are, frankly, insulting and improper.

To claim, as the embassy unfortunately did, that Ms Narsaiya would be living in the home of an unmarried man is only half correct. The embassy failed in its reasoning to admit that the applicant would also be living with his parents. To impute automatically something more than a mere friendship if a woman chooses to stay under the same roof as a man is simply ridiculous in this day and age. Are we to believe that the embassy official responsible for this decision truly believes that the fact of members of the opposite sex sleeping under the same roof creates a non-rebuttable presumption of a sexual relationship? Is a course of mid-Victorian English novels compulsory for Australian Embassy officials so that they develop such a peculiarly sensitive source of morality?

More importantly, to state that the relationship was not fully articulated is incorrect. The relationship is quite clear in the particular circumstances—it was and is nothing more than a friendship. Friendships between members of the opposite sex are hardly so rare as to lead automatically to the conclusion that something suspicious is afoot.

The entire second reason given by the embassy cannot be characterised as anything except specious, with an appearance of plausibility but in essence false. Both the MacLaren family and Ms Narsaiya value, above all else, their honesty. If there were something more to this relationship than friendship, it would be admitted. What the MacLarens find most aggrieving about this affair is the not so subtle inference that they are engaging in a shabby subterfuge. Their honesty has been impugned and they are justifiably angry about that.

As to the genuine nature of the visit; the embassy also stated there was doubt over the genuine nature of Ms Narsaiya's visit to Australia. It is unfortunate that the embassy considered the mere assertion of this doubt sufficient and failed to give any substance to that doubt. Indeed, the unsatisfactory nature of this conclusion by the embassy is implicit in its brevity. It is my belief that the purpose of the visit was totally genuine. I will go so far as to say that if this visit were not genuine, then none are. I went so far as to give a character reference about the MacLaren family to officials in Fiji.

I will now go to the matter of whether the six grounds for the grant of a visa were satisfied. In the letter refusing the grant of visa to Ms Narsaiya on 24 December 1992, the senior migration officer of the Australian Embassy in Fiji stated that there were six prescribed requirements for such a grant, in addition to the general finding that the visit was genuine. These six grounds are health, character, settlement, controversiality, debts to the Commonwealth or past exclusions from readmission to Australia. It is plain that these six grounds were, in truth, met in every case. I note that controversy is a ground for exclusion. It seems to me that the only controversial aspect of this case is the refusal to grant a visa for no good reason by the embassy.

The MacLarens have told me that they take the embassy's refusal as a personal affront to their integrity. Certainly, it is easy to see it in this way. Not unreasonably, the MacLarens would like the Australian Embassy to justify its reasons for doubting their good faith. I cannot imagine, and nor can they, what else they could do or offer to do to prove the genuine nature of the application. Another salient point must be the fact that the embassy chose to ignore the support offered to the application by three Federal parliamentarians—the former member for Bass, Mr Warwick Smith, the Hon. Senator Michael Tate and me—and the attestations as to MacLarens' bona fides by these three Federal parliamentarians.

If the criteria for the grant of a visitor's visa were applied in every case in the same way that they were applied in Ms Narsaiya's case, no-one would ever get into this country. For this reason, the motivations behind the denial of the visitor's visa must be accepted as questionable. This decision is redolent of racism and has the appearance of a Minister for immigration being unable or unwilling to control or scrutinise the action of his officers. It is indisputable that there is much more to this decision than is simply apparent—this is clear from the facts.

As thrifty, hardworking, honest and earnest Australians, the MacLarens are entitled to know what the true explanation is of this decision. Ms Narsaiya is also entitled to an explanation. There have been ample opportunities for the department to do so. Government and its officers must be accountable, if nothing else. An explanation of the refusal to grant a visitor's visa is demanded. I believe it must be received and it must be delivered. I ask for the support of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) in this particular matter, as a fellow Tasmanian.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to remarks made by the Minister reported in last weekend's Sunday Territorian in relation to the changed tendering process—
—You are scratching the bottom of the barrel now.

—I am on the Minister's mailing list. He knows a mistake when he sees it and he wants us to help him out of it. In relation to the changed tendering process for the satellite pay TV licences, the Minister is quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I accept responsibility for the fact that the submission which should have been checked by my communications adviser was not because he was on leave.

Can the Minister explain that statement in the light of his refusal yesterday to even confirm to the Senate whether or not a submission existed? Was there a departmental brief and will the Minister now table that brief?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure even what the relevance of this question is. I am happy to leave it in the hands of an inquiry until this Senate gets it and we can do what we like with it then. I have, in fact, got two communications advisers, not one. But the key issue here is that today it is the Opposition's credibility that is on the line, not the Government's. Have a look at what those opposite said this morning—

—I was a lot of years in opposition, Mr President, unlike 90 per cent of my colleagues. I was leader for five years. Have a look at the record. I took enough scalps. I threw enough garbage at the government in my day, in my time. I moved enough censure motions and I got down pretty low to do it sometimes, I admit. I had very few scruples when I did it if I was attacking a government Minister. I used to get right down there to get my scalps. In fact, if the government had thought about it at the time, it probably would have called me `dancing with grubs'. But I used to do that. Back in those days, I probably would have even talked to people like Tom Burton—
—No, you wouldn't.

—Probably not. The fact is that there has been a discovery of an error in this process—the lack of a deposit. The Government has legislation in here. I am not complaining about being on the block. We should be on the block and I should be on the block. But today, those opposite are on the block because, Mr President, we have got legislation proceeding through this Parliament now which will fix it. Senator Alston has confirmed it will.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. There is an issue of relevance here and I would ask you to rule on it. The question was very specific; it asked whether a submission existed and, if it did, whether the Minister would table it. That was the question. I would ask you to bring the Minister back to order or sit him down.
—I think the Minister was being relevant. Earlier he had strayed.
