—The answer to that question is—and I was going to deliver it in a minute—that all of this paper is going to be in the hands of the Senate within a week. And Senator Alston knows it. Nothing is being kept back from this Senate. We will get it in here. The key thing is that we know what the problem is; we are going to fix it. What I said in the chamber this morning was that the only reason that was given by the Opposition for not supporting this legislation—and it is unbelievable—is that there was some imputation, not fact, contained in the legislation that the two companies that have currently got their bids will not be able to do them.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have already directed the Minister to stop straying and get back to the question. The question was in two parts, as Senator Kemp rightly said: does a submission exist and will the Minister table it? I invite you to direct him to answer those specific questions.
—I ask the Minister to be relevant.

—I will conclude the answer on this point, Mr President. As I have said before, all the papers that are relevant to this issue—I have told the Senate and the Senate estimates committee this—will be given to the Senate along with the report.
—This is the Parliament.

—Let us talk about that. The assertion that this inquiry is in some way avoiding scrutiny of Parliament is a nonsense. The first place it is going to arrive is back here. I am concerned about natural justice for the public servants that Senator Alston also purports to be concerned about. Senator Alston's interpretation of natural justice is `that the tribunal should be free of bias'. Is anyone seriously going to suggest that a Senate committee is a tribunal free of bias? They would be laughed out of the room if they did.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. No-one is talking about a Senate committee. The Minister is being asked to stop treating this chamber with contempt and answer whether a submission exists and, if so, whether he will table it. It is not to the point at all to say that at some later stage he might or might not give some documents which may or may not exist to some extra-parliamentary tribunal.
—Where is the question?
—The question is: is there a submission and will the Minister table it? At the same time will he table that other legal opinion he asked for.

—I am responsible to this Senate and I will remain responsible to this Senate. We are at the beginning of a three-year term. I am not going to go away; death will be the only thing that will prevent me from coming back for the next term. I am always responsible to the Senate. The Senate will have all the papers; it will have the report. The Senate will then determine what to do with it. In terms of the last part of Senator Alston's question requesting me to table the paper that I mentioned in debate this morning, I now do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and refers to sugar exports to the United States. Is the Minister aware of an announcement on 11 May by the US Government that it is further reducing access for sugar imports? If so, can he explain what this announcement means to Australia and also outline what action the Government is taking in response to this announcement? Further, can the Minister also say what is the present value of Australia's exports to the United States?

—The first part of the question was about the value of Australian sugar exports to the United States. Over the last 10 to 12 years there has been a significant reduction in the amount of sugar we have exported to the United States because of market closing procedures in the US. The Australian sugar exports to the United States in Australian dollar value terms were estimated at around $55 million last year. Overall, we have less than two per cent of the US sugar market. We are the fourth largest supplier to the US.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the second part of the question, on 11 May at 7.20 p.m. Washington time, the US Department of Agriculture released a press statement headed `The US Department of Agriculture extends tariff rate quota for sugar'. In that it said that the US tariff rate quota for 1992-93 would apply in 1993-94, it would increase the quota level and that the US trade representative would shortly announce country by country quotas. That sounds like good news but in reality it means that, by averaging the tariff rate quota over two years, for the year 1993-94 there will be a reduction in the quota.

While the global reduction is specified, the US trade representative will shortly announce what the country by country effect will be. If the normal calculations are applied in Australia's case, we would expect that to be a reduction of 10,000 metric tonnes for the year 1993-94. I emphasise that the usual way of calculating our share of the global quota would see a reduction of 10,000 metric tonnes, coming down from 96,786 metric tonnes to, by the usual calculation, 86,070 metric tonnes.

This circumstance would be a significant blow to the Australian sugar industry. It would also be a further closing of access to the US market. In the current world trade situation, that is not something to be wished or supported.

Upon receipt of this news, I notified the canegrowers association, CSR and the Queensland Government. I have advised the coalition spokesman on trade of the circumstance. Immediately after Question Time I expect to see the Democrat spokesman on trade and give him a full briefing on the matter.

The question also asks me what else I have done. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and I are today sending a letter to the US Secretary of Agriculture, Mr Espy, and a copy to US trade representative Kantor. We will give a sense of the contents of that letter in a joint press release we will put out today.

We are expressing strong government concern about this turn of events in the United States. I am foreshadowing that we will take it up in Washington on 26 and 27 May in the official talks of the US-Australia agricultural consultations. I will take it up personally in Washington on 11 June when I attend the formal trade and investment arrangement council meeting on behalf of Australia.

Australia has a substantial trade deficit with the United States. As a parallel, it can be likened to the sort of trade deficit that the United States has with Japan. We are not seeking a balancing of trade; we are seeking reasonable access to the US market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the Government's recent decision to allow Mr Black to acquire a further stake in the Fairfax newspaper group and ask him to explain to the Senate why further foreign ownership of Australia's media is in the national interest.

—The Government's well established policy, as Senator Hill ought to know, is generally to welcome foreign investment in this country. In the case of mass circulation newspapers, we do impose some limits on foreign investment because of national interest pertaining to social and cultural values. Accordingly, it is the case that all proposals by foreign investors to acquire an interest in an Australian mass circulation newspaper will continue to be subject to case by case examination.

PARA.TAB: The Government's decision to increase non-portfolio foreign ownership of mass circulation newspapers to 30 per cent, providing that no one shareholder has more than 25 per cent and that the other five per cent is held by unrelated foreign interests, reflects simply the valid need of foreign investors to safeguard their financial and managerial commitment to their newspapers while at the same time ensuring that Australian interests are protected. That is the context in which the decision was made, and that is the way in which it was articulated by the Prime Minister at the time. I have nothing further to add.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that Mr Black has said that he has no objections to the Foreign Investment Review Board's advice—which the Government relied upon, at least in part, in this instance—being released, will the Minister now table the advice of that body in order that members of the public might see for themselves the full basis of the Government's decision?
—I will refer that matter to the Treasurer. He can make up his own mind.

—Can the Minister for Transport and Communications inform the Senate of the progress being made by the National Rail Corporation in commencing its operations around Australia? Can the Minister also inform the Senate of progress in the transfer of operations at the Islington terminal in Adelaide to National Rail?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate of another area of transport in this country that is moving ahead. National Rail has begun to take over the marketing, wagon deployment and terminal operations from the existing State rail systems. National Rail in April took over terminal operations at Acacia Ridge in Brisbane, Chullora in Sydney and, on 3 May, the Dynon terminal in Melbourne. National Rail has advised that the work team and multiskilling work practices embodied in its enterprise award have provided immediate productivity improvements of 20 per cent already at Acacia Ridge and Chullora. A 30 per cent increase in productivity is expected to be achieved at Dynon.

PARA.TAB: I am also pleased to advise honourable senators that earlier this week National Rail and Australian National signed all of the necessary commercial agreements to allow the transfer of operations of the Islington freight terminal in Adelaide to the National Rail system. National Rail, Australian National and the rail unions have agreed to jointly explain to all existing Australian National employees details of the agreed arrangements. This will allow National Rail to finalise recruitment of the 50 permanent and 37 temporary staff under National Rail's enterprise agreement.

National Rail expects to finalise the recruitment of the 87 Adelaide terminal staff next week, followed by completion of induction training and the formal terminal operations transferred to National Rail on 31 May. With the completion of the transfer of operations at the Adelaide terminal, the momentum of the establishment of the National Rail system, without disrupting customer services, will be maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask the Minister to table the ministerial statement from which he just read or alternatively provide to Hansard a floppy disk to save it work.
—Whether the Minister tables that or not is a matter for the Minister.
—As I have explained to Opposition senators before, they can do that themselves by pushing the right button on the computer in their office.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to today's unemployment figures, which nobody in the Opposition has mentioned yet, which show the number of long-term unemployed in Australia has actually increased by 0.5 per cent. Why is the Government giving those Australians like us lucky enough to be in work an $8 billion tax cut, which the country cannot afford, while leaving thousands of Australians on the long-term unemployed permanent scrap heap? If the Government can afford, as it keeps asserting, this $8 billion, how many long-term unemployed could be assisted back into the work force if that $8 billion were targeted to programs for those people?

—Rudimentary economics should help Senator Kernot to understand that if we increase taxes by $8 billion, that will be $8 billion less expenditure and a lot of people will lose jobs as well as those jobs that would be created by the expenditure. Senator Kernot is not proposing that we increase the amount of expenditure; she is proposing that we transfer it from the private to the public sector, which does not necessarily create any jobs at all.

—Is the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services aware that halon has significant harmful effects on the ozone layer? Can the Minister inform the Senate what contribution his department is making to Australia's commitment to withdraw halon from general use by the end of 1995 in accordance with the terms of the Montreal Protocol to which Australia is a signatory?

—This issue, which Senator Childs has raised, is very important. Halon gas has been widely used in Australia in fire suppression systems. Although it has been very effective in that regard, more recent concerns about the ozone layer have drawn to people's attention the serious concern that halons are extremely aggressive in ozone depletion. My scientific knowledge about halon gas is not the world's most profound but my understanding is that it is the same process which makes it effective in fire suppression that also makes it dangerous to the ozone in terms of its impact on oxygen. However, I am reliably advised that in normal usage halon is not harmful to people.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Childs has said, Australia is a signatory to the Montreal Protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer. To meet our obligations under that protocol, and to act as a responsible international citizen, we have decided to withdraw halon from use by the end of 1995. It is estimated that there are about 5,000 tonnes of halon in current use in Australia—70 per cent is held by the Commonwealth and State governments, 15 per cent by major corporations and 15 per cent by small business and the community. The Prime Minister announced previously that we would be setting up a halon bank on a commercial basis through the DAS centre for environmental management. The funding for that, as Senator Parer would know, is in the supplementary estimates which we discussed the other night.

Major users—that is, the Commonwealth and State governments, and the major corporations—will be expected to meet the costs of collection, storage and destruction. Money is to be set aside—$4.6 million over the next four years—to subsidise small business and community organisations and individuals who have small holdings of halon and would otherwise not be likely to come forward and make it available for destruction. It seems appropriate that we should not make those people bear the cost of what is a decision in the national interest rather than in the interest of any particular individual. So there will be a $4.6 million subsidy for that. Activity on the halon bank is proceeding now and it will get under way apace with the passage of the supplementary estimates and the money becoming available to fund the small holders.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. In 1976 the Liberal-National Government banned sandmining on Fraser Island. Is the Government proposing to allow a re-opening of Fraser Island for mining?

—I have no information available to me at the moment that there is any proposal to re-open sandmining on Fraser Island. I have never heard of any such proposal. But just to make it clear for Senator Macdonald, who performed so very well for us at the last Federal election, trying to explain how the GST would apply to local government services—
—Thanks for your help, Ian.

—It was a great help, Senator Macdonald. After changing his mind three times in the one day, what he had to say got so convoluted that I thought he had his tongue stuck up his own nostril when trying to explain how the GST policy would apply to local government. So, just to make it absolutely clear for Senator Macdonald, I will check with the Minister for the environment, Mrs Kelly, and come back to him with an answer as soon as possible. But I can assure him that I have heard of no intention to allow sandmining on Fraser Island.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I am somewhat concerned that Senator Schacht cannot give an unequivocal answer to me on this matter. It is one of the most important environmental issues around. If the Government genuinely opposes a reopening of sandmining on Fraser Island, and given its record of intervening in Queensland on environmental issues, why did the Government not take any action to ensure that a prohibition on mining was written into the management plan for the World Heritage listed Fraser Island?

—I cannot work out whether or not Senator Macdonald is in favour of sandmining, but it seems to me that he is in favour of sandmining on Fraser Island. He has asked a particular question about the protocol. To give Senator Macdonald every opportunity not to be confused, as he was confused over the GST for local government in the last election, I will also refer that point to the Minister and get a report for him as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Given the importance of value adding in processing and manufacturing to Australia's export drive, can the Minister report about recent growth in manufacturing exports and developments in the food processing sector? Also, can the Minister report on the contribution of government policies to the manufacturing revolution which has been taking place in Australia?
—Mr President—
—Have you got a written answer for this one?

—I have some information. It may disappoint Senator Macdonald to hear a good news story because all those opposite want is bad news and bad news. But despite any bad news, they keep losing elections. With the help of Senator Macdonald's contribution in the last election campaign those opposite are still sitting in the same place; so we hope he keeps sitting where he is for a long time to come.

PARA.TAB: I point out to the Senate that 25 per cent of Australia's manufacturing sales are now exports; Australian manufacturing exports have risen by 15 per cent over the past five years. One of the areas identified as a specific area of potential for Australia is the food processing industry. I am sure our friends opposite, particularly those in the National Party, would be very interested in and very supportive of the efforts of the Agrifood Council to promote food exports because it will mean better incomes for Australian farmers. I see National Party senators nodding in agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't assume that means agreement.

—I give them the benefit of the doubt; they do know how to nod affirmatively compared with nodding negatively, and I know they may have a difference of opinion with people such as Senator Macdonald. There is great opportunity for agrifood exports, particularly into our region, and the recently formed Agrifood Council will be a basis for emphasising our potential in that area.

PARA.TAB: I also point out that the recent McKinsey report, commissioned by the Australian Manufacturing Council, showed that there are 700 firms of small to medium size that are experiencing export growth of around 14 per cent compound per annum. The report also identified that there may be a further 6,000 manufacturing firms in Australia that could join that 700. If we could get a large percentage of the 6,000 to become exporters, our export growth from those manufacturing firms, which currently provide $8 billion of exports, could not only double over the next five years but probably treble or more than treble.

I have already had discussions with the portfolio Minister, Mr Griffiths, and with the department of industry to look at ways in which we can facilitate the flow of information to those 6,000 firms to encourage them to become exporters, and to join the 700.

All in all, we are getting some good runs on the board for our manufacturing exports and it is good for the Australian economy. Over the next three years Mr Griffiths and I look forward to doing everything we can to encourage the manufacturing sector to become an even bigger part of our export success story.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to child care, can the Minister for Family Services advise the Senate how many children currently benefit from the fringe benefits tax exemption for employers sponsoring child care? How many are expected to benefit from the extension of that benefit, and what will be the cost to the taxpayer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government in its child care policies, as shown by its promises during the last election, is very concerned to see that all people who want child care have access to it. To do that it has been looking at ways of extending the number of child care places that can be provided in the community. In particular, it has been pleased over the past few years to welcome the private child care sector into providing places and fee relief through that sector which enormously assists the number of people who are looking for child care.

PARA.TAB: Further to that, the Government is very concerned to see whether it cannot increase the employers' responsibility to contribute to child care places on behalf of parents in the work force in particular. To do that, it has decided as of 1 July this year to extend the fringe benefits tax exemptions from just child

ANSWER.PARA: care places built on an employer's site to include places procured by an employer in the community, and also to family day care. As to the exact amount of those figures, I would be happy to get those figures and provide them for Senator Newman.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications whether he agrees with the following statement:

QUESTION.PARA: The ABC offers information, access to the arts and sport as a public good, a community good. It offers an alternative view: it doesn't have to sell products to survive.

Is the Minister aware that this statement was made by the ALP President, the Hon. Barry Jones, in an advertisement for the ALP during the recent federal election campaign? Will the Government stand by Mr Jones's commitment as stated in the same advertisement that `Labor will protect the ABC'? Will the Minister give an undertaking that in the upcoming Budget we will see no cutbacks to the ABC like those which saw funding to the ABC under this Government reduced by about $120 million over the previous five years?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to confess that I did not actually catch up with the statement made by Mr Jones, just alluded to.
—No brief on that?

—You stick to your brief, Shirley, and I will stick to mine. The Government has a demonstrated strong commitment to the national broadcaster. It is a fact—and the Australian electorate voted on it, in a big way, I think—that, had the coalition won the last election, the ABC would have been decimated. The Government has put in place triennial funding arrangements for the ABC, and those funding arrangements will continue. This Government will demonstrate the same continued support for our national broadcaster. In terms of the delivery systems of news and current affairs around the world, the ABC services are almost unique, and this Government will preserve them and maintain them in the same successful way as it has done in the past.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask the Minister: does he recall having advised the chamber on many occasions of the virtues and improvements of the sea transport industry, both at sea and on shore? As I recall, even yesterday the Minister quoted productivity gains, staff number reductions and so on. So I ask: how is it that users have recently been advised of the second five to 10 per cent freight increase in Bass Strait shipping over the past six months?

—There is no question at all that the statement I made to the Senate was correct. The Government has no direct role in setting freight charges; they are normal commercial matters. But there is no question that substantial structural changes have occurred with shippers benefiting from improved stevedoring efficiency and reliability. Productivity has improved by 127 per cent in terms of containers that are being handled per employee shift. Average ship turnaround time has been reduced by 45 per cent. Average container rates have increased to 20 containers per hour, representing a 57 per cent increase in performance over the 12.8 containers per hour in 1989. I think Senator Cook would agree that it is about time those opposite acknowledged it.
—Absolutely.

—I thought he would agree; it would be terrible if he had not agreed. Crane rates of 22 containers an hour are regularly now being achieved on individual ships, rising to 32 containers an hour under optimal ship and stowage conditions. The work force has been cut by 57 per cent with 5,000 employees exiting the industry from the original 8,900. Cargo throughput is close to peak levels of 1989-90 when major ports experienced serious congestion and delays in cargo handling with more than double the current work force. Stevedoring contract rates have fallen by 20 to 30 per cent, and that has been generated by the intense competition as a result of the reform. Further cuts are expected when one-off reform redundancy costs have been fully met.

PARA.TAB: The Prices Surveillance Authority's first monitoring report on stevedoring costs and charges in November 1992 concluded that stevedoring charges had fallen by 59 per cent in real terms from 1985 to 1992. Many exporters are now acknowledging savings. For example, the Australian Wheat Board reports savings of up to $35 million per year following the implementation of the reform program. For example, the Australian Council of Wool Exporters, in recent major shipping contracts, negotiated freight reductions including an element for waterfront reform.

If shippers have not noticed any change, it means either that they are not looking or that their problems are somewhere else in the transport chain, and they may well be. As I said in the Senate the other day, one of the reasons that all of the transport sectors have been incorporated now in one ministry is that the principal aim of the ministry of transport over the next three years of the Government's agenda will be to work on national transport systems. The reform program has reduced the cost structure of stevedoring and, as some shippers have acknowledged, it is now up to exporters and importers to pursue through the normal commercial processes a fair share of those reform benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That is exactly what the Minster has been telling us for months. What I am asking the Minister is: how is it that the price has gone up twice in the last six months for the people who are using the freight? How can that happen when all this glory is unfolding before us?

—Mr President, we are never going to convince these people ever; I am aware of that. At some later stage—not this afternoon—I would like the Opposition to demonstrate that the information that I have just given the Senate again is not correct.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and refers to today's disastrous job figures, which show that 75,000 jobs have been lost since last month. I ask the Minister whether he has seen, in the March 1993 issue of the Economic Record, an article by Professor Bob Gregory, entitled `Aspects of Australian and US living standards: The disappointing decades 1970-1990', in which Professor Gregory states:

QUESTION.PARA: The Australian job loss has been concentrated on males. . . after allowing for population growth, one in three male middle earning jobs disappeared between 1976 and 1990.
I interpolate that 200,000 male jobs have disappeared since that time. Professor Gregory also observes:
Real earnings have fallen considerably since 1985 and real wage dispersion increased.

I ask the Minister: will the Government examine the role that greater tax equity for families could play in restoring consumer demand and work incentives and improving the distribution per capita of after tax household incomes?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to note that I have had two questions today about the important unemployment figures but none from the Opposition. It is very important that we look at the question of the nature of the job loss and the nature also of the job increase, as jobs are much too slowly increasing. The trend in full-time employment continues to rise—it has been rising since October 1992—and that growth is occurring both for males and for females. I am not presenting that as some wonderful light, saying that all our problems are solved; I am saying that the growth in full-time employment is for both males and females.
—How about the long-term unemployed?

—I am talking about employment, thank you. That is in some part redressing the issue of significant concern the honourable senator raises. The changing pattern of employment within the work force is also to do with the changing nature of the industries in which growth is occurring, as against the nature of the industries in which it is contracting. It is clear that the growth is in areas like services and tourism, where there is more likely to be a higher percentage of female employment than in some of the older, more traditional employment areas where employment is either contracting or growing less quickly. There is a whole range of underlying factors beneath the issues which Senator Harradine raised. I have not read the particular article by Professor Gregory to which Senator Harradine refers. I have obviously heard him talk about these issues before. I am aware broadly of the issues that he is raising, but I am not familiar with the particular article.

PARA.TAB: There are two other points Senator Harradine raised to which I want to respond in the time available. He talked about the decline in real earnings. One also has to look, though, at household disposable income, which has increased over that time. They are both important measures.

Senator Harradine concluded—and everything else, if I understood it, was a preamble to the final point—with the issue of tax equity for families. Having heard him speak on these general issues over a number of years, I understand broadly that to which he is referring. There was some move towards—not so much tax equity, because we are changing the nature of the payment—providing and increasing recognition for people in households who are not in the work force in the changes announced by the Prime Minister in the policy speech during the election, which we will be implementing this year. Some of the issues are being addressed.

Some of those problems to which Senator Harradine referred are slowly being changed by the very modest, all too slow, recovery which we are having at the moment. Some of the underlying factors, in terms of the changing composition of the work force, are permanent changes in the nature of our society, in the nature of employment and in the type of industries that we have in our society. We will not succeed in turning the clock back by tinkering with the tax system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a brief supplementary question. Could the Minister take on notice, and give me an answer at some stage, the aspect of consumer demand and the question of family tax as it affects consumer demand and, therefore, employment?
—I understand Senator Harradine's genuine concern about this. If the Treasurer wants to add anything to what I have had to say, I will get it and provide it to Senator Harradine as soon as I can.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, the Hon. Arthur Donahoe, who I should also point out is a former Speaker of the Parliament of Nova Scotia. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit to this Parliament is both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Given the outstanding record of the ADF in environmental management in the Shoalwater Bay training area—a record that has been enthusiastically and unequivocally supported by all the environmentalists who live in the area up to the present—will the Minister give the Senate an assurance that the ADF will continue to have access to this irreplaceable training area, despite the intrusions of an uninformed and unintelligent environment Minister?

—We intend to be using that particular area well into the future. It has been discussed within Government. Naturally, the focus of discussion within Government has been to do with sandmining rather than anything else. Where the future of that lies, I cannot say. The area is compatible with military use; but it is just as compatible with military use not to have it there. We intend to use the area from now well into the future. Senator MacGibbon has correctly noted that we have been pretty good environmentalists in that area and many other areas around Australia. Some of the more pristine areas that we are now being asked never to use again are there only because we have inhabited them for so long. I see the future use of the Shoalwater Bay area by Australia and also the Republic of Singapore continuing for many years to come.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What has the Government done to respond to the suggestions made by various people and groups about how Australia's wool stockpile could be reduced? I refer in particular to the suggestion made by Mrs Ailsa Bond of the CWA that more Australians should take up the productive, import replacing, value adding craft of knitting.

—Fortunately, I happen to have an answer briefed for me by the Minister who represents this portfolio, Simon Crean. The import of this question is that we should become a nation of knitters. In the wake of the collapse of the reserve price scheme, the Wool Realisation Commission was established to sell the stockpile and discharge the industry debt. In recognition of the current circumstances facing the industry, on 28 April the Government announced a package of measures to assist the wool industry. These measures included: additional structural adjustment assistance; maintaining the wool tax at its current level; relieving the Wool Realisation Commission of the need to sell wool into a weak market, thus avoiding further downward pressures on price; together with the previous removal of the fixed repayment requirements and freeing up the period of sale for non-wool assets. The Government has therefore maximised the commercial flexibility of the Wool Realisation Commission.

PARA.TAB: Also, a variety of suggestions, one of which we have just heard now, have been made to the Government about ways to reduce the stockpile. We have to say that for this problem there is no simple or quick fix solution. Some of the more colourful suggestions for reducing the stockpile, such as burning it—that is one suggestion I have heard—are simply out of the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what Mr Goss reckons.

—It is out of the question as far as the Government is concerned. Mr Goss is not the only one who may have said that. I have heard voices from rural Australia suggesting a similar thing. The Government still regards the stockpile as a national asset and one on which we will eventually realise a gain.

PARA.TAB: The initiative, like that of the CWA and others, cannot address the stockpile issue alone. Those suggestions do raise at least one pertinent issue. They have raised understanding and consciousness in the Australian community about the level of the stockpile and they have certainly sparked a degree of interest about ways in which the stockpile might be dealt with.

The CWA in Victoria has embarked on a training program to teach young Australians to knit. I understand that last year some 18,000 school kids learnt how to knit courtesy of the CWA program. That makes the younger generation conscious of wool in respect of its superior properties as a fibre and its applications. To that extent there is considerable value in the CWA's suggestion of knitting away the stockpile.

The other day I heard someone say that there were something like 18 billion pairs of socks in the stockpile. I think all senators would agree that we would need to trade with a nation of centipedes to reduce that significantly in the immediate future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to today's announcement from the US that next year's sugar quotas will be cut, which will be a loss to Australia of some 10,000 to 11,000 tonnes, as the Minister has said, and a $3 million cut to the farmers. This amounts to a 90 per cent cut in Australia's quota over the last 10 years. I ask the Minister: how do these latest US quota cuts square with President Clinton's rhetoric on free trade and reduced protection? Can the US be trusted on promises it has given under the NAFTA agreement on sugar imports and on finalising the Uruguay Round when it pulls this sort of trade distortion trick just because it suits it?

—Senator Boswell has given some worthwhile statistics in the first part of his question and without dodging the second part, which I will very quickly come to, there are some other statistics that can be added. Before the introduction of wool quotas—I had better get on with sugar because I have just dealt with wool!
—There is a difference.

—There is a considerable difference. Thank you very much, Senator Crane, for helping me. Before the introduction of sugar quotas in the United States in 1982, Australia's exports of sugar to the US totalled 811,000 tonnes. As I said in an earlier answer today, if the new global limits are computed in the normal way in which we would expect them to be computed, the quota for Australia for the year 1993-94 would be down around 86,000 tonnes. In fact, as Senator Boswell says in his question, it is almost a 90 per cent reduction. Back in 1982 we had a 17 per cent share of the US import market. We now have an 8.3 per cent share of the US import market and a two per cent share of the sugar market in the US overall. So that is a dramatic reduction.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell asks in his question what weight we should put on President Clinton's remarks about the completion of the Uruguay Round. The Government's view is that the best way of opening up the sugar market in the United States, and for that matter all the other markets in rural products, particularly beef, is to pursue the Uruguay Round settlement to the full this year. In order to ensure that we deliver as much weight behind the need for a full settlement this year, I have convened a Cairns Group meeting of free trading nations to be held in Thailand in June of this year prior to the meeting of the G7 so that the agricultural nations of the world can put as much effort behind their overtures to the G7 to conclude the Uruguay Round.

We would like to see that multilateral trade negotiation round conclude in a strong way on the draft final act proposals, the Dunkel text, as amended by the Blair House accord which is the agricultural settlement. That is the best way of proceeding. President Clinton has made a number of remarks recently that that is his wish too, and certainly the observation Senator Boswell has made in his question is pertinent, that in the case of sugar that does not seem to be consistent. We believe that the best way of resolving this overall is through the Uruguay Round, but we will be making the representations I referred to in my earlier answer directly on a bilateral basis to try to turn around what appears to be a very damaging decision for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring a sense of familiarity back to the Senate chamber by asking a question of the Minister for Transport and Communications. The Minister would be aware of the tremendous amount of public attention which was directed to a House of Representatives transport and communications report entitled Ships of Shame which was tabled fairly recently. I ask the Minister whether he would inform the Senate and, therefore, the Australian community of what the Government is doing about the problems of substandard shipping that was raised and addressed in that report?

—The Government has a strong commitment to the eradication of the threat to seafarers' lives, the environment and the abuse of human rights associated with substandard shipping. I think it is correct to say that the Australian Government, through its representatives at the appropriate United Nations forum, has done a very great deal in pushing the debate on this issue. This is an international problem requiring concerted effort by all maritime nations.

PARA.TAB: Australia is a relatively small player in the world shipping industry, but we are being instrumental in gaining greater attention to this issue and I would like to acknowledge publicly the efforts of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority in pressing it with the success it has had. Last year's Ships of Shame report by the House of Representatives transport standing committee is now receiving worldwide attention for its clear identification of the issues involved in tackling substandard shipping.

In passing, I commend the chairman of that committee, Peter Morris, a former transport Minister, who is particularly interested in this issue. I advise the Senate that I have asked Mr Morris whether he would have a continuing role in assisting me with that particular matter. A recent feature, a very interesting one—and for those who are interested in this matter, I commend it to them—is the BBC Panorama program on substandard ships; it is worth watching. The committee's chairman whom I have just mentioned, Peter Morris, has just returned from the United States of America where top level officials requested his briefing on the report. The Government has given careful consideration to the issues raised by the Ships of Shame report and we will be finalising our formal response to that report shortly.

Meanwhile, Australia continues to pursue initiatives in the United Nations International Maritime Organisation aimed at improving maritime safety. Last month the Australian Maritime Safety Authority represented Australia at the IMO's new subcommittee on flag state implementation which was discussing a range of methods for improving worldwide ship safety. Australia's proposals to the subcommittee were specifically aimed at reducing shipping casualties and included: implementation of quality standards to be met by classification societies which are responsible for verifying, on behalf of ship owners, the construction and ongoing standard of vessels; introduction of an international certificate of competency for ships' officers; and provision of information to coastal States on accidents occurring in their waters.

One of the things that should be pointed out in terms of that international classification is that one feature that has been revealed over and over again in terms of loss of life at sea and ships at sea is the substandard training of many of the crew on these ships. These proposals are being considered through the IMO process, processes of its member nations. Australia will be promoting their adoption by the world shipping community.

Australia has a record of which it can be justly proud in respect of shipping standards and high quality maritime training. The challenge is now to ensure that ships of other nations observe similar standards. It is worth making the point that safety does carry a cost. If that cost is worth while, it should be paid. One of the features around the world in the loss of these ships—over 40 major vessels suffering either structural damage or lost at sea with the loss of hundreds of lives—has been the age of those ships. One cannot keep a young fleet—the Australian shipping fleet is one of the youngest fleets in the world—without a cost.

I remind the people on the other side of this chamber who constantly want a scorched earth approach to freight rates that there is another element other than freight rates in carrying cargo. I refer to the safety and the lives of the people who serve on board.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women of an answer she gave to Senator Giles yesterday, when she said:

QUESTION.PARA: Yes, I am aware of the report by Mattingly and Partners. . . It claims that nearly all women have a horror story to tell about poor or patronising treatment they have received from banks or financial institutions, in particular from bank managers—most of whom are men.

I refer Senator Crowley to the Western Women Investment Service run by Mrs Robin Greenberg, which provides a service particularly to women in Western Australia. As Senator Crowley will know, the Western Australian Government's women's information referral centre, under the ministry of Carmen Lawrence, recommended that women invest in the Western Women Investment Service. What lesson is to be learnt by women from that experience?

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing that could be learnt from this whole business is that subtleties are lost on Senator Crichton-Browne. The whole point of the Mattingly and Partners report was that in mainstream financial services and banking, where the majority of suppliers of that financial information are men, women have found that the advice they got was very unsympathetic, delivered at the wrong time and the packages of advice were inappropriate.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Crichton-Browne followed that report he would understand that the reason Senator Giles asked me about this was precisely to raise a very important question—in particular, that financial institutions and banks were losing custom by being unaware of or unsympathetic to the needs of women in the services provided by financial institutions or banks. To raise one example of a person who was outside of mainstream banking and financial institutions is completely to miss the point. Nobody would support crooked behaviour by providers of financial information or banking.

The question I was asked was as to how best to provide financial advice to women. They are not looking at separatists; they are looking at how the mainstream financial institutions in banking were completely missing women's needs. It seems to me that Senator Crichton-Browne is trawling a very smelly red herring.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am sure that the Minister did not intend to reflect on me adversely. I remind the Minister, with her long history of involvement with women's issues, that Mrs Greenberg said that women should not invest with men because they could not be trusted with their money. She claimed that men infected women with sexually transmitted debt. Carmen Lawrence, the ex-Premier, encouraged women, as does the Minister, to invest with women. I again ask: what lesson is to be learnt from the Western Women fiasco?

—I suppose I ought to ask Senator Crichton-Browne to repeat that question; a lot of it was lost in the barracking and hijacking from this side. The answer to the main question remains. What I am talking about and what I am asked to represent is the aspirations of the women of Australia and the report of Mattingly and Partners addresses that. It is saying that what can be learnt is that women want good financial advice, women want advice about banking, and that if banks and financial institutions ignore they will lose a lot of custom. That is what that report showed and that is the point that I want to represent in this place.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, relates to Australians who are serving sentences in foreign prisons. Can the Minister advise whether there are any arrangements with other countries to allow prisoners to return to Australia and serve their sentences here? If not, is the Government investigating this possibility? If so, can any progress be expected in the near future?

—At present, there are no arrangements with any other country to allow for the scheme that Senator Colston has asked about, whereby prisoners who are serving sentences in foreign prisons can return to Australia to serve their sentences here. However, we are pursuing this concept in the forum of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. In July 1992 the committee agreed in principle that we should work towards a regime of the nature that Senator Colston has referred to. However, before we can participate in such a scheme, a range of legislative and administrative steps need to be taken at both State and Federal level. To this end, the Committee of Attorneys-General has set up a working group in order to devise the necessary legislative and administrative framework.

PARA.TAB: That group held its first meeting in December 1992. In order to facilitate discussions, the Commonwealth prepared a discussion paper proposing that, as a first step, Australia should seek to be a party to one of the existing international schemes—the Council of Europe convention on the international transfer of sentenced persons. It may then be necessary to look at how we can enter into other bilateral arrangements with other countries.

The Commonwealth's position is premised on the need for the full participation of all States and Territories. It is also noted in this process that there is no such agreement between all the jurisdictions. In terms of the next step, it is now up to the States and Territories to state their positions on the scheme so that the issue can be addressed at the next attorneys meeting in June 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, I said earlier in Question Time that I would try to get some information for Senator Macdonald about Fraser Island. I have received information from Mrs Kelly. The draft management plan for the Great Sandy region unequivocally rules out sandmining within the region, including the World Heritage listed Fraser Island. In fact, as I think Senator Macdonald would be aware, the Queensland Government acquired the remaining Fraser Island sandmining leases in 1991. As for other forms of mining on Fraser Island, the intention in the Queensland draft management plan is to declare it a national park. The northern half of the island is already national park. This will automatically ban mining on Fraser Island.

PARA.TAB: As for mining elsewhere within the Great Sandy region which is not World Heritage listed, this is banned in national parks such as the Cooloola park. In other areas, the Queensland draft management plan leaves open the option for considering exploration, subject to special strict statutory environmental guidelines applicable to the region. The region is not prospective for minerals, and the Queensland Mining Industry Council has already indicated today that it expects there will be little or no interest in the region. The Commonwealth Government has no proposals for sandmining before it on Fraser Island and will not allow sandmining on Fraser Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to reply to a question I took on notice from Senator Vanstone in the Senate yesterday. I was asked for my views with regard to the Longman's case and whether the Government was happy with the extent to which the High Court's decision in that case was being followed. Senator Vanstone seemed more concerned yesterday with scoring cheap debating points than with advancing debate on this important issue. She has implied that I am more interested in publicity than in the substance of the issue, but my public comments have been in response to widely expressed community concerns.

PARA.TAB: I have considered the Longman's case and I recognise that it is an important step forward in ensuring the equal treatment of women before the law. However, it does not bear directly on my response to the community's concerns with the attitudes of judges. I stress again that in commenting on the remarks of particular judges I have never sought to interfere with the proper responsibilities of the judiciary to conduct their courts in accord with the relevant general and statute law.I believe that the appropriate person to deal with the legal questions raised by this issue is the Attorney-General. Indeed, I wrote to the Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, on 6 May requesting that he raise the issue of women's equality before the law at the next meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

I note that the judiciary is responding positively to changing community attitudes and concerns, as demonstrated by the approach to this Government of the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration seeking financial support for its gender awareness program—support that the Government has been pleased to give, as announced by the Prime Minister during the election campaign, and which I strongly support.

I hope Senator Vanstone is in agreement with me on the issue of gender bias and the law. I hope in the future we can pursue a common objective in this matter in a constructive way. As Senator Vanstone is a lawyer, I suspect that she will have constructive and positive suggestions to make, which I would welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation in relation to misleading media reports.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to correct two instances of misleading and inaccurate reporting in relation to statements I have made about Cambodia. First, on this morning's Radio National Daybreak program the Leader of the state of Cambodia administration in Phnom Penh, Mr Hun Sen, said in an interview:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Australia and Japan have been saying that if there's any victims among Australians and Japanese they would withdraw their contingents from Cambodia.

He goes on to plead that Australia not withdraw its contingent in these circumstances. Mr Hun Sen's comments appeared to be based loosely on a wire service report, circulated widely in Cambodia and around Asia generally following my appearance on the Channel 9 Sunday program on 11 April, to this effect:
. . . Australia and Japan have said they will withdraw peace-keeping troops from Cambodia if the Khmer Rouge launches a major assault on UN peace-keeping positions.

Quotes of that kind appeared, for example, in the KRT/Reuter report repeated in the Melbourne Herald-Sun on 17 April. Let me make clear again, as I have on many occasions—for example, in a press conference on 21 April—that there is no question whatever of Australia taking any unilateral action to withdraw from Cambodia, however much the situation might deteriorate. Of course we hope it will not. What I did say on the Sunday program, and on many other occasions before and since, is that if there were to be a basic change in the security environment of a kind that made it impossible in practice for the election to proceed, involving widespread frontal assaults on UNTAC personnel, not merely sporadic and isolated incidents, in those circumstances of course the international community, including Australia, would have to reconsider its position, with the options being reduced essentially to two: either pull out the whole operation or fundamentally change the UN mandate into an enforcement one. I table, if I may, the texts of the various statements and transcript reports to which I referred.

PARA.TAB: The second seriously misleading report occurred in this morning's Australian in the guise of a correction on page 2 of that newspaper as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, was quoted in The Australian yesterday as saying the security situation in Cambodia was "extremely dangerous". In fact, Senator Evans said it was "increasingly dangerous"—
then comes the problem—
and "very dangerous".

The trouble with this correction, or purported correction, was that it was itself quite incorrect and, as a result, compounded and magnified the negative effect of the original piece of misreporting. The facts are simply these. In answer to Senator Hill in Question Time in this chamber on 11 May, I described the situation in Cambodia in these terms:
It is now an increasingly dangerous situation but it is by no means a desperate situation.
In response to a supplementary question, I added:
It is, of course, the case that the situation is dangerous—it is very difficult—but it also remains the case that the election can proceed . . .

Nowhere in these answers did I use the expression `extremely dangerous'; nor did I say, here or elsewhere, `very dangerous'. I deliberately chose my words in these respects very carefully, both in order to accurately describe the present situation on the ground and also because I am acutely conscious that many Australians have friends and relatives now serving in Cambodia, and the last thing I would wish to do is to unnecessarily add to their anxiety. The Australian's first attempt to report my remarks, on 12 May, came out as follows:

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans conceded the situation was now "extremely dangerous" for the 600-strong Australian contingent . . .

SPEECH.PARA: My office's attempt to secure a correction of this led to the further journalistic felony that I have already described; namely, the report today which used the expression `very dangerous' when I had said nothing of the kind but had simply said `very difficult'. I hope the Australian will find itself professionally capable of getting its report right tomorrow.

PARA.TAB: I say, finally, for the record that in the conduct of foreign relations, more so than in just about any other area of government activity, words matter—the precise language used, the nuances, the context. I cannot pretend, any more than any other Minister, that I always have the words exactly right, but on these occasions at least it would have done a great deal to avoid international misunderstanding, and perhaps some human anxieties as well, if the words I did use had been accurately reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the hearing of Estimates Committee E the other night, in the Melba column of the Australian there is a small paragraph attributing a statement to Christine Goode, who was one of the departmental officers appearing before the committee, and describing a light-hearted repartee in which she advised that the previous day, the Tuesday, had been her birthday. In this article she is attributed as saying that maybe next birthday will be better. That is totally incorrect. By reading page E85 of the Hansard of Estimates E on 11 May, one will see that that quote actually should have been attributed to me.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Standing order 190 says that, by leave of the Senate, a senator may explain a matter of a personal nature. So far, Senator West has been talking about someone else, and I cannot see how that is a personal matter for her.
—Order! When the point of order was taken, I thought Senator West had just referred to herself. I will listen carefully.
—I was referring to the fact that on page E85 of the Hansard I am reported, accurately, as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Maybe next birthday will be better; you will not need to be here . . .

—meaning that May is not a normal time for us to hold Estimates and also that it is highly unlikely that anybody in his or her right mind would find it very enjoyable to have to spend any one of his or her birthdays doing any work that relates to an estimates committee at that hour of the night, particularly after midnight. I also draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that in Margot Kingston's article in today's Canberra Times it is alleged that the time of completion was 3 a.m.; it was actually 2.28 a.m. The Hansard makes particularly interesting reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston on 13 May 1993 relating to the tendering process for subscription television licences.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from Senator Collins having committed what I would have thought was an egregious offence in not only treating this chamber with contempt but also refusing to answer a question which was so simple that it merely asked whether a document exists, I submit that he has been guilty of a much more serious offence. Yesterday, when being asked a question by Senator O'Chee about advice that had been received and on what basis he had given a direction to the Australian Broadcasting Authority, Senator Collins conceded that he had had oral advice from his departmental officers. It was put to him that the only written advice he had had was from John Doherty, a senior legal adviser in the department, and that that was to the contrary. Senator Collins said:
I did receive advice that I had power . . . If I had not been told that that was lawful, I would never have made it.

He declined to elaborate on whether the advice was oral or written on the grounds that the matter was sub judice. We know that the notion of sub judice has absolutely nothing to do with this particular situation because that, of course, is a question that goes to the merits of a case before either a jury or a magistrate. It clearly has no relevance to the situation of a judge sitting alone who has already reserved his decision. In any event, it is beside the point.

PARA.TAB: The much more serious proposition is that, following that statement to the Senate that he had received advice, which he declined to identify, Senator Collins has gone on today to identify that advice. He identified it by tabling during an answer a copy of the advice he received from Roger Beale, a senior departmental official, which accompanied the draft notification to the ABA. As I understand it, what Senator Collins relies upon in support of the proposition that he had written advice in favour of his action is this:

SPEECH.PARA: Under section 161 of the Broadcasting Services Act, you have express power to notify the ABA of general policies of the Government that are to apply to the ABA.
This is sophistry of the highest order because that is simply a provision in the Act and the whole of the legal advice Senator Collins got in writing from Mr Doherty—

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't got anything in writing.
—Senator Collins got advice from Mr Doherty. Does he want to deny that?
—Produce it.
—Does he deny this?
—Wait until next week and see.

—Once again Senator Collins is treating the Senate with contempt, pretending that somehow some extra-parliamentary committee appointed to suit his own convenience, to sheet home blame to everyone but himself, has standing ahead of this chamber. We all know that it has not. The written advice—Senator Collins conceded this in the Federal Court, as I understand it—says this:

SPEECH.PARA: Any policy or direction issued by the Minister must not be inconsistent with the scope and objects of the Broadcasting Services Act. The ABA is at law required to act in accordance with the legislation as it stands. It is questionable whether the ABA could take into account, or be directed to take into account, a proposed change to the legislation. The ABA does not seem to have a legitimate basis to adopt the approach of rejecting all applications put before it for subscription television broadcasting licences via MDS. A direction not to grant MDS licences for subscription television broadcasting services seems to cut across the objectives of the legislation.

I would have thought that was all very clear, especially to someone who fancies himself as having an understanding of the basic principles of administrative law. The proposition is that one reads power provided in an Act within the context of that Act. It does not mean that one is at large. If it says that one has power to give directions, one can give directions only within the objectives of the Act. That is precisely what the written advice was about. The written advice raised very serious doubts about whether Senator Collins had any such legal power, and he well understands this. In his own words, he is not a mug, whatever else he might be, and he ought to understand—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I said that you are not a mug.

—So he concedes that he is a mug. I apologise; I had not meant to embarrass Senator Collins in that way. It ought to be abundantly clear that the point at issue is whether that express power was indeed within the terms of the Act. If it is not, of course, it is ultra vires. That was a very important legal question on which Senator Collins had precise legal advice. And all the written advice raised all sorts of doubts about it. Apart from being couched in diplomatic language, I would have thought that any sensible person reading that would have said that it was a no-no. It was clearly telling Senator Collins, in effect, that it was contrary to the Act and that he could not do it.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, what Senator Collins had was legal advice saying that he was not able to give the directions he did. Yet he stands up here and tells the Senate that he had advice supporting his actions. If that is the best Senator Collins can do, I invite him to indicate whether there was any express legal advice other than that of Mr Doherty's; whether in fact he kept notes of any discussions he had by telephone with any of his legal advisers; or whether what he really did was ignore written advice that this was ultra vires, simply pretend that he talked a number of advisers into a certain position, and then go ahead and do precisely what he wanted to do in the first place, irrespective of any advice to the contrary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to reply to that.
—You don't need leave.
—Oh, it is a motion; all right.
—You know everything until you are properly corrected, don't you—and you will be soon.

—How about Senator Vanstone going outside and having this discussion? Senator Alston's behaviour is really quite outrageous. He knows that there are three matters before the Federal Court; not two, three—and I said all this this morning. On the question of sub judice, there are as many definitions of what is sub judice as there are definitions of ministerial responsibility.
—That is absolute rubbish.
—Can Senator Alston let me finish.
—Why? You interrupt everybody else.

—I thought Senator Alston would be interested in what I have to say. Madam Acting Deputy President, I do not think it is wise for members of parliament to discuss matters that are before the court. But I think it would be outrageously unwise for the party which is the subject of that action to do so before there is a judgment. Does Senator Evans disagree with that? Of course he does not. But only a reasonable person could come to that conclusion—and of course that description does not include, and never has, Senator Alston. I think it would be outrageous of me, as the subject of that court action—
—You told this chamber you had legal advice. Where is it? That is all you are being asked: where is it?

—Senator Alston knows how outrageous that question is. The Federal Court currently has in its possession all papers relevant to this issue—every single one of them. The Federal Court currently has within its possession three hours of evidence from me sworn under oath in that court. I will just straighten out a few—
—I have never read such a dog's breakfast in my life.

—Why does not Senator Alston go back and read all the documents. Senator Alston never has and he never will—and, with the greatest respect, I would suggest that to the press gallery as well. The misinterpretations that have been placed on that advice have been outrageous. I explained that to the Senate this morning. A whole range of options was being discussed—
—Blame everyone else.

—I wonder whether big-mouth over there could just hold himself still for a minute. A whole range of options was being discussed over that 48 hours—a whole range of options other than the option that was finally adopted, and that is something Senator Alston has absolutely failed to notice. In my view, there would have been real problems if some of the options that had been addressed and to which advice had been directed had been adopted.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston should have a look, if he wants to, at the records in the Federal Court that have been made available to journalists and were being discussed—and I talked about it this morning: options such as directing the ABA to restrict MDS to narrowcasting only, which is a course I did not adopt and on which I got advice that that would probably almost certainly require legislation. The cold hard facts are—and Senator Alston is not interested in the cold hard facts—that there were options being canvassed that were not subsequently adopted that may have given rise to that.

I am happy—indeed, I have no choice in the matter—to have those matters judged by the Federal Court because they will be judged by the Federal Court. I do not think this chamber should try to supplant that role, as Senator Alston is now trying to judge it here, because it is being specifically addressed by the Federal Court. Have a look at the submission. The press has it. Have a look at it.

There are three issues principally before the Federal Court. One and two relate to that definition Senator Alston referred to of whether the advice or the direction was within power. That is a legal matter for the court to determine.

The third issue before the Federal Court—and I canvassed it this morning—is my role in it, and that is that I took the direction knowing it was unlawful. That is not an abstract legal issue; it has been tested before the Federal Court. The applicant's submission to the Federal Court—and I am the subject of it—goes to considerable lengths to make that point. So this very point Senator Alston makes is being judged in there now. I absolutely do not resile—despite the outrageous interpretation that Senator Alston has made on sub judice—from saying that it would be outrageously improper, or certainly unwise, for a member of parliament, who is the subject of the court action concerned, to canvass those issues before the judgment has been brought down. I do not resile from saying that. One would have to be a very irresponsible person, in my view, to do so.

What I am saying to the Senate on that issue—not on the first two issues: that is, as to whether the section 160 and 161 matters were properly dealt with—is that the court will determine that. At the appropriate time the court will bring down a judgment as to whether or not the legal advice that I received was correct. I point out that the people whom I was consulting—in concert with the senior officers of my department, of course—are the people who gave the directions to the draftsmen to put that Act together.

As I said again this morning—I read it out, and why does not everybody who wants to comment on this issue have a look at the Hansard from this morning?—I thought it would be inappropriate and outrageous for me to table the full advice of the Attorney-General because it contains the detailed legal reasons for the short answers that were given. But there was no difficulty in tabling the short answers or putting them into Hansard, and the transcript from the court shows it. I gave evidence in the court that this advice existed. That evidence was presented in court as a result of questions that were being asked of me by the applicant's barrister.

The facts are that on the fifth of the month, after that decision was taken, I received written legal advice from the department of the Attorney-General, that was agreed by the Acting Solicitor-General—I might add, an eminent jurist who is held in very high regard, I know, by members of the private bar for his knowledge of constitutional law. I read into the Hansard—what more can I do?—the short answers that were given to those questions. In terms of the principle question, as to whether it was lawful to issue that direction, the answer from the Attorney-General's Department was yes. Have a look at the Hansard.

The question of Senator Alston's scenario, and that is the key point at issue here—the scenario that he outrageously painted here for the second or third or fourth time today—as to how I came to that decision, is squarely before the Federal Court. There will be a judgment made on it at some time in the future. That is a matter for the court.
So far as the Senate's role in this is concerned, the Senate will always have a role in this. I think Senator Evans will probably be particularly interested—

TALK.START.PARA: —He looks riveted.

—I think he will be interested in this, in connection with some views that I know Senator Evans has about some proceedings quite famous—or, in my view, infamous—before Senate committees in respect of natural justice. If Senator Evans agrees with the interpretation of the possibilities of obtaining natural justice, as Senator Alston puts it, it will be interesting because I have strong views about it.
—No way.

—That is right. I have strong views about that particular matter, as Senator Evans does. It is astonishing stuff the way this senator twists and turns and jumps around to take positions that suit his own position. Senator Alston said publicly many times that he `does not want anything done that will interfere with the natural justice to which the public servants who are currently being questioned are entitled'. I said at the Senate estimates committee that I agree with him. That has to be protected, particularly when one considers how short-lived this inquiry is. We will have the full results of this, and all the papers Senator Alston refers to, in our hands before we get up.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator Alston that natural justice to these public servants is very important. I also agree with Senator Alston that nothing should be done to prejudge this inquiry. But what did Senator Alston say? He said that whilst preserving this natural justice for these public servants, the matter should be tested in front of a Senate committee. This is what Senator Alston said about natural justice and I agree with him. He only says it; the trouble is that he does not do it. He said this:

SPEECH.PARA: The concept of natural justice involves ensuring that people are given the right to be heard before a decision is made to their detriment . . .
I am quoting from the Senate Hansard of Estimates Committee E on 11 May. He then went on to say this, and I also agree with him, in terms of natural justice:
. . . and also that they be allowed to be heard by a tribunal free of bias.

In my experience of six years, and I might add it is obvious to anyone who looks at them, how could any reasonable person come to the conclusion that Senate committees by their very nature are tribunals free of bias? History has shown in terms of one infamous committee that quite apart from Senate committees being tribunals free of bias, when judging people Senate committees of inquiry are kangaroo courts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue at stake here is not a question of whether public servants have been denied natural justice. The real issue at stake is the conduct of this Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins). Apart from the way in which the Minister has marched out of the Senate chamber for the second day in a row being disgracefully rude, what this issue is really about is whether Senator Collins can tell the truth. Can Senator Collins tell the truth in the Senate and can Senator Collins tell the truth in court?

PARA.TAB: Yesterday we heard how Senator Collins did not tell the truth in court. Today by his speech in this Senate chamber and by the documents which he tabled in this chamber this morning, Senator Collins has merely confirmed that he has in fact misled the court. Moreover, Senator Collins has gone further because he has repeated those deliberately and blatantly misleading comments here in the Senate chamber again today. He has compounded his sin because what he has done has been to repeat those same untruths here in the Senate.

Senator Collins would have us believe that he was given legal advice to the effect that what he was doing was legal. What Senator Collins was doing was anything but legal. Certainly it is to be conceded—and I am very glad to have this document—that Senator Collins did in fact receive a memo; a portion of which read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Under section 161 of the Broadcasting Services Act you have express power to notify the ABA of general policies of the Government that are to apply to the ABA.
In other words, we have the ABA which has to administer the policy of the Government. The memo continued:
Under section 162 you may give directions of a general nature to the ABA as to the performance of its functions.

However, it does not say that the Minister has a power to give an instruction to the ABA to do something that is contrary to the purposes of the legislation. The ABA, in putting into effect the policy of the Government, can only do what it is permitted to do within the scope of the legislation; in other words, the legislation states the limit of the power of the ABA.

PARA.TAB: Within that limit of power the Minister then has the opportunity to give particular instructions. What Senator Collins continues to run away from is the fact that the legal advice he was given by Mr John Doherty, who is the legal adviser to his department, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Any policy or direction issued by the Minister must not be inconsistent with the scope and objects of the Broadcasting Services Act and its provisions.
In other words, the Minister can give general directions to the ABA, but these have to be matters that the ABA is empowered to deal with under the Act. Mr Doherty's legal advice goes on to say:

The ABA is at law required to act in accordance with the legislation as it stands. It is questionable whether the ABA could take into account (or be directed to take into account) a proposed change to the legislation . . .

In other words, the advice says that irrespective of what instructions the Minister wants to give to the ABA about MDS, the ABA cannot put them into effect because they are outside the scope of the legislation. Mr Doherty's advice continues:
The ABA does not seem to have legitimate basis to adopt the approach of rejecting all applications put before it for subscription TV broadcasting licences via MDS.
A direction not to grant MDS licences for subscription television broadcasting—
and that is what Senator Collins was considering instructing the ABA to do—
seems to cut across the objectives of the legislation.

In other words, the Minister can do only what the legislation permits him to do. The Minister does not have absolute power; he has to abide by the rules of the Parliament. Every senator has to abide by the rules the Parliament has agreed to.
