This advice from Mr Doherty was, in effect, that the Minister could not instruct the ABA to do what he was about to instruct it to do because he had no authority to do so and those instructions were completely contrary to the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Yet Senator Collins comes into this place and waves this bit of paper that says he has a general power to give the ABA instructions within the scope of the legislation. He seems to think that this one little bit of paper will get him off the hook. This one little bit of paper hangs Senator Collins by the neck, because he knew perfectly well that the limit of his power to give instructions to the ABA was solely within the scope of the legislation.

What the Minister was in fact doing was giving instructions to the ABA to do something that cut right across the legislation—something which he had no power to do. Senator Collins therefore cannot honestly say in the Federal Court, or in this place or outside this chamber, that he has told the truth. He cannot say in court, he cannot say in the Senate and he cannot honestly say outside this chamber that he had the power to do what he did.

In other words, we have seen by Senator Collins's own words, and by the documents he chose to table in this Parliament today, that he has misled the court, he has misled the chamber and he has failed grievously to exercise the standards of good judgment which we should expect of a Minister of the Crown. Senator Collins, in walking out of the Senate again today, has shown that he does not care for the judgment of the Senate, that he does not care for the truth, and that he would rather this whole matter went away because it is awfully embarrassing for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish it would too.

—I bet Senator Burns would like it to go away too. No matter how much Senator Burns interjects, and I know his interjections are not particularly enlightening, he cannot argue with the truth. The truth is that Senator Collins has misled the court, misled this Parliament, and failed grievously to discharge his duties as a Minister.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald on 13 May 1993 relating to sandmining on Fraser Island.

SPEECH.PARA: The Goss Government's draft plan for the Great Sandy region, which takes in Fraser Island, allows for the exploration and extraction of oil, gas and minerals, as long as they are conducted `in a manner which does not threaten other values of the region'. There is a concern that this will allow for mining in that very fragile area. Senator Schacht says that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has said there will be no mining. Of course, we have learnt from a long, sad history that we simply cannot take the word of a member of this Government. Senator Ray well knows that; he promised an artillery school for Townsville before the last election and it did not eventuate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie. I did not; you know that is not true. Stop lying.
—That is true.
—I have never commented on an artillery school for Townsville.
—It was a promise before the 1990 election.
—When I was not Minister, so retract.

—I am sorry; it was Senator Ray's predecessor. The former Minister for Defence, just a few weeks before the 1990 election, promised an artillery school for Townsville. It did not eventuate. I simply use that example to say that we cannot accept the promises of Ministers of this Government.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Senator Macdonald, it might be appropriate if you apologise for the fact that you very closely associated Senator Ray with the allegations you made.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Ray was not the Minister; it was his predecessor. I apologise for that. It was the then Minister for Defence. Senator Ray, I think, is the present Minister for Defence and certainly was before the election. The point I am making is that we cannot trust the word of Ministers of this Government. That is just one example. Examples are legion if one wants to go through them. That is one that springs to mind very easily.

PARA.TAB: If Mrs Kelly, the Minister for the environment, says that no mining will take place, why did she not insist that the draft management plan contain some written guarantee of that? The Federal Government has long found itself without any scruples in interfering in environmental matters in Queensland, and the question of the World Heritage listing of the wet tropics rainforest is a very clear example of that.

The Federal Government always does this sort of thing. It has no hesitation in doing it. If it has had no hesitation before, why would it not do it now? It simply leaves in some confusion the question of whether the Queensland Labor Government will allow mining on Fraser Island in the Great Sandy region of Queensland. That confusion should be overcome by a definite statement in the management plan for Fraser Island. I call upon Mrs Kelly, if it is her view that no mining will take place, to insist that the Goss Labor Government in Queensland does something about making it part of the management plan.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion moved by Senator Macdonald to take note of my answer to his question concerning sandmining. I did not hear all his remarks; I heard part of his remarks on the monitor in my room and then came down here because I was most concerned that he had misconstrued the information I gave to the Parliament at the end of Question Time. Senator Macdonald asked a question in the Senate—on which I said I would get information for him—about whether we were going to allow mining on Fraser Island. The answer I gave was an unequivocal no about any suggestion of sandmining on Fraser island. I said that the Commonwealth Government has no proposals for sandmining before it, and it will not allow sandmining on Fraser Island.

PARA.TAB: I give Senator Macdonald the benefit of the doubt that he is confused, rather than maliciously misleading. The wider area of the Great Sandy region is not under the control of the Federal Government, it is not World Heritage listed. There is a Queensland Government management plan which could—I emphasise the word could—allow, under very strict environmental guidelines, an application for mining. The thing I find remarkable about Senator MacDonald's performance today is that he is one of the great State-righters complaining about Federal Government interference in matters he thinks are relevant only to States' rights issues, such as the environment.

Here is a case where, because the rest of the Great Sandy region is not World Heritage listed—it is a Queensland national park—Senator Macdonald is complaining that we may allow mining. It is a Queensland decision. If Senator Macdonald were fair dinkum about his concern about sandmining in the Great Sandy region—not in Fraser Island, because that is already out—he would be standing up here asking the Australian Government to have the constitutional power to take that over from the Queensland Government. He would be the first to scream and squeal that this was an intrusion on the rights of the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did that fairly easily in the wet tropics.
—Because that was World Heritage listed.
—You made it that.

—Of course. I will take Senator Macdonald up on this. I will tell Mrs Kelly, the Minister, that Senator Macdonald is now asking that the rest of the Great Sandy region be listed as World Heritage. Is Senator Macdonald saying that to us? Is he saying that he wants us to get World Heritage listing for all of the Great Sandy region?
—You clarify the confusion.
—Is that no or yes?
—You clarify the confusion; that is your job.

—I am asking Senator Macdonald because he is getting up here and he cannot answer. He has tried to be malicious and misleading; he wants to run a story in Queensland tomorrow in the press that there is a chance there could be sandmining on Fraser Island. In my answer today at the end of Question Time, I specifically said in relation to Fraser Island there will be no sandmining. That is what I said. Senator Macdonald stands up here after Question Time and interprets another part of the answer dealing with the rest of the Great Sandy region—not Fraser Island—and says that because that is under Queensland control, and we cannot say absolutely definitely—
—You have no hesitation in overriding the Queensland government.

—We have caught Senator Macdonald out on this stunt. For Senator Macdonald to claim he is an environmentalist or a friend of the environment movement, or that he is in favour of the Federal Government now intervening against Queensland, is absurd when one looks at his previous performance in this chamber. If he wants to enter this debate, he should be fair dinkum and say that there should be sandmining on Fraser Island. That is what he wants; we all know that that is his view. He does not want the Federal Government involved in any environmental matter in Queensland. That is his view. He is trying to get a cheap point and create a misleading headline in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: I think we have hit Senator Macdonald on the head with this little stunt. There will be no sandmining on Fraser Island. I will take this up with Mrs Kelly; I will tell her that Senator Macdonald is raising the issue, that he wants the rest of the Great Sandy region put down for World Heritage listing. We will see how he gets on with his mates in the National Party and Liberal Party in Queensland and the Queensland mining industry.

He apparently has crossed the Rubicon; he has given up being a flack for the mining industry to become a flack for the environmental movement in Queensland. It is an extraordinary performance only matched by his convoluted attempt to explain in the election campaign whether or not there would be a GST on local government service charges. He was caught out on that. It contributed probably three or four seats to our victory. I caught him out today trying to be malicious in spreading an untruth about the Australian Government's policy on sandmining on Fraser Island.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was particularly interested that Senator Macdonald raised this issue when his anti-environment stance is extremely well known, particularly in his own State of Queensland, not only in this matter but also in relation to the Tully-Millstream project in which we have had some altercations across this chamber in the past. Quite clearly, in that particular case there was no need to build that power station. As we have indicated previously, there is considerable evidence that it would interfere with a very important recreational facility which is now being exploited by the tourist industry very effectively. When we started this debate Senator Macdonald indicated that they could buy the water to raft down the Tully after the dam was built, totally avoiding the enormous cost which the tourist operators would have to pay and which would kill the industry.

PARA.TAB: I turn specifically to the issue of sandmining. I agree with the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) about this. The reason this issue has been raised today is that I raised it earlier in the week. It received considerable publicity in Senator Macdonald's home State of Queensland. He is simply doing everything he possibly can to counteract any sort of publicity which the Democrats might get for their very good stand on environmental protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has made a very big difference to your vote.

—It has made a considerable difference. We have won an additional seat in Queensland, something which Senator Macdonald's party was not successful in doing. The evidence is clear. Our record on environmental protection in Queensland is extremely good, and that is what Senator Macdonald is on about.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday in another debate, by way of interjection, Senator Macdonald also said, `What is in it for you?', suggesting that we would only argue any particular case if there was something in it for us. That underlines where Senator Macdonald is coming from; he will support things where there is something in it for him but not as a matter of principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, you're just a little grub.

—What is in it for him is that he wants to stir up a bit of publicity. I can only agree absolutely entirely with Senator Schacht in this case that it is a very cheap political stunt and he has no commitment to protecting either Fraser Island or the Great Sandy region.
—Why don't you go and join them?
—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I ask Senator Macdonald to withdraw the remarks he made about Senator Coulter.
—Which?
—The word starting with `g'; I think he knows the one he made.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—There was such a lot of clamour, I did not hear the word to which you take exception.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I was the only one who heard it, I do not require him to withdraw.

—On the point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: I also heard clearly and distinctly the remarks that Senator Macdonald made about Senator Coulter. In accordance with the Standing Orders, they should be withdrawn.
—Senator Macdonald, I am assured that you made a remark that was derogatory of Senator Coulter and I would ask you to withdraw.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, if you ask me to, I will. I do not know quite what you are talking about. If you are going to make those sorts of rulings, you must also listen to what Senator Coulter says. It does not worry me; not many people take any notice of what Senator Coulter says.

—Senator Macdonald, I have asked you to withdraw unconditionally. I assure you that in the event that such complaints were made about Senator Coulter's language, I would have upheld those requests as well. Would you please do so?

—I have, Madam Acting Deputy President. But I do ask you to be impartial in your rulings. It seems in order for Senator Coulter to malign me, but if I happen to say something, his friends in the Labor Party protect him. They always look after the Democrats—and maybe that is what is in it for Senator Coulter, that he gets these people, these thugs, to protect him.
—Senator Macdonald, you are out of order. Will you please be seated.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Devereux on 13 May 1993 relating to productivity improvements in the manufacturing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: As one who was in the manufacturing sector before entering the Senate, I welcome the encouraging news that Senator Schacht conveyed to the Senate earlier this afternoon. However, I believe that perhaps we should give some balance to the comments that were made by the Minister in relation to certain improvements in manufacturing activity. I therefore draw the attention of the Senate to a survey which was conducted by the Australian Chamber of Manufactures. Its March manufacturing survey showed the alarming news of a 50 per cent increase in the number of firms moving offshore between 1991 and 1993. This means a further increase in the export of Australian jobs and a further—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which report are we talking about?
—The Chamber of Manufactures' March manufacturing survey.
—Just released.

—Yes. It indicated a 50 per cent increase in the number of firms moving offshore between 1991 and 1993. I remind the Senate that this means a further increase in the export of Australian jobs and further increases in our import Bill. I think we need to put this in total perspective, although I welcome those increases and those improvements the Minister referred to.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to speak on this subject because we do not have many debates, questions or answers on manufacturing in this country. Therefore, I urge the Government to sit down with business and the unions to develop a vision and a plan for Australian industry that will develop Australian industry and create Australian jobs. I thank the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I asked Senator Watson for the information because I wanted to get the right survey. I will take that information up with the department. I do not know whether the figure of 50 per cent was an increase from two firms to four firms or an increase from 10 firms to 20 in total volume, and that point has to be looked at.

PARA.TAB: I also want to draw Senator Watson's attention to one aspect of the McKinsey report that I quoted in my answer. That report put some information forward about firms investing overseas. It is not as concerned as Senator Watson was in his remarks, saying that many of the successful firms exporting from Australia do so because they have joint ventures and opportunities from their establishment of a venture in an overseas country. Those behind the report are not as concerned about the issue of the export of jobs, which Senator Watson quite rightly raised, as initially all of us would be.

I want to point out one other matter to Senator Watson. The figures I referred to were increases in exports from the manufacturing sector, not general overall manufacturing output. I assure Senator Watson that he has raised an issue with me and now that I know the report he is referring to I will seek some further information and provide it to him. If he is interested, I will also make arrangements to get for him some information from the McKinsey report because I am sure that, with his interest in this area, he will find the material of assistance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the National Capital

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on the National Capital on Gungahlin's transport links. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

The Parliament established the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory (now known as the Joint Committee on the National Capital) to inquire into and report on, inter alia, the National Capital Plan and amendments to the Plan. On 16 August 1991, acting under these terms of reference, the then Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories referred to the Committee proposals contained within the National Capital Plan for transport links to serve the future township of Gungahlin, in Canberra's north.

The Committee has undertaken a lengthy and detailed review of these proposals, having held four days of public hearings and field inspections and received 63 separate submissions to the Inquiry from individuals, organisations, governments and government agencies with an interest in these proposals. Both the ACT Planning Authority and the National Capital Planning Authority were among the 18 individuals and organisations to give evidence before the Committee.

On 30 May 1991, the Committee presented its Report to Parliament. The Report includes a comprehensive body of recommendations addressing planning, environmental and community concerns. As Minister for the Arts and Territories I am pleased that these recommendations in large part support the principles of planning and development put forward within the National Capital Plan.
Where the Government has accepted the need for changes to the National Capital Plan, these will

SPEECH.PARA: now be considered within the framework of the statutory requirements of the Plan.

PARA.TAB: The Committee's report has identified specific initiatives that can be pursued within the Australian Capital Territory to benefit local, and indeed global, environmental concerns. The Report has done so in a careful and balanced way, such that the transport needs of future Gungahlin residents will be met while protecting the amenity of existing residences located within Canberra's northern suburbs, and preserving key areas of native bushland so important to the National Capital.

Many of the recommendations address matters that are primarily of concern to the Australian Capital Territory Government, and as a result I have forwarded a copy of this Response to that Government for consideration.

A number of the recommendations, particularly those which consider issues of employment location in the Territory and policies for the future of public transport, have already been identified within the National Capital Plan and are currently being acted upon.

It is my firm belief that the work of the Joint Committee on the National Capital, in respect of the National Capital Plan, is fundamentally important, as it provides a bridge between the Australian Capital Territory under self government and the Australian Capital Territory as the Nation's Capital.

SPEECH.PARA: RESPONSE OF THE GOVERNMENT TO THE REPORT Of THE JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY): `GUNGAHLIN'S TRANSPORT LINKS'
RECOMMENDATION
1. The Committee recommends that:
(a) bus services be introduced into Gungahlin as soon as the first neighbourhoods are occupied;
(b) intertown express services be introduced between Gungahlin and Belconnen, and Gungahlin and Civic as soon as demand exists;
(c) a conveniently located bus interchange be established in Gungahlin at the first opportunity; and

(d) a detailed strategy of measures to encourage the use of public transport and other non-car modes of transport, such as those described in paragraph 3.4, be developed and implemented as soon as Gungahlin's first neighbourhoods are occupied.
COMMENT

While these matters are the responsibility of the ACT Government, the extent to which non-car modes of transport including buses are utilised would be expected to have a significant effect on the scale of the need for the development of road links to Gungahlin.
RECOMMENDATION
2. The Committee recommends that:

(a) the NCPA and the ACT Planning Authority jointly commission or conduct a study into the establishment of a rapid transport system in the Australian Capital Territory.This study should consider the following matters:
(i) the most appropriate type of rapid transport technology;
(ii) the extent of such a transport system, for example whether it should link Gungahlin to Civic alone or be part of a wider network;
(iii) a timetable for the construction of such a system including the possible early establishment of the system in already settled areas of Canberra;
(iv) the construction and operational costs of such a system;
(v) the potential to attract private involvement in the establishment of such a system through `joint venture' or `value capture' arrangements; and
(vi) the impact of such a system on reducing the demand for additional road space from Gungahlin;
COMMENT

Supported. The NCPA and the ACT Planning Authority have jointly commissioned a group of consultants to conduct the Future Public Transport Options Study. Work has commenced to address these issues as well as the question of the wider public transport needs of Canberra in the future.
RECOMMENDATION

(b) to maximise the potential advantages of a new technology rapid transport system, including the possibility of reducing the need for additional road space to cater for the travel needs of the future residents of Gungahlin, this study should be completed and its findings released before the Commonwealth and Territory Governments commit themselves to the construction of any new roads to or from Gungahlin; and
COMMENT

Supported. The timing of road works necessary to meet the needs of Gungahlin is the joint responsibility of the Commonwealth and ACT Governments, firstly in completing the Future Public Transport Options Study. The ACT Government is then responsible for developing detailed road proposals and having these considered under environmental legislation. The NCPA is responsible for considering the implications for the National Capital Plan and, if necessary and appropriate, proposing amendments to the Plan before works proceed. Finally, the ACT Government is responsible for implementation of the proposals, whether they be for a new technology rapid transport system or arterial roads.
RECOMMENDATION
(c) in the interim a reservation be made between Civic and Gungahlin to allow for the construction of a rapid transport system. (Paragraph 3.25)
COMMENT
Supported. The Commonwealth Government considers that there should be a reservation for a rapid transport system covering the entire ACT.
Policies of the National Capital Plan are:

6.3(b) A corridor between Civic, the town centres and major employment nodes, suitable for priority or segregated right-of-way for use by public transport services will be reserved against a possible future need to develop a system of inter town and express routes suitable for buses or other technologies as appropriate.
6.3(c) Transport strategies should promote the convenience and efficiency of public transport use.
RECOMMENDATION
3. The Committee recommends that:

(a) the Commonwealth and Territory Governments jointly and separately (where appropriate) develop and implement the measures described in paragraph 4.4—such as limiting employment growth in Civic—to limit the number of vehicles travelling between Gungahlin and Civic or other southern destinations; and

(b) the Commonwealth Government's long term strategy for office location be amended to give priority to the development of additional office space in Gungahlin as well as in Tuggeranong and Belconnen. (Paragraph 4.8)
COMMENT
Supported. Policies of the National Capital Plan are:

3.3(b) Land use and development projects shall not result in increased Commonwealth office employment in Civic, except within the context of a program agreed by the Authority or unless the increases are minor and within Commonwealth Departments or agencies already located in Civic and it can be clearly demonstrated that such increases are in the interests of functional efficiency.
3.3(c) Any Commonwealth Department or agency seeking to place additional employment in Civic shall consult the Authority.

3.3(d) Commonwealth employment will be encouraged to locate in town centres (other than Civic, Parkes, Barton and Russell). The Authority will also assist any Commonwealth efforts to encourage the private sector to invest in such projects.

3.3(e) Only key Commonwealth policy departments, with Commonwealth Government approval, may be located on National Land in Parkes and Barton within the limitations imposed by local and overall transport and environmental considerations.
3.3(f) The Authority will assist Commonwealth agencies to consider non-central locations as possible alternatives where town centre locations are not feasible or appropriate.
RECOMMENDATION
4. The Committee recommends that:
William Slim Drive between the Barton Highway and Ginninderra Drive be upgraded (Paragraph 4.24)
COMMENT
This is an ACT Government responsibility. However, the implications for the National Capital Plan of any proposed work would need to be considered.
RECOMMENDATION
5. The Committee recommends that:
(a) provision not be made in the National Capital Plan for a John Dedman East road; and
COMMENT

The government supports the current efforts to increase use of public transport and has made a contribution to the Future Public Transport Options for Canberra Study. The Government notes that the John Dedman East option cannot be built without amendment to the National Capital Plan. Future action will be assessed in the light of the outcomes of the Future Public Transport Options for Canberra Study.
RECOMMENDATION
(b) the Bruce Ridge—O'Connor Hills area be given legislative protection to preserve its ecological, recreational and educational values. (Paragraph 4.60)
COMMENT

This area is a Designated Area of the National Capital Plan and therefore has detailed conditions which apply to planning, design and development. As the land is Territory Land, only the ACT Government can give further legislative protection. More detailed recommendations will depend on the outcome of the current inquiry into Canberra's Open Space System being conducted by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Capital.
RECOMMENDATION
6. The Committee recommends that:
(a) a detailed environmental impact assessment be made of the John Dedman Community Option and John Dedman West alignments, addressing such issues as:
(i) the potential impact of each alignment on the Bruce Ridge and O'Connor Hills, and
(ii) the potential impact of the Community Option alignment on the amenity of facilities at the AIS for residents and other users; and
COMMENT
This is an ACT Government responsibility. However the Commonwealth Government would need to consider the implications for the National Capital Plan of any proposed work.
RECOMMENDATION

(b) in conjunction with the assessment, a broader study of the present and future parking and traffic management needs in the area of the AIS be conducted jointly by the ACT Planning Authority and the NCPA. (Paragraph 4.63)
COMMENT
This is an ACT Government responsibility. However, the Commonwealth Government would need to consider the implications for the National Capital Plan of any proposed work.
RECOMMENDATION
7. The Committee recommends that:
(a) provision be made in the National Capital Plan for a Majura Parkway;
COMMENT
Supported.
RECOMMENDATION
(b) a detailed alignment study be conducted to minimise any impact on existing leases in the Majura Valley, for example by following the line of the existing Majura Lane;
COMMENT
This is an ACT Government responsibility. However, the Commonwealth Government would need to consider the implications for the National Capital Plan of any proposed work.
RECOMMENDATION
(c) a detailed environmental impact assessment of the Parkway be made, addressing such issues as:
—the potential impact of the Parkway an animal movement corridors and how best to maintain those corridors; and
—the possible impact of increases in traffic levels on Northcott Drive and Fairbairn Avenue and the need to introduce or upgrade noise abatement measures; and
COMMENT
This is an ACT Government responsibility. However, the Commonwealth Government would need to consider the implications for the National Capital Plan of any proposal for works.
RECOMMENDATION
(d) the ACT Government investigate the immediate introduction of noise abatement measures along Fairbairn Avenue.
COMMENT
This is an ACT Government responsibility. However, the Commonwealth Government would need to consider the implications for the National Capital Plan of any proposal for works.
RECOMMENDATION
8. The Committee recommends that:

(a) Monash Drive not be constructed. However the road reservation should be retained in the National Capital Plan until it is clear that a severe disruption to the amenity of North Canberra can be avoided by the increased use of public transport and by the effective operation of the peripheral roads; and
COMMENT

Supported. The timing of road works necessary to meet the needs of Gungahlin is a joint responsibility of the Commonwealth and ACT Governments, firstly in completing the Future Public Transport Options Study. The ACT Government is then responsible for developing detailed road proposals and having these considered under environmental legislation. The NCPA is responsible for considering the implications for the National Capital Plan and, it necessary and appropriate, proposing amendments to the Plan before works proceed. Finally, the ACT Government is responsible for implementation of the proposals, whether they be for a new technology rapid transport system of arterial roads.
RECOMMENDATION
(b) the Mount Majura-Mount Ainslie area be given legislative protection to preserve its ecological, recreational and education values. (Paragraph 4.99)
COMMENT

This area is a Designated Area of the National Capital Plan and therefore has detailed conditions which apply to planning, design and development. As the land is Territory Land, only the ACT Government can give further legislative protection. More detailed recommendations will depend on the outcome of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Capital's Inquiry into Canberra's Open Space System. The location of a Majura Parkway would be subject to environmental impact assessment;
RECOMMENDATION
9. The Committee recommends that:

(a) the proposed extension to Ginninderra Drive not proceed but that, to minimise the level of through traffic in Lyneham and O'Connor, Mouat Street be widened and traffic management and calming techniques be introduced in the area:
COMMENT
Supported. The Commonwealth Government will seek an amendment to the National Capital Plan in accordance with the statutory process.
RECOMMENDATION

(b) the implementation of these measures not be deferred until the expected increase in traffic from Gungahlin occurs, but commence immediately so that the already high levels of through traffic are reduced; and
COMMENT
This is an ACT Government responsibility. However, the Commonwealth Government would need to consider the implications for the National Capital Plan of any proposed work.
RECOMMENDATION

(c) the ACT Planning Authority conduct a comprehensive study of all North Canberra suburbs to identify particular streets that warrant the introduction of traffic management and calming techniques. (Paragraph 4.105)
COMMENT
This is an ACT Government responsibility. However, the Commonwealth Government would need to consider the implications for the National Capital Plan of any proposed work.
RECOMMENDATION
10. The Committee recommends that:
(a) the joint NCPA and ACT Planning Authority study of the area south of Mitchell and between the Federal and Barton Highways commence immediately; and
COMMENT
Supported. The National Capital Plan has identified the need for this study.
RECOMMENDATION

(b) the study assess the usefulness of a highway link road and determine a road alignment which would effectively link the two highways with the Majura Valley corridor so as to encourage commercial and other through traffic to divert to the peripheral arterial roads and by-pass North Canberra. (Paragraph 4.110)
COMMENT
Supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the motion that has just been moved by Senator Robert Ray. Firstly, in some ways it is disappointing that it has taken so long to receive a response to the report entitled Gungahlin's Transport Links, which was tabled in May 1991. The Minister will be surprised, if he goes to the area, to find how Gungahlin has grown and become inhabited in the meantime. So the matter of transport links from Gungahlin to the older parts of Canberra has been, and remains, important. Particularly important are the links between Gungahlin and the Civic area. This issue came up again in an inquiry we held but have not yet reported on relating to construction on Vernon Circle around City Hill. Hopefully, that report will be able to be tabled in the Parliament once the Joint Committee on the National Capital has been re-established.

PARA.TAB: In recommendation No. 3 of the report we refer to limiting the number of vehicles travelling between Gungahlin and Civic or other southern destinations. I refer to that issue particularly because it did come up again—I think I was one of the members of the committee who raised it—when we looked at the matter of the type of construction that could reasonably be placed around Vernon Circle and City Hill. We were being asked to approve developments in that area while the answers to the questions about Gungahlin traffic getting to Civic and southern destinations have yet to be resolved. I mention it again here merely because it is still not resolved.

Perhaps the most outstanding thing about the Government's response to the report is the way that it highlights the linking between the responsibilities of the National Capital Planning Authority—that is, the Federal Government—and of the ACT Government in certain areas of Canberra. The extent to which this is referred to in the Government's response is accurate, and I am not challenging it. I merely refer to it in order to highlight the very great necessity to see that these two government bodies work most closely together. If they do not, the loser will surely be the national capital. We will never be able to encourage business to come here and people to invest here if these two planning authorities function in such a way as to make it too complicated and too costly to do so.

I am speaking about this issue this afternoon in order to highlight the necessity for the national capital plan and its influence on the territory to blend into and work well with the ACT plan. This envisages the two governments recognising their responsibilities not just to their own plans but to the people of Canberra in making sure that the plan works.

Throughout the document there are comments such as, `This is an ACT Government responsibility'. However, the Commonwealth Government would need to consider the implications for the national capital plan of any proposed work. That is correct, but it must also recognise the time it can take to work out things like that when anybody comes along with an idea that they wish to proceed with in this area.
I intend to speak only to recommendation No. 3 and recommendation No. 10 of the committee today. Recommendation No. 10 of the committee states:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the joint NCPA—
that is, the National Capital Planning Authority—
and ACT Planning Authority study of the area south of Mitchell and between the Federal and Barton Highways commence immediately . . . .
It then goes on to item (b). The response is that this recommendation is supported. The response then says:
The national capital plan has identified the need for this study.

This recommendation was made to this Parliament in May 1991. I would have hoped that much more had been done than appears to be implied in the Government's response. If the matter has gone no further than what is being said to the Senate today, I believe it is high time that it is given some priority. Because more houses are being occupied in Gungahlin every day, the links to the city are very important for those who will be affected by them—certainly those in the northern suburbs of Canberra.

PARA.TAB: We have referred to the other areas of Monash Drive and the links around the other side of Canberra. Those links are important whether John Dedman East road proceeds or not. It was our view that it should not. I say to both the Federal and ACT governments, through their planning authorities, that some of these matters need to proceed with slightly more haste than appears to be the case from the way that this response has been worded. I seek leave to continue my remarks later because I am not certain whether Senator Macdonald wishes to speak. He may wish to do so on another occasion.
Leave granted; debated adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the Republic of Fiji

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Republic of Fiji. I have pleasure in presenting this brief report by a delegation of the Australian Parliament to the republic of Fiji last October. The report, which was agreed to last December, has been delayed due to the pressure of parliamentary business last year and the election this year.

PARA.TAB: The visit to Fiji, led by Stephen Martin in his then role as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, accompanied by Peter Fisher, the former National Party member for Mallee, Phil Bergin, the then Sergeant-at-Arms, Jack Heath, from Stephen Martin's staff, and myself was very short, spanning only four days, although in the three days prior to the visit we had also participated as delegates and observers in the South Pacific conference. However, although the visit was short, it was important in that it was the first official visit of a parliamentary delegation to the new Parliament, and represented another stage in the normalisation of relations between Fiji and Australia following the coups some years earlier.

The report summarises the four days the delegation spent in Fiji. The delegation met with the Prime Minister, Sitiveni Rabuka, the Deputy Prime Minister, Filipe Bole, and the presiding officers of the Parliament and the leaders of the Opposition parties, Mr Jai Ram Reddy of the National Federation Party and Mahendra Chaudrey of the Fijian Labour Party. We were also able to have discussions with a number of business people, Fijian and Australians, who are running businesses in Fiji, both in the capital, Suva, and the industrial city of Ba on the north-west coast of the island of Viti Levu.

During these visits we learned of some of the difficulties experienced in Australian-Fijian business relations. There are difficulties with the South Pacific regional trade agreement—or SPARTECA, as it is known—and particularly with the rules of origin of that treaty. There are difficulties in developing standards. I believe that this is an area where direct and specific aid could be given by Australia which would be very useful to Fiji. There are also difficulties for Fijian business people in obtaining visas when making short business visits to Australia.

On our return these problems were conveyed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). Important questions of racial tension, and constitutional reform flowing from that, were raised by the delegation. We were pleased to receive an assurance from the Prime Minister of Fiji that he would make a statement to the Parliament on the timetable for the review of the constitution during the next session of Parliament. I note that this statement has since been made and that there does appear to be a genuine desire to tackle some of the difficult representational and constitutional problems which have been the cause of Fiji's recent difficulties.

I would like to thank the Presiding Officers of the Parliament of Fiji on behalf of the delegation for arranging a comprehensive and interesting program for our short visit. Thanks are also directed to the Australian Embassy staff, in particular the Ambassador, Mr Trotter, and his wife, and Doug Foskett, one of the embassy staff, who travelled with us. Finally, I want to thank all of those Fijians whose warmth and frankness made our short visit so rewarding.

Fiji has undergone some dramatic changes in recent times, yet it continues to prosper. It is, and will continue to be, a significant influence in the Pacific. It is important that Australia maintain good relations with it and that we try to assist the Fijian people in addressing some of their difficult problems. Visits such as this can only assist in this process.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Delegations to Republic of Korea and Pakistan and to Malaysia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the reports of the Australian parliamentary delegations to the Republic of Korea and Pakistan, between 10 and 23 June 1992, and to Malaysia, between 24 June and 2 July 1992. As the only member of the delegation from the Senate who participated in the official parliamentary delegation to the Republic of Korea and Pakistan and to Malaysia, it falls to me to present and speak to the reports. I have great pleasure in doing so.

PARA.TAB: It was a three-week delegation and the membership differed for each of the reports. I will speak first to the parliamentary delegation to the Republic of Korea and Pakistan and then later on the delegation to Malaysia. The leader was Mr Lloyd O'Neil, the former honourable member for Grey, South Australia, and the deputy leader was Mr David Cowan, the former honourable member for Lyne, New South Wales, from the National Party of Australia.

It was an extremely varied and busy visit to both Korea and Pakistan. I should note that, as this was a year ago, considerable changes have occurred in both those countries since the time that we were there. While we were in Korea we were able to make some very significant visits—two examples being to the demilitarised zone and to the Pohang Iron and Steel Corporation.

Through its discussions and visit to the demilitarised zone, the delegation gained some appreciation of the strength of feeling associated with the question of reunification. The fact that an estimated one-quarter of the population of South Korea are separated from relatives in North Korea indicates something of the potency of that issue.

It was concerning to hear of practices not directed towards making peace and working for positive relations. We heard of past instances of rivalries and ill-feeling between the two parties and I report with regret an incident which occurred in the demilitarised zone in early May, involving North Korean soldiers firing two bullets at a South Korean guard post. However, it appears the shooting was triggered accidentally, and fortunately does not seem to have intensified any hostility.

In relation to the visit to the Pohang Iron and Steel Corporation, we noted an impressive degree of monitoring of environmental effects of the industry in the area. POSCO's physical operations were impressive not only in scale but also in their standard of technical efficiency. The delegation was impressed by these visits and wishes to thank all the people associated with the program within Korea and Pakistan. I seek leave to incorporate the names of people we wish to thank who assisted the delegation.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Pakistan I was privileged to be able to visit a women's prison. We received cooperation to be able to go to many other places of interest and gain insight into what was happening there. One of the highlights of the visit for me was the opportunity to meet with Madam Benazir Bhutto. As people may be aware, there was some unrest and, since that time, there has been further disturbance in Pakistan politically, with elections scheduled for 14 July. As I mentioned before, I want to thank the staff of the High Commission and the parliamentary officials who assisted us very ably in showing us the country and the operations of their parliaments.

PARA.TAB: Finally, in relation to the parliamentary delegation to Malaysia, which occurred on 24 June to 2 July, the delegation leader was Mr Laurie Brereton, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith. It was a very important time for establishing better relationships between Australia and Malaysia. On several occasions mention was made that at that time there had been no parliamentary visits from Malaysia to Australia for four years.

Members of the delegation were very happy that, following our invitation for a parliamentary delegation to visit Australia, the invitation was taken up and the Malaysian delegation visited Australia from 13 to 20 September 1992. One regret was that we did not see more of Malaysia. We felt that the next Australian delegation should include the eastern side of the Malaysian peninsula and Sabah and/or Sarawak in its schedule.

Australia's relationship with Malaysia is one of its strongest in the Asian region. Defence and educational ties continue to be the core elements of the diverse and substantial partnership between the two countries. The delegation was repeatedly assured that these were not affected by the periodic strains in bilateral relations experienced during recent years.

Other elements of the Australia-Malaysia relationship include trade and investment, tourism, control of narcotics and refugee resettlement. It was noted, too, that Penang and Adelaide have a sister city arrangement. There was some mention of the media irritants which had been working against the relationship between the two countries, but it was expressed that these were seen to be isolated incidents and problems were being overcome with the greater level of interaction.

A sign of the positive state of relations between Australia and Malaysia was the high level of appointments afforded to the delegation. In addition to meeting with the President of the Senate, there were meetings with the Ministers for foreign affairs, defence, justice and finance. The foreign affairs Minister of Malaysia suggested that relations could be further enhanced if parliamentarians from both countries sought to make contact with each other at meetings of the Inter-Parliamentary Union and the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and on other similar occasions. The delegation considers this a very worthwhile suggestion and members would urge their parliamentary colleagues to avail themselves of any such opportunities.

I take this point to note that we have actually received an invitation to the East Asia and Pacific Parliamentarians' Conference on Environment and Development, which will be held from 7 to 8 June in Seoul, from Mr Park Jun Byung, President of the Korean National Assembly's Korean Parliamentary League. I should have referred to this when I was speaking on the Korean delegation, but it is also an example of the point that the Malaysian foreign Minister made. It represents the kind of cooperation that all countries welcomed. An Aboriginal art exhibition was a highlight of the Malaysian visit and we congratulate all those who were associated with the preparation and presentation of it.

During our stay I visited the prison in which Michael McAuliffe, an Australian citizen who is currently facing the death penalty in Malaysia, is being held. We were able to point out that both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) have appealed for clemency for Mr McAuliffe, and the delegation made a similar appeal. I was grateful to be allowed the visit with Mr McAuliffe and gave him an assurance of Australia's concern regarding his well being and of our continuing interest in his situation.

Mr McAuliffe has been in custody for seven years and is pleased to be undergoing a process of review by the Penang pardons board, because it enables him to be in a better situation within the prison. He is therefore in no rush for those pardon proceedings to conclude. While we may wish that he be granted clemency and are concerned that a citizen is facing the death penalty, which is not legal in our country, it may not necessarily be in his interests to try to speed up that process of appeal. I therefore simply express our renewed concern that one of our citizens is facing that penalty in a strange land.

I conclude my remarks by urging honourable senators to read the report. It was a very satisfactory experience. I gratefully acknowledge all those people in Malaysia who assisted with the organisation and conduct of that successful visit, whose names have been listed earlier. In particular, I make note of the staff of the Malaysian Parliament and the Australian High Commissioner, His Excellency Mr Frank Murray, and his staff.

I also acknowledge the efforts of those people in Australia who assisted with the organisation of all three visits and provided briefing materials and oral briefings and staff of the Department of the Parliamentary Library; officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; members of the Parliamentary Relations Office; and employees of Qantas. DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: National Report on Schooling in Australia

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Tierney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the national report on schooling is to inform the Australian people of the education that was provided during 1991 to over three million students in 10,000 schools across the eight States and Territories of Australia. The report is an excellent document which contains valuable information relating to the various school systems in Australia. It is the issue of the devolution of powers and responsibilities from State bureaucracies to the individual schools, outlined in this report, which I particularly wish to address today.

PARA.TAB: I specifically wish to focus upon the example of the excellent education system in my home State of New South Wales, presided over by the Hon. Virginia Chadwick MLC. The New South Wales government school system adopted nine priorities in 1991, and these priorities formed the basis for planning at all levels. The first of these priorities was to implement the main strategies and recommendations of the Scott report to ensure that schools, not the central bureaucracy, are the focus of educational services. Additionally, the New South Wales system sought to promote and recognise excellence and choice. Therefore, I believe that New South Wales stands as an example for the other States to follow. The current Director-General of Education in New South Wales, Dr Ken Boston, came from South Australia to New South Wales because he was attracted by the exciting educational reform program in our State.

The New South Wales coalition Government has various initiatives relating to the goals of promoting and recognising excellence. Among these are basic skill testing; assessment and reporting of student progress; dezoning of schools; and the creation of selective high schools, senior high schools, technology high schools and centres of excellence within many other high schools. As a result of these initiatives, parents have a greater opportunity to fulfil their aspirations for their family by sending their children to schools which much better match their children's needs. Indeed, next year we are planning to move my youngest daughter, Marguerite, from a private school to the State Broadmeadow High School for the Performing Arts because we believe the curriculum at that school best meets her needs and aspirations.

I have told this story to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that parents have great concern about the quality of their children's education and are effective monitors of children's progress if provided with the opportunity to do so. All the research shows that if parents and teachers work in a cooperative relationship, educational outcomes are greatly improved. That is why the New South Wales education system includes in its nine policy principles the need to encourage the involvement of parents in the community more closely in school decision making. Australia's best education system, that of New South Wales, states as a goal the need to provide curriculum and educational experience relevant to the long-term needs of students and the community. I recommend this report to the Senate, as it provides the opportunity for those from other States and anyone else interested in education to review the excellent policies being implemented in New South Wales, and hopefully adopt them for their own State education systems.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I congratulate you on occupying, I think for the first time, the important seat in which you are now sitting. When I spoke before on this report I made some general comments. I congratulated ATSIC for much of the good work it had performed, whilst indicating that there is always room for improvement in the way it operates—the same as there is always room for improvement in the way we all operate.

PARA.TAB: When my time expired, I was raising a note of warning to the Government and the commission. It related to a vote in the electorate of Herbert, based in Townsville, where an independent candidate, who ran on what I think most people would loosely describe as an anti-Aboriginal, anti-migrant, anti-welfare campaign, received some 14 per cent of the vote. That is a very substantial figure for an independent candidate and I might add that he polled third after the candidates for the Labor and Liberal parties.

The warning I give to the Government and to ATSIC is that they really must explain very carefully the way they effect their programs for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. There is a perception, which is reflected in that vote in the electorate of Herbert, that a lot of the money that is spent is wrongly spent. It has brought about a considerable hardening of attitude amongst many Australians who believe that they are being unfairly treated by comparison with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. It is a very complex question. I am not for a moment saying that I agree with or support that proposal; I am simply warning that there is that feeling around. It behoves the Government and ATSIC to more clearly define their programs and outline where the money is going.

I am sure that 100 per cent of Australians would support the spending of money on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and any disadvantaged group in the areas of health, education and housing—I do not think anyone would argue about that—but there are many programs which people perceive as not being in the best interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, and as really becoming an absolute waste of money and a wrong direction for the spending of money.

There is a real problem with alcoholism in Aboriginal communities. That problem is a very debilitating one for the Aboriginal and, to a lesser extent, Torres Strait Islander races and it really needs to be addressed by the Government. But there is an enormous number of other programs which people cannot understand the benefit of and which I do think the Government and ATSIC should look at very carefully to ensure that money is not being wrongly directed in those areas and that all Australians are seen to be receiving a fair go.

I do not want to elaborate any more on that except to raise the warning, and I do hope that the Government and ATSIC will become aware of it. I am sure they will also be analysing the vote of that particular candidate. I hope they will adopt strategies which will make all Australians understand the need for proper assistance for Aboriginal, Torres Strait Islander and all other disadvantaged people.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Ian Macdonald:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, as a Queenslander you would be aware, as I am, of the concern of many Queenslanders when it comes to the disposal of toxic and radioactive wastes. There are very great concerns at Gurulmundi, outside Miles, where a waste dump is going in, in the face of very strong opposition from a section of the community. There is also in the Brisbane valley around Esk a very great concern that a radioactive waste depository may be established there shortly. There are concerns in various parts of Queensland—in Gladstone, Rockhampton, Townsville, Mt Isa and elsewhere—that there may be plans by the Queensland Government to establish toxic or radioactive waste dumps in those areas.

PARA.TAB: I would ask the Federal Government to indicate to me—in fact, I have some questions on notice to the Government—just what sort of role the Federal environment department is playing in investigating, reporting on and, if necessary, doing something about those dumps. There is a lot of scientific evidence one way and another in the case of the Gurulmundi site and, whilst governments have to make decisions on the balance of reports, there are some very concerning scientific reports on the effect that the siting of that dump at Gurulmundi may have on the environment and amenity of the surrounding area. That does not relate directly to this report but it is, of course, indirectly related.

In looking at this report, I simply note that permits were granted for the export of hazardous wastes for the periods August 1991 to February 1992, February 1992 to August 1992, and so on—for a considerable period of time. Those permits were for exporting wastes principally to the United Kingdom—Ellesmere Port, Fawley and Pontypool. Apparently, on 5 May the Basel convention came into force and because the United Kingdom was not yet a party to it, under article 4.5 of the convention Australia was unable to export hazardous waste beyond 5 May 1992 to the United Kingdom for destruction. Permits that had been issued beyond that date were varied to suspend export of waste to the United Kingdom on 5 May.

I wonder—the report does not say and possibly someone from the Government might be able to indicate to me—what happened to all the hazardous waste that was intended to be exported and for which permits had been granted and which are now no longer available. There do not seem to be permits granted for export to any other destination and I wonder whether that means we are now stockpiling in Australia hazardous waste which apparently we used to be able to export. It is an interesting question and I would hope that someone in the Government might at some time be able to provide me with an answer to it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the 1991-92 annual report for the Australian National Maritime Museum—an annual report which is very late. I speak with some regret, as a great fan of the national maritime museum and as a foundation member of it; but that emotional support for the museum does not prevent me from complaining about the fact that this report is excessively late. The audit office only signed its report on 15 March 1993.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that when an auditor's report is so late—nine months after the completion of the financial year, and well beyond the guidelines for government instrumentalities—there should be a reason included in the report for the delay. There is no such reason and I think there ought to be. I do not know whether the audit office plans to include in its latest publications a statement about why this audit took so long, but there certainly should be some statement somewhere about why it took so long.

I understand that the draft report, apart from the Auditor-General's report, was ready a long time ago. One cannot blame anyone else in the chamber, by the look of things, because that report was conveyed reasonably speedily to this Parliament on the resumption of sittings after the election.

I do note one thing in the audit report: the museum has not applied the recoverable amount test for valuation of non-current assets, and the auditor agrees with that. There is no doubt that it is impossible, basically, to value a museum's collection. For that reason, I think it only sensible that the auditor has gone away from the normal structure.

There are a couple of other points I want to make. The report, in a financial sense, is disappointing—apart from the late auditing—in that admissions have nowhere near approached the attendance figures that had been hoped for. As a result, revenues are substantially down on what had been hoped for. As the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Museum is a popular venue for overseas dignitaries and international tourists. Over 200,000 visitors have paid to inspect the Museum—
in the year to last June. The report goes on:

However, entry takings have fallen short of projections, as the imposition of entry charges by Sydney museums which were traditionally free has encountered public resistance, the recession has discouraged discretionary spending, while new entrants have increased the competition for the cultural and leisure dollar. In this market, a bigger advertising budget is essential to compete for visitors with State and private attractions.

Unfortunately, this situation has continued into the current financial year, as the Advance to the Minister for Finance has shown in recent times and as became evident in the Senate estimates committee process when additional appropriation was required to pay the bills. This raises an interesting question because, as this report points out:
Development of new programs—
at the museum—
particularly exhibitions—
and, by the way, the way to attract people is to have new exhibitions and develop new programs—

is hampered by lack of discretionary funding. For instance, 35% of the Government Appropriation disappeared on renting premises, including $3.4 million for the Museum building at Darling Harbour. Rent will be even higher in a full year.

In a sense, a great proportion of the Government's allocation of around $11 million last year went to pay itself rent. So the capacity for this outstanding museum to really increase its activities sufficiently to attract lots of people to it, particularly by way of publicity, promotion and advertising, is regrettably limited.

PARA.TAB: The museum depends heavily on volunteers to provide support for it. If those volunteers were not there, the shortfall would be even larger and the pressure on the public purse even greater. I certainly want to commend those volunteers for all the work they do along with, of course, the very dedicated staff and board of the museum. But I do ask that they get their annual report out a lot quicker next year, and I hope we will see evidence of a clear program, some kind of pattern, to ensure that the museum is adequately funded.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Competency Based Approaches to University Selection and Credit Transfer

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, may I add my congratulations to the elevation of your good self to the position of Acting Deputy President. Certainly those of us on our side look forward to your deliberations and rulings with some interest.

PARA.TAB: I address my remarks this afternoon to the report entitled Competency Based Approaches to University Selection and Credit Transfer, the advice from NBEET. In so doing, I note that a couple of days ago the Government tabled 10 NBEET reports all in one go. I was very concerned about that tabling in one hit, given that some of those advices were extremely important. This particular advice, for example, is a major issue doing the rounds at universities. Certainly in relation to the Government's training agenda, it is vitally important that we get this right. That the Government can simply table this advice along with nine others, in my view, makes a mockery of the scrutiny element involved in the parliamentary process.

It is extremely difficult for us to read all these advices, take in their content and make sensible comment about them when 10 are tabled in one go and we have only five minutes to address the very important questions that are involved. This issue of competency-based training is one of them. I signal here that the Democrats will be raising this issue at the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, and this whole question of how we can more effectively scrutinise education policy.

It has been my experience over the last 18 months that this Parliament has very little opportunity to examine and comment on in detail education policy as developed by this Labor Government. I believe that is a very serious development because it means that policy and actions are developed by bureaucrats and sanctioned by Ministers, and we are left to simply examine the crumbs and really do not have much opportunity for input.

I think the Government needs to remember that there are those of us on the other side who do have some experience and expertise, having come from the area, and would certainly be very keen to ensure that the Government's programs receive more scrutiny. It seems to me that NBEET, the body whose 10 reports we are examining this afternoon, has an enormously important role in formulating, and advising the Government on policy; and yet there is very little effective scrutiny of how NBEET operates and the role that it plays.

With those remarks, I turn now to this very important report which, essentially, arises out of issues that were canvassed in the Finn report and the Mayer report. Both of these reports, related to competency-based training and restructuring of our TAFE sector, have been very industry driven—driven by the needs of industry rather than by what constitutes a broad-based education and how a broad-based general education can deliver to Australia the kinds of skills it needs to catapult it into the international economy.

I suspect that, after much soul searching in the next five years as to the direction that training policy has taken in this country, we will see the Government do a U-turn and recognise that at this time—that is, 1992-93—far too much emphasis in training policy has been put on the needs of industry at the expense of a general broad-based education.

`Competency' is a word that is bandied around very broadly in education circles. What I have discovered in my work is that it means many things to different people. It is certainly a question that needs to be ironed out. I do not know whether this NBEET advice has actually seriously dealt with that question. The universities have very serious concerns about the application of key competencies to a university degree. That is an issue that this Government must really comes to grips with. It has not done so, and NBEET has not done so in this report.

We partly agree that the Higher Education Council must seek to continue to reconcile the issues of competency and credit transfer. It has tried to address that in this report. I hope that this will be a starting point for debate. It is an issue that we will continue to scrutinise in this Parliament.
Debate (on motion by Senator Bjelke-Petersen) adjourned.

We believe the subject of the motion to be of great importance to the Australian people. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate, mindful of its role to protect the rights of the States and all individuals—
(a)reaffirms its responsibility as the permanent house of review in the democratic structure of the Commonwealth of Australia;
(b)regrets the failure of the Queensland Premier (Mr Goss) to appreciate the importance of upper houses in restraining executive power;
(c)condemns Mr Goss for his ill-informed campaign to abolish upper houses; and
(d)expresses its concern that the advocacy of Mr Goss for the abolition of upper houses is part of the wider agenda of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for abolition of the States and the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The agenda of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is a matter of concern to many Australians. One suspects that, despite his protestations that he is concerned with the so-called minimalist conversion to the republic, he has in mind something much greater. An article appeared in the Bulletin recently written by David O'Reilly, who I think has good connections within the Labor Party. He put it in these terms:
. . . the prime minister has achieved his life-long political dream of winning sufficient unfettered political power to remake the nation according to his own vision.

That is of concern to us and to so many Australians. The core of this debate today specifically is the intervention yesterday by the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss, when he, in effect, called for the abolition of upper houses. The upper house of Queensland has gone, but the other States and our federal system have the benefit of upper houses not only as houses of review but also as a restraint on the power of the executive.

PARA.TAB: If one reflects very briefly on what power there would be within this Parliament to restrain Mr Keating if the Senate did not exist, one would realise very quickly that there would be very little. Mr Acting Deputy President, do you realise that this week—only the second week into the parliamentary session—the House of Representatives is already operating under a guillotine? So, members of the House of Representatives are not given proper opportunity to debate legislation.

That is the level of legislative accountability that the House of Representatives has in our constitutional structure. That is the very limited opportunity that is given to members elected to the lower house in our federal structure to meet their responsibility of reviewing legislation put to them by the government. That means that the only chamber that can properly fulfil that role is the upper house in our constitutional structure, the Senate.

It is not only a matter the Government's legislative program—I think the Government has dumped on the House of Representatives something like 70 Bills to debate in the course of a few days this week under the guillotine that it has imposed. It is also a matter of financial accountability. It is this chamber, the upper house of the Parliament of Australia, which really fulfils the responsibility of accountability, of ensuring that the elected government in this country is accountable to the people through the parliamentary process. We do that through our estimates procedure. We used to do it through comprehensive debate in the Committee of the Whole in this place until the Government and the Australian Democrats conspired this week to cut out that process. We will nevertheless continue as best we are able to ensure that in financial matters the Government is responsible to the Australian people through the proper functioning of this chamber. It is this chamber and that responsibility that our Prime Minister, Mr Keating, would wish to abolish.

We heard yesterday that one of the few remaining State Labor Premiers in this country also would wish to see the Senate abolished. The attitude of the Prime Minister to the Australian Senate is well-known. We had the debate last year on his abusive comments when he referred to this chamber as `unrepresentative swill'. He made those offensive comments because he found that the Senate was a restraint upon his executive power, and he resorted to such abusive language. That followed his revelation to students of De La Salle college only a few days before, on 11 September of last year, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We shouldn't have a Senate, basically. It's an impediment to the smooth operation of the parliamentary system.

In other words, `We shouldn't have a Senate, basically. It's an impediment to the way in which I, Mr Keating, wish to govern this country'. That is why the people of Australia have constantly supported the retention of the Australian Senate. They have done it because they have become concerned about the over-centralisation of power and, in this instance, using again the words of Mr O'Reilly, the almost unfettered power of the Australian Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in terms of the government that has just been elected in this country.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister wants to abolish the Australian Senate. He wants to remove the restraint that that has on his executive power. We learnt yesterday that Mr Goss, the Premier of Queensland, is of the same mind. Mr Goss dresses it up by saying that he wants the Senate abolished because it no longer represents the States. I know the history of the Australian Senate and the fact that political parties have exercised greater power as the years have gone by. In fact, if a Labor senator got out of line he or she would be expelled. Nevertheless, basically senators in this place are conscious of their responsibilities to their States, do represent their States and put forward matters that are of particular concern to their States. So that is hardly an excuse for wishing to abolish the Senate. Therefore, one can only come back to the same sentiment that was expressed by the Prime Minister, that for the moment it is basically a nuisance to him. That is why he no longer wishes it to exist.

Therefore, we know one part of the Prime Minister's wider agenda of constitutional reform. He wants a republic. He wants to abolish the position of the Governor-General. He also wants to have major constitutional reform of the principal structures of the parliamentary system in this country—that is, he wants to abolish the Senate.

We also wonder about an even wider agenda of the Prime Minister. His attitude to the Australian flag, for example, is well known. Last year we had the humiliating experience of his going to Jakarta and announcing to Asia that it was his intention to get rid of the Australian flag. He said that he found the flag somewhat un-Australian because it had the Union Jack as part of it. He went on to make a similar statement in Papua New Guinea immediately after his trip to Indonesia.

The Prime Minister has not hesitated from saying it since. He promised so many that we will soon have a new flag and that he would be causing a submission to be brought to Cabinet. In fact, he wishes to abolish from our structures and our traditions anything that might have some British connotation. That is part of his agenda—abolish the States and abolish the flag. One wonders what the next step after that will be. We hear from other Labor spokesmen that the next step is, in fact, to abolish the States themselves because they are also an impediment to centralised control, to centralised power.

What we have sought to do, by bringing this debate to the Senate for its attention today, is to remind the Australian Government that we will fight the attempts by the Prime Minister to gain unfettered control of our parliamentary system. We will commit ourselves to the Australian people to ensure that the Prime Minister will not be able to achieve constitutional reform that removes the traditional safeguards on executive power. We will fight to maintain symbols, such as the flag, that are so important to many Australians. We will fight to maintain a system that shares power between the States and the central authority, the Commonwealth of Australia, because within that there is a greater safeguard against abuse of power. That is the message that we wanted to bring to the Senate today, in the terms of the notice of motion given by Senator Boswell yesterday. That is the reason why I so proudly stand here today and support Senator Boswell by moving that motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I gave notice of this motion on behalf of Senator Hill and on my own behalf. I did so in response to the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss, who yesterday launched what I believe was a direct assault on the Senate. He told the press:

SPEECH.PARA: We might as well abolish the Senate, because it no longer represents the States.

He also said at a later press conference that getting rid of upper houses, including the Senate, was `a good place to start' in that it would get rid of a few politicians. That is a very populist sort of statement from a Premier who, I believe, has been down to Canberra on very few occasions.
