TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As there are no senators to speak on committee reports, I move:

PARA.TAB: That consideration of committee reports and Government responses be not proceeded with this day.

SPEECH.PARA: I propose that the Senate deal with procedural matters, including the composition and allocation of departments to standing committees, at this stage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 12 May, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That Standing Order 25 be amended as follows:
Paragraph (2), omit the following:

PROCTEXT.PARA: "(e)The Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade;
(f)The Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology;
(g)The Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs;
(i)The Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.
(f)The Standing Committee on Legal, Constitutional and External Affairs;
upon which Senator Teague moved by way of amendment:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after ``That'', substitute:
``standing order 25 be amended as follows:
`Paragraph (2), omit:
"(f)The Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology; and
"(i)The Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.",
substitute:
"(f)The Standing on Industrial Development;".'.".

TALK.START.PARA: —During my previous contribution to this motion I emphasised the matters that Senator Teague had raised on the absolute necessity to retain the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I highlighted many aspects of Senator Teague's speech and canvassed the very good work that that particular committee had been doing over a long period of time. I mentioned that in the last years the inquiries with which I have been involved have certainly been important and have led the way.

PARA.TAB: I then referred to the other committee that is about to be abolished; that is, the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I made the comment that it was rather interesting that I was on both of the committees that were about to be abolished, and hoped that it did not have anything to do with me.

I hope that the committee on foreign affairs, defence and trade can be retained. I understand that Senator Teague has been talking with the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats to see whether there is some way in which the matter can be resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's disgraceful.

—I thank Senator Knowles. I had made the point that the proposal to reduce the number of committees is absolutely disgraceful. I did say some unkind words about the Democrats, but in view of recent negotiations, I will not repeat those just at this moment.

PARA.TAB: The committee on transport, communications and infrastructure is also very important. I was involved in some of its inquiries whilst I was a member. In particular, I referred to the inquiry into the very fast train proposal, and specifically mentioned the fine work that my colleague Senator Margaret Reid had done during that inquiry. Just before the adjournment of the debate I was talking about the inquiry into satellite launching facilities within Australia. I indicated that it had been a very significant inquiry and certainly fully canvassed the satellite launching proposals.

One of the great things about these committees is that their inquiries—some of which are quite technical—widen the knowledge and experience of all senators. I had a political interest in the space base and its location in north Queensland. Having become involved in that inquiry, it was very interesting to understand all the ramifications and great benefits to the Australian economy from the space industry that we have had for many years.

This committee was able to travel to the proposed site for the space base in North Queensland which is at Temple Bay. We were able to speak with Aboriginal and environmental groups about the situation of that particular location. We were also able to visit Woomera and see what is now left of what was obviously a leading edge in space technology in the 1950s and possibly the 1960s. It was at that time in the inquiry that I and other senators became aware of the very significant role that Australia played in the past in space technology.

This was a particularly important inquiry. The committee reported to the Government and in turn the Government responded. I hope this inquiry will provide a lot of information when these sorts of matters are discussed in the future.

The committee on transport, communications and infrastructure then took on the very important role of looking at heavy vehicle charges. Mr Deputy President, as a Queenslander, you would be aware of the huge importance that the more diverse States such as Queensland and Western Australia place upon road transport. Matters relating to the charges that are affixed to heavy transports are very important to us.

The committee travelled the length and breadth of Australia. We went to Meekatharra, which is in Western Australian, and many parts of Queensland and took evidence from a wide range of groups interested in heavy vehicle charges. We were able to get a real understanding of the issues involved.

It became fairly obviously that some members of the Labor Party on that committee were not too happy with some of the results we were getting because they were contrary to Labor Party policy. The committee found an enormous acceptance of the Liberal Party and National Party proposals to abolish fuel tax. That, if nothing else, came through clearly as a result of the inquiries we made and the people we talked to. Before the election was called, the committee's report on heavy road vehicle charges was presented to and dealt with by the Parliament, I might say fairly perfunctorily by members of the Government who were a bit embarrassed by some of the aspects of the report.

As we approached the end of the year the committee on transport, communications and infrastructure determined that it should inquire into both government supplied and voluntary agency supplied emergency services around Australia. That inquiry has not yet commenced but the members of the committee have, as I recall, settled the terms of reference for that inquiry. It would have been a major inquiry into matters of very great significance. Certainly in my State of Queensland where emergency services are often called upon in times of calamity resulting from cyclones—which are prevalent in North Queensland, the Northern Territory and the north-west of Western Australia—floods and bushfires that regrettably occur, these matters are considered to be important. All these matters were to be investigated by this committee.

I do not know what will happen to that inquiry if the committee is not to continue. If that inquiry does not proceed it will deprive the Australian people of an in depth look at these emergency services and what reforms can be introduced. I suppose the Government will say that all of those inquiries will proceed and if the number of committees is reduced then the transport, communications and infrastructure inquiry will still not disappear. It will be incorporated into another committee.

One does not need to be a genius to work out that if we lump a committee with an enormous number of departments and areas to look at with another committee it then diminishes very greatly the time that combined committee will have to look into those particular matters. There was one proposal that the transport, communications and infrastructure committee could be lumped in with the industry, technology and commerce committee. That could be said to make sense. But it puts an enormous work load on the combined committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —It'll handle it easily.
—It may do, Senator Burns. I do not think Senator Burns is on that committee. I think he is on the foreign affairs, defence and trade committee.
—Absolutely—an important member.

PARA.TAB: Senator IAN MACDONALD—I was about to say that Senator Burns is a very important member of that committee. The industry, technology and commerce committee—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am on that too.

—I was not aware that Senator Burns was on that committee. If by chance the transport, communications and infrastructure committee were lumped with that committee, then it would mean an enormous workload for the committee. Notwithstanding that Senator Burns may be on that committee, there is only a certain amount of time that he can put into that committee and other committees in which he is involved. It would be very unfortunate if such circumstances were to occur.
—Are you continuing, Senator Macdonald?

—I am confirming with my colleague how important it is not to have a committee that is overburdened. I hope the Government will leave the number of committees at nine. The Opposition understands that the Labor Party has lost seats in the Senate and therefore will not have the same number of personnel available to staff the committees, but it is not really a question—(Quorum formed).

PARA.TAB: I was about to conclude because I know a number of my colleagues are very anxious to participate in this debate. I simply conclude with the plea that the number of committees remain at nine; that the Government understand that this chamber cannot properly scrutinise government legislation and all the other inquiries that need to be looked at by these committees with fewer than the current number. I urge the Government and my friends in the Australian Democrats to very seriously consider any reduction at all. If there is to be any reduction, I urge that it be minimal—say, perhaps removing one committee. I know my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne is anxious to participate in this debate, so I conclude with those remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It would be an understatement to say that there is a little confusion around the place tonight, but the situation is being made more awkward by those honourable senators who are standing and not taking their seats.

—In the two minutes in which I am going to speak I hope I can add to that confusion so that we are all of equal status. I rise to support the views articulated in a persuasive way by Senator Macdonald that the number of Senate standing committees ought to be nine.
—Why not make it 57 so that we can get on with other things?

—It is interesting to observe, through Senator Schacht, the view of the Labor Party that the essence is to get the Government's program but not to have it scrutinised. If there are competing factors in terms of those twin objectives, the casualty is always proper scrutiny of government legislation and government conduct. I recommend to Senator Schacht for excellent reading—
—You are sounding like a permanent Opposition, Noel.

—Considering the period I have been here, I could be excused if that were the case. I recommend to Senator Schacht a reading of the findings and recommendations of the Western Australian royal commission into the conduct of government which clearly demonstrated that it was the gross failure of the parliamentary—
—You had the numbers in the Legislative Council to do something about it and you didn't.
—If Senator Schacht wants to ask me privately about that, I will be only too happy to accommodate him.
—Order! I would remind the Minister and Senator Crichton-Browne that it is Thursday night and it could be a long one.

—That royal commission's findings set out in graphic terms the enormous price that society has paid for there not being a proper scrutiny of government conduct, of government legislation. Given that there are 76 senators in this chamber, it is not unreasonable for us to have nine standing committees. In fact, there is a compelling reason to have 10. But the ultimate barrier to our having any given number of committees is the capacity of the Government to man them.
—To staff them maybe?

—Well, Senator Kernot will know that I have long held the passionate view that the appropriations for the Department of the Senate ought not to be fettered by the constraints or the financial circumstances—
—You want fiscal irresponsibility, do you?

—To suggest that the proper funding of the Senate in any way is fiscal irresponsibility is again a graphic example of the Government's total disregard for proper scrutiny by the Parliament. Ten committees is not a large amount. There are 76 senators. I understand and recognise that the Government has increased its ministry to 10 in the Senate.
—And it has lost two seats.

—And it has lost two seats. So its capacity to man these committees is reduced. If it had appointed the 10 Ministers on merit, one would have some difficulty putting forward the proposition that there ought not to be a limit, but because the baubles are handed out by an indulgent Prime Minister—
—If it is merit, why are you where you are?
—Order on my right!

—I think I fulfil the position I hold very admirably, and I am still in my apprenticeship. The truth of the matter and the reality is that it is not a question of funding. Nobody has sensibly argued that the Senate ought not to have the capacity to scrutinise legislation, that there ought to be a barrier or ceiling on the number of Senate committees, that there ought to be financial limitation which places constraints on the capacity of the Parliament to scrutinise legislation and the conduct of the government.

PARA.TAB: Only an irresponsible government would argue than its program is more important than the scrutiny. It is an important check and balance and a very important filter for the government itself. The history of legislation being returned by the Senate because of poor drafting, mistakes, or inadequacy of legislation is legendary. Much of that is detected through the committee filter system.

We have been asked to accept a reduction in the number of committees from nine to seven simply on the basis of the capacity of the Government to man these committees—that is the truth of the matter—and because of the deteriorating vote that the Government attracts in the Senate. In Western Australia it was the lowest it has been since 1977 when we almost won Fremantle; I think it was 38 per cent this time around. And the Liberal Party got 3.8 per cent of quotas. I can understand why there is an inevitable reduction in the numbers of the Labor Party. Because of that reduction, it has a reduced capacity to man committees; because of that factor, we are expected to have a reduced number of committees. As a result we are led to have reduced scrutiny of the legislation and of the Government's performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a non-sequitur.

—I am interested to hear Senator Schacht argue that proposition because that really is the essence of the matter. It was not put in the last Parliament that we ought to have fewer than nine committees. It has not been put before and, to my knowledge, no persuasive argument has been articulated by the Government as to why it should now be seven.
—That does not affect the quality of the senators contributing to scrutiny of Bills.

—Senator Schacht will know that there is just so much any one senator can do and, as senators are distributed across the committees, it is important for them to focus on the objectives and the references before the one committee of which they are a member.

PARA.TAB: I think the Government now has 30 senators and it has 10 Ministers, which leaves 20 senators left in the pool. It has even given itself a parliamentary secretary, so it has 19 senators to service nine committees. The Government always has three senators on each committee, so if there were nine committees it would need 27 senators, but it has only 19. So it proposes to reduce the number of committees to seven simply on the basis of arithmetic. When we get to the stage where the Government's arithmetic—the numbers—is the primary and essential ingredient in determining the number of committees we have—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just because you operate like that in Western Australia—
—Senator Schacht, if you want to speak on this matter, wait until Senator Crichton-Browne has concluded.

—I am sure that Senator Schacht was joking when he was reflecting on the Liberal Party in Western Australia. The one thing that we have a glorious reputation for is absolute and thorough democracy. If there is one thing that can be said about the Liberal Party in Western Australia, it is that it is the grassroots that speaks. The voice that we hear articulated in other forums of the party is simply the echo of the ground swell of grassroots support which flourishes and lives in the Liberal Party in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Like all political parties, we have aberrations. Senator Schacht is presumably referring to the seat of Floreat. That is an aberration, but they come and go; they wash in and wash out. Mrs Constable, the present member in that seat, will soon depart and it will be held by the Liberal Party, I have no doubt about that. These frolics and side diversions are but, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) would say, the fabric on the body politic and of no great moment.

There ought to be nine committees and I appeal to the Democrats to support that proposal because the Democrats have always carried a responsible position in respect of scrutiny of legislation. They have always been enthusiastic to set up select committees when they thought there was a purpose and a need. That contrasts very nicely with the ex-finance Minister, Senator Walsh, who was so enraged at the prospect of a piece of legislation actually getting thorough scrutiny by a committee that he threatened to cut off the funding for it. I suppose that is one way of choking democracy. It reminds me of the Stuart kings who used to decide how much money the parliament would get. That very much dictated the capacity to in any way scrutinise the conduct of the king and his councillors.

I conclude by saying that I believe that nine is the number of committees we should be aiming for, but if in the end we have to settle for eight, at least it is an improvement on the seven that the Government is presently proposing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to bring the Senate up-to-date on the state of negotiations. It might be helpful and we might then get a vote.
—Having been here since 8 o'clock, I think that would be an excellent idea.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The differences are clearly before the Senate. The Opposition, as has been said again tonight, has been particularly disturbed by the Government's intention of reducing the Senate standing committees from nine to seven and consequential difficulties have flowed from that. A compromise, nevertheless, has been reached. As in all compromises, nobody is entirely happy. This compromise is that there be eight standing committees, so we only lose one.

PARA.TAB: The committee that will be saved is the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. That is a good thing. A number of honourable senators have spoken of the important work that that committee has done. At the moment it is part-way through a reference on Australian-Japanese relations. It would have been particularly embarrassing if that inquiry had been abandoned halfway through. It would have been equally difficult for that inquiry in its current state to have been picked up by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. The compromise that includes retaining the Senate foreign affairs committee is obviously a good one. We applaud it and are only disappointed that the Government did not see the importance of that committee all along.

The committee which will go is also a vitally important one, dealing with transport and communications—in other words, national infrastructure. There are few areas more important to Australia's future than its infrastructure. Much of the debate in the last few years has been about micro-economic reform and the need to upgrade Australia's infrastructure. The fact that there will not be a Senate standing committee dedicated to that responsibility is a great disappointment to us. However, that is a decision that the majority in this place—the Government and the Australian Democrats—wish to impose upon us. That is a decision that we will have to live with.

The best option to try to absorb the work of that committee would seem to be to absorb it into the existing work of the committee dealing with industry, science and technology. We would end up with a mega-committee dealing with industry, science, technology, transport and communications. One might think that that will be an impossible task; it will certainly be a very difficult task. I guess it logically follows that everything that one would want to do in the critically important areas of industry policy on the one hand, and now infrastructure on the other, will simply not get done.

We, therefore, hope that it will not be long before we on this side of the chamber have the numbers that will enable us to reinstate an infrastructure committee within the standing committee structure of this Senate. It would certainly be our intention to do that as soon as possible. For the time being, the Government and the Australian Democrats will vote that committee out of existence.

What I have just put to you, Mr Deputy President, about a new mega-committee means that we are abandoning Senator Panizza's amendment that I referred to earlier, which was to try to absorb transport within the rural affairs committee. The reason we are doing that is that we think it is important that there is a committee of this Senate dedicated to rural affairs, whereas transport obviously encompasses other than rural and primary industry matters. It might wish to look at international air travel or a monorail in Sydney. There are all sorts of subject matters that go beyond the scope of a dedicated rural committee. We think it is important to maintain the integrity of that committee and that is why we have decided not to press Senator Panizza's earlier amendment.
I think the drafting has now been completed and we might be able to vote in accordance with what I have just outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a couple of general points about the procedure in response to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill). I would like to inform honourable senators that I think we will have to have a slight interregnum here while the actual amendments are drawn up. I think that might take as long as 15 minutes. I want to respond to the substance of Senator Hill's remarks in a moment. After I have made my contribution I propose to adjourn this debate and perhaps bring on government business notice of motion No. 2, which deals with time limits. That might be a sensible way of ensuring that procedures do not—
—Why not proceed with this because I have got something totally different to say?
—The reason I make this point is that these amendments have to be drawn up. There are two amendments, they are complex and the Clerks have informed me it will take about 15 minutes.
—Senator Walters wants to speak.

—Okay, I am happy to try to assist. I accept the position of Senator Hill. There has been an attempt in good faith from all parties in the Senate to try to reach a compromise on this question of the size of standing committees, their composition and the allocation of departments. I briefly endorse Senator Hill's remarks in as far as they referred to those points. I understand that there will be eight committees, four of which will have eight members and four of which

SPEECH.PARA: will have six members. In relation to the four committees with eight members, four of those members will be from the Government, three from the Opposition and one from the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or.
—There will be four from the Government, three from the Opposition and one from the Australian Democrats.
—Or an Independent.

—Or an Independent. The Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration will be six in number, comprising three members from the Government and three from the Opposition. Three other committees will be six in number, comprising three members from the Government, two from the Opposition and one from the Australian Democrats. I am happy to indicate to the Senate what the proposed allocation of departments on those committees would be so that everyone is entirely clear where we are going.

PARA.TAB: The community affairs committee, which will be eight in number, will cover the departments of health; housing, local government and community services; social security; and veterans' affairs. The Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which will be eight in number, will cover the departments of the Attorney-General and immigration and ethnic affairs. The rural and regional affairs committee, which will be eight in number, will cover the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. The foreign affairs committee will cover the departments of foreign affairs and trade as well as defence. It will also be eight in number.

As I indicated, the next four committees will be six in number. The first is the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which will cover the parliamentary departments and the departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Treasury and finance. The environment, recreation and the arts committee will cover arts and administrative services; and environment, sport and territories. As I said before, the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training will be six in number and will include the departments of employment, education and training; and industrial relations.

Finally—there might be some argument about the name of this last committee; I have taken on board Senator Teague's very strenuous request that we include every possible portfolio area in its name—there will be a committee on industry, science, technology, transport and communications. I would prefer a shorter title, if we could find an appropriate one, that will cover industry, technology—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a ridiculous list.
—It is the Opposition's idea.
—It is your idea. It's in the book.

—This proposal to have transport and communications in with industry, science and technology comes from the Opposition. I am happy to accept it in the spirit of trying to reach a compromise. This committee covers the departments of industry, technology and regional development; tourism; and transport and communications. So that is the intent of both the Opposition and the Government in this regard.

PARA.TAB: I believe that in a few minutes Senator Teague or another senator will be able to move the formal amendment to the motion under government business order of the day No. 3 to give effect to the number of standing committees and the amendment of standing order 25. We will then be able to move to my government business notice of motion No. 1, which relates to the allocation of departments to legislative and general purpose standing committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very concerned about the reduction in the number of committees. Most things that have been said on the matter have pointed out that this measure is purely for the convenience of the Government. The Government has an unprecedented number of Ministers in this place. As a result, it does not have enough senators left to service the committee system.

PARA.TAB: The committee system is not a committee system of Government members; it is a committee system of the Senate. If it were not for the Australian Democrats supporting the idea of the committee system being the Government's system instead of the Senate's, we would not be faced with this situation; we would just be making sure that Government members worked a little harder than they do at present by perhaps having to be on two committees rather than just the one.

However, this situation leaves us with no alternative. As usual, the Democrats are voting with the Government on this procedural motion. That leaves us having to negotiate the best arrangement we can from the Government's original motion.
I have an amendment that I will move regarding the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which has been circulated. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out:

PARA.TAB: Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services

TAB.TAB: Social Security
Veterans' Affairs",

PARA.TAB: and insert:
Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services
Prime Minister and Cabinet in so far as it relates to the Office of the Status of Women

TAB.TAB: Social Security
Veterans's Affairs".

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the Democrats listened to the amendment. I am sure that they will agree with it because all it does is add coverage of the Office of the Status of Women by the community affairs committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all right.
—Senator Kernot says that she has no problem with it.
—We agree with it.
—Senator Kernot says that she will agree with my amendment. Therefore, I do not have to worry about what the Government intends to do.

PARA.TAB: It is about time that at least one of our committees looked at the status of women. It will cover a very large area. Having been chairman of the committee under our government and deputy chairman of it under the present government, I am only too well aware that we already have an overload of work, particularly with the amount of legislation that is referred to it for its scrutiny on Fridays of sitting weeks. I believe that there is no other committee that the status of women would fit neatly into, so I propose that it be dealt with by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to say a little about the proposed conglomerate committee. Over a period I have had a little experience in some of the areas it covers. Even though Senator Coulter and Senator Ferguson are the only other two senators here who have been members of it, we obviously do not need a reminder of the fact that this new committee will handle by far the greatest number of annual reports—industry, science and technology et cetera—as well as heaps and heaps of legislation.

PARA.TAB: I do not know when the Government thinks it will be possible to deal with the load of legislation that will come through from industry, science, technology, regional development, tourism, transport and communications. We will not even be able to read the reports let alone look at the legislation that will flow from them. We only have to look at the amount of legislation that is currently before us regarding transport and communications, the portfolio areas most recently added to it. The Government cannot add more to the committee's workload if it has any intention of the committee handling the job in a reasonable way.

Further, not only we will be given twice as much work as any of the other committees and twice as much work as in the past, but also this brilliant proposition is intended to cut down the number of committee members from eight to six. This new committee will have to operate at least as two subcommittees because it cannot possibly operate as one. I know for sure that Government members will be pressed fairly tightly even to attend its hearings. Although it is intended that they be able to do a reasonable amount of committee work, I do not know that that will be possible.

Unless the Minister can convince me that it is possible for this committee to operate, I will just have to keep on reminding him of the natural impediments that go with it. But I do not think he has given this the slightest thought at all. It was just a nice tidy thing to do—take something away; throw it away; cut and shut it; and put it all into one.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a proposition that came from the Opposition.
—It is a proposition that is in the Notice Paper as it came directly from the Government.
—As amended by the Opposition.
—There is no amendment to this by the Opposition. There is no amendment to what the Government has proposed since day one, and it is absolute nonsense.
—Talk to your own colleagues.

—I do not have to talk to my colleagues; I can read. I do not have to be briefed like the Government's Ministers do and like Senator Faulkner obviously does. The point of the exercise is that the proposition that the Government has put up says that industry, science, technology, regional development, tourism, transport and communications will not be handled by a committee of eight but by a committee of six, and it has to handle all the reports, all the legislation, all the references and things that come through. I do not know how Senator Faulkner could possibly know so little about the running of this place that he could think it possible.

—As I have said before, I have only been in this place for 12 months. In that time I have worked on the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I cannot help but support what Senator Archer has said about the amount of work that is involved in that committee. We already have a wide range of departments that have to be represented under industry, science and technology without adding transport and communications, when transport and communications was formerly a committee of its own which handled a wide range of subjects which might involve a tremendous amount of work both outside metropolitan areas and in the metropolitan areas of Australia. I find it hard to believe that that committee can handle all of the legislation that will come before it or be referred to it with a six member committees.

PARA.TAB: I know, as I said before, my time has not be been long on that committee, but I know the amount of work that is done. Senator Archer has been on that committee for a considerable number of years—I think he was a former chairman of the committee. If anybody knows the amount of work that is required and the number of reports that have to be tabled by that committee, Senator Archer should after some 17 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's the same as every committee.
—It is not the same as every committee because of the number of departments it represents and the amount of legislation that gets referred to it.
—I have been on it.

—Senator Kernot may have been on it, but all I am saying is that in my experience I know just how much legislation comes before that committee. I think it is ridiculous for a six man committee to try to incorporate all the work that has to be done from those departments, bearing in mind the amount of work that is already undertaken for industry, science and technology and then having to add transport and communications, which has always been a very active committee that has handled so much legislation that has been referred to it. It is quite ridiculous to think that that committee can function as a six man committee with so many departments to service and so much legislation that gets referred to it.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Faulkner) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TIME LIMITS: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That the following conditions apply to debate on motions relating to answers given to questions without notice:

TAB.TAB: (a)motions shall relate only to answers given that day to questions without notice;
(b)a Senator may speak for not more than 3 minutes on such a motion;
(c)the total time for debate on all motions relating to answers to questions without notice on any day shall not exceed 30 minutes; and
(d)the time taken in raising and determining any points of order during debate under this order shall not be regarded as part of the time allowed for debate under this order.

PARA.TAB: (2)That this order operate as a sessional order.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter came about during the period of the last Parliament when the processes of the chamber became bogged down because, after every Question Time, even on occasions when there was an urgency motion or an MPI, endless debates ensued with senators moving to take notice of an answer to a question given in Question Time. This particular sessional order was in place during the last Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the Opposition is considering amendments to this to increase the time provided in this motion for an individual senator to speak, although there is no suggestion that the time for debate on all motions relating to answers be relaxed from 30 minutes. Obviously, the Government will strongly support seeing that time limit contained at 30 minutes. I think our experience shows that this sessional order has worked well. I think it is appropriate that it be in place again for this Parliament.

The proposal itself indicates that the time taken in raising and determining points of order will not be counted into the total time for an individual speaker or debate. I think that is appropriate under the circumstances, given that often the nature of these particular debates leads to some controversy, obviously having just been dealt with in Question Time. I think that might add to the work of the chamber being more effective.

I must say I am relaxed about a suggestion that I understand will come forward from the Opposition that the time for an individual speaker to speak to such a motion will be extended. I think that has some justification and validity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Five minutes.

—I know Senator Kernot says five minutes. I must say the reason that three minutes is in this motion is that the Australian Democrats originally asked that this be limited to three minutes. If the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are relaxed about four minutes or five minutes, I will accept those constraints. The only reason three minutes is in this motion is that we received that request from the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: In trying to reach a consensus position in the chamber, as Senator Kernot knows is my want on all occasions, I just tried to ensure that we reached an agreed position. But I am relaxed if the Democrats and the Opposition care to move an amendment to extend that period to either four or five minutes. I think either of those propositions would be appropriate, and I would be happy to see such an amendment moved and accepted by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Subparagraph (1)(b), omit "3", substitute "5".

SPEECH.PARA: The history of this matter is the abuse of Question Time during the last government when Ministers used the occasion of Question Time to abuse the Opposition for its policies in particular rather than to provide serious answers on public interest matters relating to their portfolio. During Question Time there is no opportunity for the Opposition to respond to such attacks. Therefore, more often than we had in the past, we used the practice of seeking leave to move a motion after Question Time to take note of a Minister's answer and to respond in order to correct the record.

PARA.TAB: That practice was only second best because now, in the days of television, members of the public have access to a Minister's answer through the direct television coverage, but of course they do not have access to the response of the Opposition after Question Time. Even though it was second best, we thought that it was a better practice than not pursuing such matters at all. At least it meant that within the chamber there was contemporaneous debate on issues that had disturbed the Opposition which had been raised by Ministers in answer to questions.

For some time the Government adopted the practice of refusing leave. That led to various suspensions and attempted suspensions. It was decided—I think by the former Manager of Government Business—that that was too much trouble, so the Government started giving leave almost as a matter of course. The Government, however, wanted some restraint on the maximum time for such debates. That led to the development of a sessional order such as the proposed one before the Senate now, setting aside a 30-minute period with designated timeslots for each speaker to deal with such matters.

We are pleased that this motion is before the Senate again, because we think that the practice of dealing immediately thereafter with matters of a controversial nature that arise in Question Time is the Senate operating in a useful form. Some might say that it has led to more informative debates than some of the debates on matters of public importance which in the past tended to take up a great deal of this time.

There can be an argument as to how much time should be applied for this purpose. Some honourable senators on this side of the chamber would obviously argue, from an opposition perspective, that a half an hour is too limited. Nevertheless, that is the figure before the chamber at the moment and we will not seek to vary it at this time. The only variation that I will seek to make is to amend it so there is a maximum of five minutes per speaker, which is in accordance with the notice of motion I gave on the first day of this sittings.

We would also have liked the motion to be in a form that provided that, in a technical sense, leave was no longer necessary. As I read it, technically speaking, leave is still necessary, but because the Government is prepared to move this motion, I take it that it is recognising it as a practice it will respect in future, as it has in recent times. Therefore, we will support the motion, with the amendment—for which I seek the support of the Senate—that an honourable senator may speak for no more than five minutes on such a motion, rather than what the Government has provided in its form, which is that an honourable senator shall speak for no more than three minutes on such a motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —We understand that the original distribution within the half-hour was five-minute timeslots, as now proposed by the Opposition. We were quite happy to accept 30 minutes divided into five-minute slots. We understand that the Opposition then wanted to go to three-minute allocations. Now it wants to go back to five. I just want to put the record straight with respect to that. Along with the Government, we are quite relaxed about whether it is three or five minutes, although I agree with the Opposition's present position that five minutes gives more adequate time to cover matters which are raised in questions, particularly as we give Ministers four minutes to answer a question.

PARA.TAB: I want to raise another matter, not by way of amendment but just to signal our concern. It has become the practice in taking note of answers that if a particular honourable senator raises a matter in relation to a particular question, the person in the chair then asks the next person who rises whether he or she wishes to speak on the same matter. It is quite possible for the whole half-hour to be taken up with comments on the one question.

I make a plea that in future we diverge from that pattern. For example, if a person is given the call and seeks to take note of question No. 3 and the next person with the call seeks to take note of question No. 5, I ask that it be taken in that sequence so that there is a fair distribution of the available half-hour for six speakers, rather than that the person who just happens to get the call first virtually dominates the whole half-hour. I do not think that needs to be written into any sort of an order or procedure. I think it is within the power of the Chair at the time to call speakers in that sort of order. We certainly support both the motion and the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will accept the amendment moved by Senator Hill. I do not know whose idea it was—that of the Democrats or the Opposition; I only know that it was not originally my idea, even though it is encompassed within the motion that I moved. I suppose it is a little inconsistent in the sense that a speaker has five minutes to respond to an answer given in Question Time and a Minister is limited to four minutes on his or her original answer and one minute on a supplementary, but I think that four or five minutes does give any honourable senator ample opportunity to develop a case. It also gives the opportunity for a minimum of six honourable senators to speak to a motion moved to take note of an answer to a question during Question Time. I commend the new sessional order to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

"(5)That the committee report to the Senate on or before the last day of the Budget sittings 1993.
"(6)That:

TAB.TAB: (a)the chair of the committee be Senator Sherry until 30 June 1993; and

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the amendment is to appoint Senator Sherry by name as chair of the Select Committee on Superannuation until 30 June 1993 after which time, according to that formula, the leaders will agree upon a new chair, and in the absence of that agreement duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chairs and deputy chairs shall be determined by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The motion contains a loophole in that we need to nominate the new chairman before the end of this sitting of parliament. If we have not constituted the committee with the new chairman, it will not be able to meet until the Senate reconvenes in August.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is consistent with the principle that we are seeking to have implemented for all Senate committees—not just select committees but also standing committees—and, therefore, in principle we obviously agree with it. The principle is that, basically, in future the chairman will not automatically be a nominee of the Government but rather will be somebody selected by the chamber. I think that will be a major reform because the Senate will be taking control of the business of the Senate rather than allowing the Government to take control of the business of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: We have had trouble in persuading the Australian Democrats, at least in the short term, to accept that principle in relation to standing committees. I indicated earlier that in relation to the motion to set up the standing committees, I would be moving an amendment to provide a form as I have just described so that the Chair would be decided in future by a majority in this place.

As we have been temporarily unsuccessful in persuading the Democrats as to the merit of that proposal, I have decided not to press that amendment later tonight when we re-establish the standing committees. I do not want that to be interpreted in any way as backing away from the principle. We really do think it would be a good reform in the interests of the Senate and we intend to continue to seek to persuade the Australian Democrats as to the merit of that reform. We hope we will be ultimately successful and then we will be back in here in a flash with the form of the amendment that I had earlier circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing happens here in a flash at the moment.
—This will actually save some time tonight because, as I just said, I will not be moving the amendment.

PARA.TAB: At least we have made some progress in relation to select committees. We have re-established the select committee on the Victorian loans matter and that committee is actually structured so that a majority in the Senate can control the numbers. Senator Coulter will be continuing as chairman of that committee.

We have re-established what I refer to as Senator Walters's community welfare committee which is dealing with telecommunications and Senator Reynolds will be continuing to chair that committee. We are pleased to support that. In this instance, we are wanting Senator Watson, who has had a distinguished record on this select committee, to take over as chairman of the Select Committee on Superannuation. I understand that the Democrats are supportive of Senator Watson assuming that responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Please note.

—I can record that note? That is good. In the meantime, however, we recognise that part of the reference before the Superannuation Committee is being concluded and it is appropriate that the current chairman, Senator Sherry, remain in the chair for that task. That will be concluded, as I understand, by the 30 June 1993 and Senator Sherry, who of course is now also carrying the onerous burden of being a Parliamentary Secretary, will stand down from that position in accordance with Senator Kernot's amendment. The majority in the Senate will decide a successor and that successor, we expect, will be Senator Watson. So I am pleased on that basis to support the amendment that has been moved by Senator Kernot. I hope that the Democrats might see fit in due course also to incorporate the principle of this amendment within standing committees of the Senate.

—I rise to elaborate on a point which essentially lay behind what Senator Hill was saying but perhaps was not made as explicitly as it might have been; that is, that the Democrats are very happy with the process of the apportionment of Chairs to the select committees between the different parties. But we are a little nervous at this stage, particularly in view of what happened in the chamber yesterday when we debated all day long whether we should reduce the speaking time at the second reading stage from 30 minutes to 20 minutes and the power of standing committees which are dealing with legislation to obstruct the proper consideration of legislation.

PARA.TAB: We would prefer to proceed in the way in which we are now proceeding, and that is to try sharing the Chairs of the select committees. If indeed that works well, if there is not obstructionism and if the process seems to be, as Senator Hill outlined, properly preserving the scrutiny function of the Senate without playing politics with bits of legislation which should be proceeded with expeditiously, we would be very happy then to review the matter of chairmanship of the standing committees in line with what Senator Hill is saying.

That is our position. We are not totally rejecting his position; we are just a little nervous of going down that road at this stage. We will be prepared to review it and if Senator Hill wants to revisit that in the life of the next session, we will look at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

One has to know when one is done in this game and I know that we are struggling in relation to this matter.

PARA.TAB: I will not prolong the debate, but I do want to place on record that the Government does not accept this principle and it has never been accepted in this chamber or in this Parliament before tonight. The Government certainly will never embrace such a proposition. I draw attention to the sorts of comments that we have heard from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill).

For example, the Senate Select Committee on the Loans Council, to use its short name, or the Senate Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loans Council, to use its long name, is not a select committee into the Victorian loans matter as he described it. I think that is indicative of what those opposite are really on about in relation to these select committees and seeing the Chairs of these committees fall into the hands of non-Government senators.

As I have said before, it is pretty clear what the fate of Senator Kernot's amendment will be, but I implore any open-minded and objective senator to consider what the consequences of voting for that amendment will be. I ask the Senate to support the motion as it stands in the name of Senator Sherry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will now move an amendment in the form that has been circulated to the Manager of Government Business (Senator Faulkner), the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) and which will soon be circulated to all senators.

PARA.TAB: The amendment amends the motion moved by Senator Faulkner so that, instead of moving from nine committees to seven, we will move from nine committees to eight. However, the requirement in the motion that Senator Faulkner moved for 28 Government senators, 21 Opposition senators and seven senators from minority groups and Independent senators will be retained. Of the eight committees, there will be four committees of eight members and four committees of six members and, in all cases, half of the committee members will be Government senators.

In this description there is, effectively, the amalgamation of two of the standing committees that we have known over recent years. The two committees have become one and it is to be called the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. Because this is a regrettably large area of concern for one standing committee, we have ensured now that it is a committee with eight members. The one committee on which the minority groups and Independent senators are not represented is the Standing Committee on Finance and Government. In the last Parliament it did not include any representative from those senators, it only had three from the Government and three from the Opposition.

What we have here is a genuine compromise and we can still look at it with marginal regrets. Firstly, there is now a very large area of concern for one of the standing committees and we do regret that, but we have ensured that it has eight members. Secondly, we would see that from the Government's point of view, whilst there is still a call on 28 Senate positions to be provided by the Government—which was one of its major concerns with its reduced numbers of senators—it is still the same number. With regard to the Democrats, we have heard their concerns to have representation on seven committees, and those seven that they have chosen are included.
With those few words of summary, I move:
