TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has an amendment which he has circulated in the Senate. I will speak to that amendment while we are waiting for him. At the time of the debate on this broadcasting Bill—last December—the Minister understood that the ABA was doing extensive qualitative and quantitative research throughout the whole of Australia. I am sure there has been a misunderstanding in the legislation because, as the legislation presently stipulates, the ABA is the only body that has to look at the survey that is being done and it does not even have to report back to the Senate in any way. Senator Harradine has just entered the chamber. I was only speaking on his amendment to fill in until he came, so I will now hand over to Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Walters's courtesy in speaking to this matter until I arrived. I had thought that further consideration was being given by the Government and its advisers to this matter. As the Parliament knows, the philosophy behind the broadcasting services Bill is one of self-regulation, where the industry develops codes of practice and registers those codes of practice. If the ABA is not satisfied that those codes of practice have been drawn up after proper public consultation or if the terms of those codes of practice are inadequate, then the ABA can register a standard; it can make a decision which, in effect, is a standard.

PARA.TAB: Those codes of practice and standards are amendable by the Parliament under section 128 of the legislation, which is entitled `Standards and codes to be amended by parliament'. However, one decision of the ABA is not amendable by Parliament. That is the one to which this particular amendment refers. The amendment refers to schedule 2, part 6, clause 10(1)(g) which talks about a decision of the Australian Broadcasting Authority. It says, and I paraphrase, that licensees of subscription television broadcasting services are not to broadcast `R' material until such time as there has been a survey and until the ABA has approved of the broadcast of such programs.

I am clearly advised that that decision alone, as it affects program standards, is the only one that is not amendable by Parliament.The purpose of my amendment is to ensure that it is approved by the Parliament. As I indicated when I foreshadowed this amendment in my speech on the second reading, my amendment is more interventionist in this particular area than is section 128. I indicated to the Government at that stage that perhaps it should, in fairness, place that decision of the ABA in respect of program standards on the same basis as every other decision of the ABA in respect of program standards. I commend the proposition to the Senate. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 3, page 4, add the following clause:

"4. Schedule 2, Standard Conditions, Part 6, Subscription Television Broadcasting Licences, clause 10, paragraph (1)(g) of the Principal Act is amended by omitting "and the ABA has approved the broadcast of such programs;" and substituting "and the ABA has recommended, and the Parliament has, by resolution of each House, approved, the broadcast of such programs;".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are very concerned about program standards not only in television but in all forms of the media in Australia. We were very supportive of having a set of television, video, pay TV and film standards. We were very pleased when we saw that; we thought it was done very well.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that section 128, which Senator Harradine is trying to amend at the moment, talks about public standards for the depiction of various things in pay TV and what people think in general on how these things have changed over the years. When we were looking at public standards in the Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services, we found that standards had changed substantially. We were interested to see that all of us on that committee were completely normal people as far as this sort of thing goes. In relation to section 128 I will be very interested to hear what the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) has to say so that we can make up our mind on this very important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's view is that this amendment is not necessary because it is caught up by other provisions of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. That is the Government's position on this. I indicate to the committee that I am prepared to support Senator Harradine's amendment.

—Perhaps I may clarify one matter. As I understand it, under the current arrangements the ABA will in due course in accordance with the code of practice determine what the classification amounts to. The ABA having approved it, it is then in operation, but it can be amended by the Parliament, meaning both Houses of Parliament. The effect of Senator Harradine's amendment is to provide that, rather than the ABA approving it, the Parliament has to approve it, meaning both Houses of Parliament. Is that right?
—Yes, but it is Senator Harradine's amendment.

—Yes, it is my amendment. The position is that the approval of the ABA under clause 10(1)(g) is the only decision taken by the ABA in respect of program standards that is not amendable by the Parliament. What Senator Alston says about section 128 is correct. The mechanism in that section is to enable the Parliament, by a decision in accordance with the procedures outlined there, to amend other standards or codes of practice. Clause 10(1)(g) is not a standard or code of practice. This is a decision of the ABA which the Parliament has requested that body to make. All I am doing in this amendment is to ensure that that decision is the subject of approval by resolution of each House of the Parliament.
—You are correct.

—On that basis, I indicate that the Opposition will support the amendment. We accept the proposition that the Parliament in those circumstances ought to be the one to approve it, given that otherwise we are only left with section 128, which Senator Harradine says does not apply in this instance.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Collins) read a third time.
Consideration resumed.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)After clause 3, page 2, insert the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "3A.Section 94 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting in subsection (3) "by 1 March 1994" after "agree".

This amendment requires the Minister to declare a full digital transmission standard if the satellite licensees A and B cannot agree on a standard. The amendment would put a deadline of 1 March 1994 in place for the licensees to agree on the standard. By inserting the words `by 1 March 1994' after `do not agree' in section 94(3) of the principal Act, we will prevent anyone from stalling the introduction of pay TV artificially by delaying the setting of a digital standard.

Optus and a number of equipment manufacturers have recently made public statements that compressed digital video reception equipment for direct-to-home broadcasting by satellites will be commercially available by that time. This amendment will be an impetus to both manufacturers and successful licensees to meet ours and the Government's intention that Australians receive nationally available satellite pay TV services as soon as possible. As all senators know the ABC is included in satellite pay TV. If a standard has not been set by that date the Minister then has the power, under section 94(3) of the Act, to set a standard of his choosing. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to detain the Senate unnecessarily tonight so I simply indicate that in a general sense the Government will be supporting this amendment. I was going to make a few other remarks but I will make them when the appropriate clauses are being debated.

—I simply indicate that the Opposition welcomes the decision to set a fixed date. We think that will go a long way towards focusing minds in a number of directions and to ensuring that pay television does come on stream sooner rather than later, given that we have had a scandalous 13-year wait.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 4, page 2, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Allocation of other subscription television broadcasting licences

PARA.TAB: "4.Section 96 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after subsection (3) the following subsections:

TAB.TAB: '(3A) In dealing with an application for a licence under subsection (1) for a service that is dependent on an MDS system as its means of transmission or as a part of its means of transmission (whether that application is made before or after the commencement of this subsection), the ABA must not allocate such a licence before services commence under licence A, licence B or licence C.
'(3B) Subsection (3A) ceases to have effect on 31 December 1994.'.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment omits clause 4 of the Bill which prevents the allocation of subscription television broadcasting licences using MDS. In accordance with the Minister's notification to the ABA, the Democrats amendment would substitute new provisions which would put in place a better policy framework, as we believe, for pay TV.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be supporting this amendment.

—As I understand it what this proposed new clause does is say that it is not possible for the ABA to grant an MDS licence until such time as the satellite service has commenced. I simply want to point out that if the object of the exercise is to ensure a start up date that is common to both systems, then that could have been achieved just as readily by allowing licences to be granted in the same way that satellite licences will presumably be granted in the relativity near future—on whatever version goes through the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Satellite licensees will then have bankable documents but those who wish to apply to have their MDS licences for broadcast purposes will have to wait on one version—in the worst case scenario—until 1 December 1994. I would be interested to hear from the Minister or from Senator Bourne what harm it is suggested would have flowed from allowing licences to be granted on the understanding expressly that the service could not commence operations until such time as satellite services were operational.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment that has been moved by the Democrats is, to use a generic word, tougher than was previously envisaged, but I understand it. The central policy position of the Senate last year was that we would have a national subscription satellite service involving the Australian Broadcasting Corporation with two channels as part of a satellite system, with MDS able, at that time, to compete on an equal footing with the satellite which will include the ABC.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, MDS licensees will not be disadvantaged because they will be able to become broadcasters in a truly technological model. This is the central position that we adopted last year based on the assumption, wrongly as it turned out, that MDS could not threaten the viability of the satellite. MDS was always seen as an ancillary broadcaster. We will be able to commercially organise arrangements for it to be a rebroadcaster.

I point out that Senator Alston is correct in saying that this would be an outside chance in 1994. I must say that it would be a fairly outlandish scenario that brought us to that point. That is worth pointing out because the provisions of the Act, and the penalties that apply, are fairly substantial. It would be in the most extreme scenario that we would go to that sunset date.

Having said that, I must say that I have no in-principle objection—and I told Senator Bourne this—to having the sunset clause at the end of 1994, which is a new provision. I guess that is a catch-all clause so I am not objecting to that because it picks up what would have to be an outlandish situation.

I will describe what the outlandish situation would be that would make the end of 1994 very unlikely. Senator Bourne's amendment brings forward to March the time whereby licensees have to agree on a standard. When Senator Bourne was discussing with me earlier today her proposed amendments, I have to say that I mentioned July to put a generous time on it. In the original Act there was no time.

On reflection I must say—and I would be amazed if Senator Alston disagreed with me—that no-one can see everything. Flaws in Acts only occur when people find mistakes in them afterwards. I think it probably would have been wise of us to put the time limit on at that time.

Honourable senators will recall the circumstances in which that legislation went through parliament. To be perfectly frank I am amazed that it came out in as good a shape as it did. It was a fairly traumatic time and I have not forgotten the late night sittings. We have been debating procedures in the chamber today, and I must say that I certainly have not forgotten one procedure that occurred at that time that I have never seen before or since in the Senate. I have no doubt that everything that could possibly happen during the history of the Senate has happened. I did see one procedure that night that I have never seen before and Senator Alston may have forgotten about it. When we got to the point where we were once again discussing change we had Senator Alston, the former member for Bass and, I might add, the extraordinary presence in the advisers' box of the Leader of the Opposition, Dr John Hewson. At that stage we brought on the adjournment debate in the middle of the debate on the Bill in order to extend the time we had to seek advice.

I have never seen that done before or since. We had about six adjournment speeches while we were all taking counsel together about how we would change the Bill. I have to concede—and I know that the Democrat senators and Senator Harradine will remind us of this—that it was not the most perfect way to put an Act together. Senator Powell pointed that out to us in very graphic terms. In fact I read her speech in Hansard the other day and one could hardly argue with it.

I was not going to expand on this point tonight but, in respect of this amendment, it is probably an appropriate time to concede that. I do not think that was the Government's fault necessarily. It is easy now to talk about defects in the Act, but I do not think any senator who took part in the debate and was in here watching what was going on would disagree with me. We were faced with the extraordinary situation where the shadow Minister from the House of Representatives was in the advisers' box and he was then joined by the Leader of the Opposition, whom I have not seen before or since in the advisers' box in Senate chamber. Mind you, I am not saying that I want to see him there again.

I remember one week when I did not physically leave my office in Parliament House for four days. That was the last week; Senator Alston probably did not leave his office for four days either. I had departmental advisers in my office working on the constant changes that were flowing through from the Senate. I know that two of those officers, Tony Shaw and Christine Goode, who have been in the news lately, also did not leave my office for those four days, except to go home to change their clothes, have a shower and eat. I do not think it was the ideal way to pass an Act of Parliament through, and I am astonished that it survived as well as it did.

Not only am I agreeing with these amendments—and Senator Alston would agree with this—but also it was probably a sensible amendment which, when I reflected on it, we should have put in then. There was no time limit set in the Bill, but there is now. When Senator Bourne suggested March to me instead of July, I checked and I found that it should be possible for the people to do that. But there is another advantage to it, that is, because it is a firm time, it will provide a real impetus—and I am told this by industry sources—to put the resources into developing the digital technology.

The digital technology already exists. It is being broadcast on a trial basis around Australia now and I have to say it is a superb signal. The departmental laboratories here in Canberra have had access to it. It is being moved around Australia on a test basis and it is very impressive. So the technology already exists; it is simply a case of the commercial box to deliver it having to be developed. I am told that setting that date will provide a real impetus for that development to go ahead.

Potentially—and I am not overstating it because it may or may not happen—that will provide Australia with a very interesting advantage over every other country. We will be the first country in the world to develop digital PAL. There are, of course, many other PAL systems around the world. Once we have successful licence holders, resourced licence holders, once the licence is delivered—that is the key to it; we have to fix up that licence process because we have to get the industry started—and a firm date in March next year set for the standard, my advice from industry is that the effort will be put into getting this box. That will give at least the potential for an industry in Australia to export this digital PAL technology to the rest of the world. I support the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —To those who thought we had seen everything in this Senate and that, indeed, the Minister's experience in relation to the appearance of others in this chamber was somehow unique, we have tonight seen yet another first, I would have thought. I asked a question in relation to the second amendment and we have just heard eight minutes worth of speech on the first. The first amendment has already been carried.

PARA.TAB: I will ask my question again. I ask the Minister to look at the second amendment. Is the effect of it that, although there is a common start-up date in terms of operational services, even though it may be possible to obtain a satellite licence in a matter of a couple of months, it will not be possible to obtain an MDS licence, at least until 1 March 1994 and, on the extreme version, until 1 December 1994? If that is the case, why should a satellite licence holder have a bankable document but an MDS licence holder not?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did digress a bit; it is a habit I have. I will try to be more concise. What I was explaining was that the December sunset clause provision, which is a brand new provision courtesy of the Democrats, is a good one.

PARA.TAB: In March those concerned have to set the standard. If they do not set it, the Minister can set it for them. They have six months to start the service. If they do not, that becomes—and these provisions are already in the Act—a breach of their licence provisions. Under the Act, if that happens, the ABA can issue them with a directive or a notice that they are in breach of their licence conditions and advise them what they have to do to get back into their licence. If they ignore that notice under section 142, there is a penalty of $2 million for being in breach of their licence conditions, which is a fairly stiff penalty, but other provisions of the Act also provide for continuing offences—that is, a daily offence.

I am not suggesting that Senator Alston's scenario is incorrect; it is technically correct. In the real world, I would suggest that with these punitive provisions for someone parking the licence, it will be a pretty expensive exercise after they have paid whatever price it is. I am not going to speculate about what it is worth. Just let us say it is worth $100 million—I do not know, but it will be a lot of money anyway. They have paid that to get it, they then get slugged with $2 million instantly if they do not actually use it and then they pay a daily penalty. I think those provisions are pretty stiff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to have to keep at it, but the Minister has explained the various permutations and combinations that might flow from the grant of satellite licences and how long it will be after the grant of that licence before the satellite service commences. That is all very well, but my question is the following. Why should an MDS licence holder be required to wait for a grant of licence before the start-up of the satellite service? In other words, why should each of the two not be able to obtain licences now, or in the near future, and then the start-up date is determined by other factors—it may be shorter, it may be longer, but at least they are both in a position to have bankable documents.
—I understand Senator Alston's point and I did say the position that was adopted before was certainly a tougher position. It is a Democrat amendment, and I understand the purpose behind it.
—But you are supporting it.

—It is a tough position. It is only going to happen once. After the first allocation, it is not going to happen again. After that the ABA looks after it, so this is a one-off thing. I have to say that I support the amendment, as I have said, because it provides absolute certainly, and that is why I support it. We assume some things in here. I acknowledge Senator Bourne's clarification of the position she put to me. The fact is the Democrats wanted to restrict MDS to narrowcasting, except for the circumstances that were described by Senator Bourne this morning. So this amendment is very supportable. In the first instance, it provides that absolute certainty that the satellite system, with the ABC in it, will start before another system can, and I support that. We got into trouble last time for not doing it.

—There is a public perception, which I can understand, that at least one of the people who now owns a lot of the MDS licences has been or would be disadvantaged by this. But if we go through this—and I hope the Minister will correct me if I am wrong—I believe that at the moment the allocation of MDS licences is an allocation of a piece of the spectrum. If somebody has a licence they are able to use that piece of the spectrum for a certain amount of different purposes known as narrowcast and other things. In general, those pieces of the spectrum are now being used for these narrowcast or whatever uses to which they can be used without being broadcast.

PARA.TAB: The way to gain a licence for broadcast over that piece of the spectrum is to go to the ABA and say, `I would like this changed over to broadcast'—or to be under part 5 or whatever it is of the thing that we are working under. When that happens the ABA just changes it over, subject to the usual Trade Practices Commission rules in regard to cross-media considerations and all the other aspects that the Commission looks at. If the current holders of MDS licences—the current possessors of this piece of the spectrum—are doing something nefarious, the TPC will not let them change over to a broadcast licence. If they are not—I cannot say I have seen any evidence that any of the current holders of these narrowcast licences are doing anything nefarious—it will be changed over in a matter of days.

So there can quite justly be an expectation on the part of the people who now have those narrowcast licences that they will automatically be changed to broadcast licences once the satellite is up and running. We are looking for the absolute certainty that we will get the very best system. We believe that includes the ABC. We have said that all along and we still say it. I am referring to licence holder C on the satellite.

Once one of those licence holders on the satellite gets up and running—it does not have to be C; it could be A, B or C—the licences can be changed over. If the ABC is not the first up, that is up to the ABC, but it should be and I certainly recommend that it be the first. I imagine that this would happen long before 31 December—I have been told July is a reasonable starting date. The minute one of them gets up and running, the narrowcast licences are able to be changed over to broadcast licences. The current holders of narrowcast licences can then go out and get money and do deals on the reasonable expectation that they will get a broadcast licence when it is changed over, unless they are naughty people. If they are not naughty people, they will get it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe my understanding of commercial reality is different from that of others in this place. It seems to me that there is a world of difference between the two situations we are considering. In the first situation one actually has a licence in one's hand, having been granted by it the ABA based on TPC clearance, but one is restricted or governed by the start-up date of satellite services. In that situation we would say to an MDS licence holder, `You have been conducting narrowcast services already. We will look at your track record to date. We will take into account all the relevant criteria. We will grant you a licence now or in the next few months, but you cannot start up, conceivably until December of the following year'. I would have thought there was a much greater degree of comfort in that situation because one would have the certainty of knowing that one has one's licence. It has been approved and cleared but it cannot be used until a later, somewhat indeterminate time.

PARA.TAB: There is a lot to be said for the fixed start-up date because it reverses all the incentives. I think we would all acknowledge that. It has the great virtue of ensuring that those who get satellite licences in the next few months have a built-in incentive to agree on a system and start up as soon as they can.

However, what I found very interesting about the Minster's contribution was that he said that this will ensure that the satellite system will start before the other. In other words, this is a built-in legislative provision that ensures we will not have a common start-up date. Let us be clear about that. The Government is saying that the satellite service must be up and running—operational—before MDS, because we cannot even grant an MDS licence until the satellite service is up and running. So, by definition, the MDS service will not start until some time after the licence has been granted. That seems to me to be quite the opposite situation to what was put by those who have argued that this provides a common start-up date, that we are talking about technological neutrality and that on a certain particular date—which we cannot precisely identify; we can just put our provisions—we can ensure that both types of service start up at that time, if they choose to.

There is a lot to be said for that. But that is precisely what the Minister is now saying is not the case. He is making it clear that the Government now wants to ensure that the satellite system will start before MDS, and he does that by delaying the grant of MDS licences until the satellite system is operational.

I simply say to the Minister that that seems to me to provide a commercial disadvantage to the MDS licence holder. Even if we were to say, for example, that the MDS licence holder cannot start until three months after the satellite service is in place, we would have achieved our purpose of ensuring that the satellite system started before MDS but at the same time we would have given that MDS licence holder every opportunity to go out and raise funds in the marketplace on the basis of certainty. But there can be no certainty—there might be confidence—until the licence is actually granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because we obviously want to conclude these Bills tonight. I do not think that Senator Alston will argue with that. We have been over all the arguments. The purpose of this exercise tonight—whether Senator Alston agrees or disagrees with the detail of it—is to put in the certainty that we have to acknowledge, at least on the Government side, was left out last time around. That is why I am supporting these Democrat amendments.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that there is the disadvantage that Senator Alston is talking about at all. Senator Bourne has laid out the facts and the current licence holders know these facts. Let us get down to tintacks. The TPC's role is only in respect of the anti-competitive—in other words, cross-media—sections of the TPC Act. One would not have to be a very smart MDS licence holder to very readily work out whether one was going to be in conflict or even come within a thousand miles of being in conflict with that. Personally, I do not know of any current ones that are. I think the TPC has publicly indicated that sort of thing in terms of who might be in trouble and who might not be. It is highly unlikely—in fact, outlandishly unlikely, as Senator Bourne has said—that they would be.

Therefore, the only thing the licence holders have to worry about is the ABA scrutiny. The ABA scrutiny—Senator Bourne again says correctly—provides that only fit and proper people and so on will be allowed to be broadcasters. They themselves would know whether they are likely to be caught by that. The scenario Senator Bourne has laid out, a lot more clearly than I have, is correct; that is, that the licence holders themselves would know whether they were likely to fall foul of the TPC, and they would know whether they were likely to fall foul of the provisions of the ABA investigation. I am sure Senator Alston would know that that is not likely unless they had the kind of history that is alleged to be held by some people who have been in the news lately in terms of pornography and so on. They would then know that they would get these licences. This is a one-off start. It is important that the one-off start is clarified.

I think Senator Alston would probably agree, because we want to finish these Bills tonight. The Senate is sitting for the next couple of weeks. A report will be brought down in this house on a certain matter. Senator Alston knows full well that there will be endless opportunities to give me all the stick that the Senate believes I need to get. But all of us would agree that, rightly or wrongly, whether we disagree or agree with the provisions, we all want this matter finished and this legislation through tonight. I support the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I think of it—this is utterly irrelevant—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—Some relevance would help.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that sotto voce. For the last couple of days the Minister has undertaken to provide me with a formal response to my notice of motion in relation to the MDS documents.
—It was not intentional.

—I know. I just thought I would mention it now because otherwise we may find ourselves adjourning in all the haste that the Minister professes on the one hand while, on the other hand, speaking for 10 minutes at the drop of a hat. I am just reminding him of it now.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 4, page 2, add the following clause:

SPEECH.PARA: ``5. After section 96 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Monitoring of cross-media ownership of licences allocated under section 96

SPEECH.PARA: `96A.(1) The ABA, in consultation with the Trade Practices Commission, must monitor the cross-media ownership of the holders of licences allocated under section 96 in the context of the objects of this Act, particularly paragraph 3(c).
`(2) If, as a result of that monitoring, the ABA is concerned that the objects of this Act are being undermined, the ABA must report that concern to the Minister.
`(3) The Minister must cause a copy of a report under this section to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after receiving the report.'.

This amendment, which adds section 96A, requires the ABA, in consultation with the Trade Practices Commission, to monitor cross-media ownership and report to the Minister, who must then table that report in both Houses of this Parliament. This provides the flexibility to deal with developments in what is well and truly an emerging industry. The TPC procedures under the Broadcasting Services Act, plus its ongoing powers, allow the TPC to intervene in any pay TV licence allocation, licence transfer or change in ownership and control.

PARA.TAB: Satellite pay TV services will be receivable in areas where few other services are likely to be available. Therefore, they may be highly influential. They should, therefore, be subject to specific cross-media rules. This amendment extends those cross-media rules to all forms of pay TV delivery. It also extends the rules to satellite licensees after 1997, which was not formerly in the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will say very briefly that the Opposition takes the view that this is simply monitoring for the sake of monitoring. It will no doubt ensure that even more bureaucrats are paid higher salaries. At the end of the day, it is quite unnecessary. As I had understood it, the Government was scrupulously concerned to ensure that there were not cross-media rules in relation to MDS licences. We are now apparently about to go through yet another process of scrutiny for the sake of scrutiny. I simply put it on the record that we are not supporters of that sort of regulation for regulation's sake.
—That is Senator Alston's view and position and perhaps I have some sympathy with it, but all I can say is: the Democrats made me do it. I support them.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 5, page 2, add the following clause:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Matters to which conditions may relate

PARA.TAB: "6. Section 100 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a)by omitting from subsection (4) `licensee A, licensee B and licensee C' and substituting `subscription television broadcasting licensees';
(b)by inserting after subsection (4) the following subsection:
`(4A) Conditions under subsection (4) may be different for different classes of licensees.'.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment will ensure that all operators of subscription pay television will have to develop Australian industry plans as the satellite operators are already required to do. This change will set up a new regulatory playing field for all subscription television broadcasting services including satellite, microwave and cable. Local manufacturing content rules should provide Australia with the best possible industry opportunities from the introduction of pay TV by, hopefully, providing more Australian jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —From our point of view, this again is mindless regulation. Subsection (4) provides that the Minister may direct the ABA to impose a condition under the section designed to ensure that licensees A, B and C adequately involve Australian industry. It is highly subjective and means nothing in particular. But it will certainly ensure that there are plenty of highly paid people wandering around, crawling all over it and at some stage deciding that it does or does not constitute active involvement. If that is what the Democrats want—
—You are always going crook about unemployment.

—Senator Burns is right. The Government has no other solutions, so I can understand why it is espousing this one. Apart from the obvious employment benefits, I cannot see that it will do very much at all for the pay television industry, and certainly not for consumers.
—The Democrats made me do this too.
—Come on. It is like the Telecommunications Act.
—No. I am about to clarify that. This is an amendment that I support strongly.
—You are shameless.
—No. Apart from an objection about a few more bureaucrats, what is wrong with requiring Australian industry plans?
—That is right; what is wrong with it?
—That is exactly right.
—But it doesn't.
—But why oppose it? I do not want to get into a debate.
—You said that.
—Okay, fine. What is wrong with it? Nothing.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 6, page 2, add the following clause:

SPEECH.PARA: "7.Section 215 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section is substituted:

`215.(1) The Minister must, before 1 July 1997, conduct a review of the television broadcasting industry to assess the national benefits that would accrue if more than 3 commercial television broadcasting services were permitted in licence areas.

`(2) The Minister must, as soon as practicable, but in any case before 1 July 1997, conduct a review of the operation of the condition relating to Australian content on satellite subscription television broadcasting licensees, including the feasibility of increasing to 20% the level of expenditure required under section 102.'.".

My last amendment is dear to the hearts of Democrats, although I am not too sure about the Opposition or, indeed, the Government. It amends subsections 215(1) and (2) of the original Bill. The review of the television broadcasting industry is supposed to be carried out by 1 July 1997, this requires the Minister to bring that forward and to ask that the ABA assess the feasibility of increasing the level of expenditure required under section 102—expenditure on Australian drama on these channels—to 20 per cent. As the Senate will recall, this was the level which we wanted originally in the Bill. At the moment, it is 10 per cent. We want the ABA to look at this as soon as possible—before the date in the original Act—and to look at putting it up another 10 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say is that if the Australian Democrats are in the business of wanting to ensure that the product costs as much as possible and, therefore, that as many consumers as possible find it more expensive than they would prefer, they are on the right track.
—Because of Australian content?
—Who says that is what they want?

—I indicate that we will be supporting this amendment. But I anticipate the reservations that Senator Bourne expressed. This was debated at length. The Government rejected the imposition of the 20 per cent content because we thought it was too high and was likely to cripple an emerging pay TV industry in terms of production costs. There is no doubt that Australian production costs are very high, but there is also no doubt—I do not think very many Australians would disagree—that it is in the national interests of this country to have the maximum amount of Australian content on the media.

PARA.TAB: I might say that that was very much in my mind in trying to maintain a firm role for the ABC in a service that could afford to pay for it. Let us be frank: it is an expensive product. No other television service in Australia produces the amount of Australian production that the ABC does. But I concede that Senator Alston is right about that.

I will make one important point; I said it to Senator Bourne when she canvassed this proposition with me earlier today. I have an obligation, out of courtesy, if nothing else, to consult the ABA on this matter because it is doing the review. I will be saying to the ABA—and I give this commitment—that it should bring forward the review to a point after the industry starts where it feels that the industry has operated long enough for it to have sufficient information available to make that decision.
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not know what this industry will do. Senator Kernot should have a look at the experience around the world. It might succeed—and I hope it does—but it might also fall on its face. But I will do that. As far as I am concerned—I do not want to put a figure on it—my view is that the pay TV service should carry as much Australian content as it can.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise a very serious concern that has been brought to my attention about racial discrimination in the Queensland Parliament by none less than the Premier of the Queensland Government, Mr Wayne Goss, and one of his Ministers, Mr Mackenroth.

PARA.TAB: I have been absolutely disgusted to read in the Hansard of the constant, sometimes subtle—and of today's order not so subtle—racial slurs and attacks on the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Santo Santoro. Mr Santoro is of Italian descent—he was born in Sicily—but has been living in Australia for some 29 years. Mr Santoro is a highly-qualified person in his own right who has made his mark in his own right. He has not been given a leg-up by anybody. He has two degrees; one with honours. Yet this Queensland Government is prepared to attack him in a way which I think is absolutely and utterly appalling and degrading to all people of overseas origin. This Queensland Government is part of a labour movement throughout Australia that trumpets loud and strong about the benefits of anti-discrimination legislation, yet this Queensland Labor Government can make constant attacks on Mr Santoro.

I want to make sure that the Senate understands exactly what has been happening up there. Mr Goss has made constant references to Mr Santoro's history. When speaking in the Legislative Assembly on 11 May, Mr Santoro said:

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, this is the beginning of an exercise by the Labor Party to deny our history. I do not know what Government members have against our history. We should be proud of it.
To this, Mr Goss interjected: `What's your history?'. Mr Santoro went on to say:
I was not born of English stock. The Premier can be abusive—he can mutter words of abuse under his breath—but I am very proud of my history.
And so he should be. Mr Goss went on further to drop in his little bit about his real agenda. He said:
We might as well abolish the Senate, because it no longer represents the States.

Mr Santoro went on to accuse Mr Goss of being a constitutional vandal, which I think is a very mild statement considering what Mr Santoro has had to endure from the Premier. Today Mr Mackenroth happened to say to Mr Santoro:
You are from Sicily. I cannot hold you responsible for the Mafia, can I?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a disgrace. He is the person who has been reinstated to the Cabinet after questionable behaviour.
—Who said that?
—Mr Mackenroth.
—I think that is disgraceful.

—Mr Mackenroth is a member of the Labor Party—Senator Collins's party—in the Queensland Government. I am pleased to hear that the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) and Senator Collins are agreeing with my assertion that this is a disgraceful attack on Mr Santoro. Mr Santoro is a fine, respectable man. I have known Mr Santoro personally for some 15 years and I know that he is held in very high regard in Queensland, as he has been throughout Australia in the organisations with which he and I have been involved. I think this is a huge example of hypocrisy by the Goss Government. It also shows an enormous degree of ignorance and insensitivity. I think it is dreadful to suggest that because someone is born in Sicily—or Italy in general—he or she must somehow be connected with the Mafia.
—He would probably know more about it than Mr Santoro, in my opinion.

—I acknowledge that. Many would probably consider that what the Leader of the Democrats has just said is a truism. It is appalling to think that the Minister was forced over quite an extended period to withdraw, yet I understand from Queensland sources that the persecution still continues.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that the Queensland Government would be far better served by addressing the problems of the drought, unemployment, the police issues and the problems within the Department of Primary Industries than by daring to attack Mr Santoro in such a dreadful, hypocritical and absolutely unjustified manner. Mr Santoro deserves better; the Australian public deserves better; and, most of all, the people of Queensland should be able to expect that a government is not going to cast a racial slur against any member of the community who was born overseas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, I very rarely speak in the adjournment debate. I do so tonight to correct a very serious charge which was laid against me today in the Senate by Senator O'Chee. In the current circumstances, the record does have to be corrected. Before I do that, I want to speak briefly on another matter.

PARA.TAB: I recently saw on television a very interesting profile of the famous American evangelist Billy Graham. I am a Catholic, not a Baptist. I want to relate an experience I had as a young person—I think I must have been only 10 or 12. I travelled by bus a very long way to hear Billy Graham speak at a Sydney stadium. That was a long time ago. I can still remember that night. Thousands of people were present.

I mention that because one thing really struck me right at the end of the interview, when the last question was asked. Whether we agree or disagree with Billy Graham's religion or position, it must be said that he has campaigned on a lot of moral issues throughout his life. I think he is in his seventies now. Right at the end of the interview, the interviewer said to him, `Dr Graham, if you had one choice, if you could push a button that would rid the world of what you believe is its worst feature in terms of things that disturb world peace and tranquillity, what would you push the button to rid the world of?'. I was sitting there thinking of heresy and all the rest of it. Billy Graham thought for a minute and said, `Well, if I had to push a button to rid the world of just one evil that I think the world would most benefit from, I would press the button to rid the world of racism'. And I agree with him.

In the Senate today, Senator O'Chee alleged that I had lied to the Federal Court—apart from being disorderly, but I am not worrying about that—and had deliberately and blatantly misled the Senate, which is something I have never done, by claiming I had received written advice from Mr John Doherty that the MDS decision was lawful. This record must be corrected. I have said today—and I believe it to be true—that I do not think it is wise for politicians to discuss cases when they are currently before courts, particularly when the politicians concerned are the subject of the court action. These assertions—which were highly disorderly, apart from anything else—have to be corrected because they are not true.

Senator O'Chee claimed that my statements to the court and to the Senate were in clear contradiction to written advice I received from Mr Doherty `on Thursday 28 January'. The advice was among the scores of documents lodged with the Federal Court. I said earlier that these documents are very much in the public domain.

Senator O'Chee's interpretation is entirely wrong on every single count. Read in the whole, Mr Doherty's advice says that I must not take any action which can be inferred as acting against the general principles of the Act—and I did not. Senator O'Chee is labouring under the misapprehension that I directed the ABA to act against the principles of the legislation.

Senator O'Chee claimed that he read the transcript provided to Senator Alston by this office. I have to say that he cannot have done so. Either that or he simply cannot understand the legal options set out in Mr Doherty's advice and how the advice relates to the Broadcasting Services Bill. That is one explanation; another is that he is deliberately misleading the Senate and the general public. I do not accuse him of that because I think, frankly, that he has not read the transcript—he couldn't have—and he certainly has not carefully read that written advice.

The central point of the case which was put by Mr Horton QC for Mr Cosser was that there was something in the Broadcasting Services Bill that my decision deliberately subverted or tried to overcome by some sort of executive amendment to the statute. However, as Mr Heydon QC pointed out in his summing up, no statutory regime was enshrined in the Bill for the introduction of pay television. The summing up states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no word of phrase in the legislation which says anything about MDS licences being granted first.

That statement is found on page 90 of the transcript. Mr Heydon said that Mr Cosser's counsel had submitted that my decision on 29 January meant satellite would come first and MDS second or third. My decision, however, meant that they would both be brought in at the same time.

PARA.TAB: My decision was taken to ensure that MDS did not threaten the viability of satellite pay, thereby robbing many people outside of major cities from receiving pay television. Most importantly in terms of the decision I took, the role of the ABC would also have been injured beyond doubt, something which this Senate specifically insisted in the Act should not happen—the ABC should have a role. That was under threat and that is principally why I took the decision I did.

This is entirely consistent with the principles of the Act which seek to promote the availability of the most diverse range of radio and television services to audiences around the country. It is in the objects of the Act. The Act also seeks to achieve a regulatory environment which will facilitate the development of a broadcasting industry which is efficient, competitive and responsive to audience needs. It was in my view entirely appropriate for me to take the actions I did in those circumstances.

As the Federal Court was told, I was not seeking to change or suspend the law. I merely used the wide discretionary legal powers available to me to avoid what I saw as a situation which would disadvantage a large number of Australians.
Senator O'Chee's troubles do not stop there in terms of the inaccuracies. I might add, the court transcript reveals how inaccurate his assertions are, so he cannot have read the court transcript.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does he know you are talking tonight?

—No, but I am quite happy for you to ring him up, but he might just get himself into more trouble. The document he read from was in fact advice electronically mailed to Roger Beale, Christine Goode and Rohan Buettel. If he has the advice, he should have a look at the top of it and see who it was addressed to. These people are officers of the department. It was never sent to me, never seen by me at all. It had no reason to be. It was internal departmental advice taken during the officers' construction of the tender process. I never saw it, nor should I have ever seen it. So the assertions that I received written advice are absolutely and blatantly untrue.

PARA.TAB: I might add that that was made clear during the court proceedings. If Senator O'Chee in making these serious charges—and they are damned serious—had read the transcript, he would have seen that because it is contained in the court transcript. Of course, he cheerfully ignored it. If one takes what he said on its face value that he read the transcript, one will come to the conclusion that he is either deliberately misleading the Senate on this matter—and I do not accuse him of that—or he has not read it very carefully.

I told the Federal Court—it is in the transcript—that I never received written advice from Mr Doherty on these issues and never asked for written advice. That is correct; I never did. The advice was conveyed to me orally during the numerous phone conversations I had with senior departmental officers and my own advisers. Senator O'Chee should read that.

Over two days of telephone conferences, I received oral advice. These were telephone conferences with the department. Because I am in Darwin I actually have a conference facility in my office. It is a cheap one—it only costs $1,000 from Telecom but it is very good and I commend it. I often have telephone conferences and find, particularly when you are talking to people you know, that the extra vision from a teleconference does not add much to it.

I had many of those telephone conferences over that couple of days in which officers from the department were involved. I point out an obvious fact that the officers of the legal section of the Department of Transport and Communications are specialists in communications law. The officers in my department and Mr Doherty were in fact the people who provided the drafting instructions for the Act that I was seeking advice on. So arguably they would know as much about it as anyone else. That written advice was never seen by me. The one piece of written advice I did get of course, its having been sent to me, was the advice which said, `You have the express powers', et cetera which I tabled this morning.

There is another grave misinterpretation that has been placed on this—not just by Opposition members. Fair enough, they are entitled to have a go; I cannot complain. I had 10 years in Opposition, five as leader, and I had enough goes in my time and delivered enough flak to not complain about getting a bit back. That other grave misinterpretation has also been placed by members of the press gallery who have just jumped into this issue. This is not an issue one can jump into. It is so complex that anybody that just sits in front of the old keyboard and the visual display at a newspaper office and bashes out the story without having read at least 500 or 600 pages to get the story right is bound to make a mistake—and people have. People have read the departmental minutes, seen the assertions made that were referred to from the day before I took the decision and said, `You were told that this was not the way to go'.

There is a simple and correct explanation for that. Many of the options then being discussed were options which I rejected and which in my view would have required amendments. As I mentioned in the Senate, one of the options being actively discussed, because all options were being considered, was to issue a direction to prescribe narrowcasting for pay only—in other words, to knock it out of the broadcast role completely in line with proposals that were put to me during the debate. So the option that I finally adopted was in fact not the option that many of these advices were referring to. But nobody has bothered to check that little fact.

Senator O'Chee began his remarks by claiming that this debate was about decency, and that staggered me. I have to say again that I have no rigid views on sub judice matters. There are a lot of interpretations about sub judice and I do not think it should be applied narrowly, but I certainly do think it is not fair to expect a politician such as myself to canvass matters that are before a court when that politician is himself the subject of legal action. Potentially it is attacking a mute target. That is why I am saying that it is not fair. I might add that I do not think it is very sensible—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you a mute target?

—For the simple reason that if people make free with the court transcript on a decision that has not yet been brought down, when part of the matter before the court is that I abused my public office in deliberately taking a decision that I knew not to be lawful—that is the charge the court is going to have to make a determination on; it is before the court—I do not think it is fair for people to set themselves up in here as judges and to run the transcript when sensibly I should not discuss it at all.

PARA.TAB: I am very unhappy and reluctant to have to discuss it now. But having effectively been accused of these very grave charges in a most disorderly way, I feel I have no obligation in that respect. I am very reluctant to do it and not because I am afraid of the truth. I make the obvious point that if I were afraid of the truth I would never have voluntarily gone to the Federal Court, sat in a box for three hours under cross-examination and given evidence on oath. It is the first time I have ever been cross-examined in a court in my life and I found it a very trying experience. Even though I have been in public life for 16 years, it is a different quantum to sit in the court and give evidence. It is very intimidating and I would not have done that if I had been afraid of the truth.

But what I am asking is for people, out of common decency, to stop canvassing these issues in here when they know I am the subject of a court action and cannot really reply to them properly, because the matter is currently before the court and a judgment has not been brought down. I do not think that is fair, particularly when that canvassing is grossly inaccurate and comes from people who could not sensibly make an assertion unless they had sat down and read the full 100 pages of the court transcript—which they clearly have not done—and all of the documents. If they had done that, and if Senator O'Chee had done that, I have to say with sweet reason to him, he would see that he was wrong and the grave charges that he has made against me in this Senate would be wrong.

If at the end of the day the court makes that decision, I hope that Senator O'Chee will consider that perhaps it was not wise to quote from court transcripts in a case that has not been heard when the subject, the person he is talking about, cannot really effectively and properly respond to him. I think it is neither very wise nor conducive to the system of justice that he does that. If Senator O'Chee would leave the legal theatrics to the professionals or the cast of LA Law, I really must say that I think we would all be a lot better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to bring to the attention of the Senate the continuing saga of the F3 Freeway, which is continuing because of the poor planning of the Federal ALP Government. The Federal Government has finally got around to allowing the next stage of the F3—the main northbound freeway out of Sydney—to connect to the New England Highway.

PARA.TAB: The previous plan touted by the former Minister for Land Transport, Mr Bob Brown, was to end the F3 in the middle of a swamp, 8 kilometres short of a satisfactory intersection with the New England Highway. The Government's plan was then to carry the heavy traffic between Sydney and the north of New South Wales over that 8 kilometres of residential road called Lenaghans Drive. This will come into effect in December this year and it will last for at least two years. This of course is a ludicrous situation. It will result in bottlenecks for northbound traffic, particularly at Christmas time; it will result in serious traffic hazards and make life exceptionally uncomfortable for the residents of Lenaghans Drive.

One of the most amazing aspects of this saga is the fact that the additional traffic burden created on local roads due to the truncated freeway directly affects the Charlton electorate of the former Minister for Land Transport. But the new plan is only to build the northbound lanes of the new carriageway. All southbound traffic will continue to use Lenaghans Drive. This of course means that Lenaghans Drive becomes a one-way road which will create severe traffic problems for the residents of the area. For example, should a resident of Lenaghans Drive wish to visit someone who lives half a mile to the north on the other side of the road, that resident needs to get on the northbound carriageway of the F3, travel all the way out to Beresfield and then travel south again on Lenaghans Drive; this trip could be up to 16 kilometres.

Additionally, the safety problems have not been adequately addressed. A residential road which will be turned into a carriageway for one of Australia's major transport routes will be totally unsuitable for local traffic. The pedestrians and local traffic will be placed in danger, and this will be heightened by impatience and inconvenience.

So, as the Senate can see, although the announcement to extend the F3 to connect with the New England Highway is to be welcomed, it is only half the solution to the Lenaghans Drive nightmare. It is expected to take over two years to complete the northbound lane to Beresfield and upgrade Lenaghans Drive as the southbound lane. Then, if time and funds permit, another carriageway will be built for the southbound traffic allowing Lenaghans Drive to revert to a local road. However, this extra carriageway is not expected for at least another 10 years. Given the history of the F3, which has been under construction now for 30 years, we probably will be waiting for the extra traffic lanes for about another 20 years.

Additionally, while all the earthworks are being done for the F3 northbound lane, the Government could also commence work on the southbound lane thus containing costs. What has happened is that this Federal ALP Government, which has the funding responsibility for the federal roads system, should immediately make money available and fully support the proper completion of the F3 Freeway.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The Australian Nursing Assessment Council (ANAC) was established in 1982 with the approval of the nursing registration authorities in the various States and Territories. It operated as a non-statutory body with its own constitution within the network of the Council on Overseas Professional Qualifications (COPQ) Panels and that network in association with the National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition (NOOSR). It remained formally under the NOOSR umbrella until its abolition on 30 June 1992. On 1 July 1992, the Australian Nursing Council was established as an independent body and subsumed the functions of ANAC.

(a) Before 1 July 1992, ANAC acted as an independent unit centrally assessing the qualifications of overseas-trained nurses applying to practise in Australia; assessment guidelines were based on the requirements of the various State registration authorities for nursing.
(b) The ANAC secretariat was housed in the facilities of the COPQ 1982-89 and then within the facilities of NOOSR 1989-30 June 1992.
(c, d & e) Not applicable, this is a defunct body.
(f) No specific Commonwealth funding was provided. In the period 1989-92 NOOSR provided accommodation for the ANAC secretariat and covered postage and telephone costs.
